00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
Do we live in a borderless world?

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
Before you answer that, have a look at this map.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:19.958
Contemporary political map shows

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
that we have over 200 countries in the world today.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:25.958
That's probably more than at any time in centuries.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
Now, many of you will object.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
For you this would be a more appropriate map.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
You could call it TEDistan.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
In TEDistan, there are no borders,

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
just connected spaces and unconnected spaces.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:41.958
Most of you probably reside in one of the 40 dots

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
on this screen, of the many more

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.958
that represent 90 percent of the world economy.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:50.958
But let's talk about the 90 percent of the world population

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958
that will never leave the place in which they were born.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:58.958
For them, nations, countries, boundaries, borders still matter a great deal,

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:01.958
and often violently.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
Now here at TED, we're solving some of the great

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
riddles of science and mysteries of the universe.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
Well here is a fundamental problem we have not solved:

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
our basic political geography.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
How do we distribute ourselves around the world?

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.958
Now this is important, because border conflicts

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.958
justify so much of the world's military-industrial complex.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
Border conflicts can derail

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
so much of the progress that we hope to achieve here.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
So I think we need a deeper understanding

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
of how people, money, power,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
religion, culture, technology

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
interact to change the map of the world.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
And we can try to anticipate those changes,

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.958
and shape them in a more constructive direction.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
So we're going to look at some maps of the past,

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
the present and some maps you haven't seen

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.958
in order to get a sense of where things are going.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
Let's start with the world of 1945.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
1945 there were just 100 countries in the world.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
After World War II, Europe was devastated,

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
but still held large overseas colonies:

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:02.958
French West Africa, British East Africa, South Asia, and so forth.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
Then over the late '40s,

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
'50s, '60s, '70s and '80s,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
waves of decolonization took place.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:10.958
Over 50 new countries were born.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
You can see that Africa has been fragmented.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:16.958
India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, South East Asian nations created.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:20.958
Then came the end of the Cold War.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
The end of the Cold War and the disintegration of the Soviet Union.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.958
You had the creation of new states in Eastern Europe,

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
the former Yugoslav republics and the Balkans,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
and the 'stans of central Asia.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
Today we have 200 countries in the world.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
The entire planet is covered

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
by sovereign, independent nation-states.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:44.958
Does that mean that someone's gain has to be someone else's loss?

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
Let's zoom in on one of the most strategic areas of the world,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Eastern Eurasia.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
As you can see on this map,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
Russia is still the largest country in the world.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
And as you know, China is the most populous.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
And they share a lengthy land border.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
What you don't see on this map

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
is that most of Russia's 150 million people

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
are concentrated in its western provinces

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
and areas that are close to Europe.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:10.958
And only 30 million people are in its eastern areas.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
In fact, the World Bank predicts

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
that Russia's population is declining

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
towards about 120 million people

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
And there is another thing that you don't see on this map.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
Stalin, Khrushchev and other Soviet leaders

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
forced Russians out to the far east

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
to be in gulags, labor camps,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:29.958
nuclear cities, whatever the case was.

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
But as oil prices rose,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
Russian governments have invested in infrastructure

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
to unite the country, east and west.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
But nothing has more perversely impacted

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
Russia's demographic distribution,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
because the people in the east, who never wanted to be there anyway,

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
have gotten on those trains and roads

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
and gone back to the west.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
As a result, in the Russian far east today,

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
which is twice the size of India,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
you have exactly six million Russians.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
So let's get a sense of what is happening in this part of the world.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
We can start with Mongolia, or as some call it, Mine-golia.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
Why do they call it that?

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
Because in Mine-golia, Chinese firms operate

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
and own most of the mines -- copper, zinc, gold --

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:13.958
and they truck the resources south and east into mainland China.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
China isn't conquering Mongolia.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
It's buying it.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
Colonies were once conquered. Today countries are bought.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:25.958
So let's apply this principle to Siberia.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
Siberia most of you probably think of

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
as a cold, desolate, unlivable place.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
But in fact, with global warming and rising temperatures,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
all of a sudden you have vast wheat fields

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:39.958
and agribusiness, and grain being produced in Siberia.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
But who is it going to feed?

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
Well, just on the other side of the Amo River,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
in the Heilongjiang and Harbin provinces of China,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
you have over 100 million people.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
That's larger than the entire population of Russia.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
Every single year, for at least a decade or more,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
[60,000] of them have been voting with their feet,

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:03.958
crossing, moving north and inhabiting this desolate terrain.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
They set up their own bazaars and medical clinics.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
They've taken over the timber industry

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
and been shipping the lumber east, back into China.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
Again, like Mongolia,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:16.958
China isn't conquering Russia. It's just leasing it.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:20.958
That's what I call globalization Chinese style.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
Now maybe this is what the map of the region

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
might look like in 10 to 20 years.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:28.958
But hold on. This map is 700 years old.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
This is the map of the Yuan Dynasty,

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
led by Kublai Khan, the grandson of Genghis Khan.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
So history doesn't necessarily repeat itself,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
but it does rhyme.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
This is just to give you a taste of what's happening in this part of the world.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
Again, globalization Chinese style.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
Because globalization opens up all kinds of ways for us to

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:52.958
undermine and change the way we think about political geography.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
So, the history of East Asia in fact,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
people don't think about nations and borders.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
They think more in terms of empires and hierarchies,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
usually Chinese or Japanese.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
Well it's China's turn again.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
So let's look at how China is re-establishing

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
that hierarchy in the far East.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
It starts with the global hubs.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
Remember the 40 dots on the nighttime map

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
that show the hubs of the global economy?

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
East Asia today has more of those global hubs

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
than any other region in the world.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
Tokyo, Seoul, Beijing, Shanghai,

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
Hong Kong, Singapore and Sidney.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
These are the filters and funnels of global capital.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
Trillions of dollars a year are being brought into the region,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
so much of it being invested into China.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
Then there is trade.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
These vectors and arrows represent ever stronger

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
trade relationships that China has

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
with every country in the region.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
Specifically, it targets Japan

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
and Korea and Australia,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
countries that are strong allies of the United States.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
Australia, for example, is heavily dependent

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:53.958
on exporting iron ore and natural gas to China.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
For poorer countries, China reduces tariffs

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
so that Laos and Cambodia can sell their goods more cheaply

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
and become dependent on exporting to China as well.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
And now many of you have been reading in the news

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
how people are looking to China

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:11.958
to lead the rebound, the economic rebound, not just in Asia, but potentially for the world.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
The Asian free trade zone, almost free trade zone, that's emerging

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:19.958
now has a greater trade volume than trade across the Pacific.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
So China is becoming the anchor of the economy in the region.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Another pillar of this strategy is diplomacy.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:29.958
China has signed military agreements with many countries in the region.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
It has become the hub of diplomatic institutions

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
such as the East Asian Community.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
Some of these organizations don't even have

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
the United States as a member.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
There is a treaty of nonaggression between countries,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
such that if there were a conflict between China and the United States,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
most countries vow to just sit it out,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
including American allies like Korea and Australia.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
Another pillar of the strategy,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
like Russia, is demographic.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
China exports business people, nannies, students,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
teachers to teach Chinese around the region,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
to intermarry and to occupy ever greater

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
commanding heights of the economies.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
Already ethnic Chinese people

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
in Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
are the real key factors and drivers

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
in the economies there.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
Chinese pride is resurgent in the region

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
as a result.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
Singapore, for example, used to ban Chinese language education.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Now it encourages it.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
If you add it all up what do you get?

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
Well, if you remember before World War II,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
Japan had a vision

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
for a greater Japanese co-prosperity sphere.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
What's emerging today is what you might call

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
a greater Chinese co-prosperity sphere.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
So no matter what the lines on the map tell you

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
in terms of nations and borders,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
what you really have emerging in the far east

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
are national cultures,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
but in a much more fluid, imperial zone.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
All of this is happening without firing a shot.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
That's most certainly not the case in the Middle East

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
where countries are still very uncomfortable

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
in the borders left behind by European colonialists.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:05.958
So what can we do to think about borders differently in this part of the world?

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
What lines on the map should we focus on?

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
What I want to present to you is what I call

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
state building, day by day.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
Let's start with Iraq.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
Six years after the U.S. invasion of Iraq,

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
the country still exists more on a map than it does in reality.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
Oil used to be one of the forces holding Iraq together;

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:26.958
now it is the most significant cause of the country's disintegration.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
The reason is Kurdistan.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
The Kurds for 3,000 years

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
have been waging a struggle for independence,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
and now is their chance to finally have it.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
These are pipeline routes, which emerge from Kurdistan,

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
which is an oil-rich region.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
And today, if you go to Kurdistan,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
you'll see that Kurdish Peshmerga guerillas

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
are squaring off against the Sunni Iraqi army.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
But what are they guarding?

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
Is it really a border on the map?

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
No. It's the pipelines.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
If the Kurds can control their pipelines, they can set the terms

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
of their own statehood.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
Now should we be upset about this, about the potential disintegration of Iraq?

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
I don't believe we should.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
Iraq will still be the second largest oil producer in the world,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
behind Saudi Arabia.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
And we'll have a chance to solve a 3,000 year old dispute.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Now remember Kurdistan is landlocked.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
It has no choice but to behave.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
In order to profit from its oil

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
it has to export it through Turkey or Syria,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
and other countries, and Iraq itself.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
And therefore it has to have amicable relations with them.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
Now lets look at a perennial conflict in the region.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
That is, of course, in Palestine.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
Palestine is something of a cartographic anomaly

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
because it's two parts Palestinian, one part Israel.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
30 years of rose garden diplomacy

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
have not delivered us peace in this conflict.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
What might? I believe that what might

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
solve the problem is infrastructure.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
Today donors are spending billions of dollars on this.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
These two arrows are an arc,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
an arc of commuter railroads and other infrastructure

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
that link the West Bank and Gaza.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
If Gaza can have a functioning port

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
and be linked to the West Bank, you can have a viable Palestinian state,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
Palestinian economy.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:07.958
That, I believe, is going to bring peace to this particular conflict.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:11.958
The lesson from Kurdistan and from Palestine

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
is that independence alone, without infrastructure,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
is futile.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
Now what might this entire region look like

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:22.958
if in fact we focus on other lines on the map besides borders,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
when the insecurities might abate?

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
The last time that was the case was actually

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
a century ago, during the Ottoman Empire.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
This is the Hejaz Railway.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.958
The Hejaz Railway ran from Istanbul to Medina via Damascus.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
It even had an offshoot running to Haifa

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
in what is today Israel, on the Mediterranean Sea.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
But today the Hejaz Railway lies in tatters, ruins.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
If we were to focus on reconstructing these curvy lines on the map,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
infrastructure, that cross the straight lines, the borders,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
I believe the Middle East would be a far more peaceful region.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
Now let's look at another part of the world,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
the former Soviet Republics of Central Asia, the 'stans.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
These countries' borders originate from Stalin's decrees.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:05.958
He purposely did not want these countries to make sense.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
He wanted ethnicities to mingle

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
in ways that would allow him to divide and rule.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
Fortunately for them, most of their oil and gas resources

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
were discovered after the Soviet Union collapsed.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
Now I know some of you may be thinking, "Oil, oil, oil.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
Why is it all he's talking about is oil?"

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
Well, there is a big difference in the way we used to talk about oil

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
and the way we're talking about it now.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
Before it was, how do we control their oil?

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
Now it's their oil for their own purposes.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
And I assure you it's every bit as important to them

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:36.958
as it might have been to colonizers and imperialists.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
Here are just some of the pipeline projections

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
and possibilities and scenarios

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
and routes that are being mapped out for the next several decades.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
A great deal of them.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
For a number of countries in this part of the world,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
having pipelines is the ticket to becoming part of the global economy

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
and for having some meaning

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
besides the borders that they are not loyal to themselves.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
Just take Azerbaijan.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
Azerbaijan was a forgotten corner of the Caucuses,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:03.958
but now with the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline into Turkey,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:07.958
it has rebranded itself as the frontier of the west.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
Then there is Turkmenistan, which most people think of

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
as a frozen basket case.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
But now it's contributing gas across the Caspian Sea

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
to provide for Europe,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
and even a potentially Turkmen-

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:23.958
Afghan-Pakistan-India pipeline as well.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
Then there is Kazakhstan, which didn't even have a name before.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:29.958
It was more considered South Siberia during the Soviet Union.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
Today most people recognize Kazakhstan

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
as an emerging geopolitical player. Why?

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.958
Because it has shrewdly designed pipelines to flow across the Caspian,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:41.958
north through Russia, and even east to China.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
More pipelines means more silk roads, instead of the Great Game.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
The Great Game connotes dominance of one over the other.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
Silk road connotes independence and mutual trust.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
The more pipelines we have, the more silk roads we'll have,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
and the less of a dominant Great Game competition

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
we'll have in the 21st century.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
Now let's look at the only part of the world that really has brought down its borders,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
and how that has enhanced its strength.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
And that is, of course, Europe.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
The European Union began as just the coal and steel community of six countries,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
and their main purpose was really to keep the rehabilitation of Germany

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
to happen in a peaceful way.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
But then eventually it grew into 12 countries,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
and those are the 12 stars on the European flag.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
The E.U. also became a currency block,

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:30.958
and is now the most powerful trade block in the entire world.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
On average, the E.U. has grown by one country per year

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
since the end of the Cold War.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
In fact most of that happened on just one day.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
In 2004, 15 new countries joined the E.U.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
and now you have what most people consider

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
a zone of peace spanning 27 countries

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
and 450 million people.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:52.958
So what is next? What is the future of the European Union?

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
Well in light blue, you see the zones

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
or the regions that are at least two-thirds

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
or more dependent on the European Union

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
for trade and investment.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
What does that tell us? Trade and investment tell us

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:06.958
that Europe is putting its money where its mouth is.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
Even if these regions aren't part of the E.U.,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
they are becoming part of its sphere of influence.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
Just take the Balkans. Croatia, Serbia

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
Bosnia, they're not members of the E.U. yet.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
But you can get on a German ICE train

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
and make it almost to Albania.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
In Bosnia you use the Euro currency already,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
and that's the only currency they're probably ever going to have.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:30.958
So, looking at other parts of Europe's periphery, such as North Africa.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
On average, every year or two,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
a new oil or gas pipeline opens up under the Mediterranean,

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
connecting North Africa to Europe.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
That not only helps Europe diminish its reliance

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
on Russia for energy,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
but if you travel to North Africa today, you'll hear more and more people saying

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
that they don't really think of their region as the Middle East.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
So in other words, I believe that President Sarkozy of France

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
is right when he talks about a Mediterranean union.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
Now let's look at Turkey and the Caucasus.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
I mentioned Azerbaijan before.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
That corridor of Turkey and the Caucasus

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
has become the conduit for 20 percent

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
of Europe's energy supply.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
So does Turkey really have to be a member of the European Union?

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
I don't think it does. I think it's already part of

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
a Euro-Turkish superpower.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
So what's next? Where are we going to see borders change

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
and new countries born?

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
Well, South Central Asia, South West Asia

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
is a very good place to start.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
Eight years after the U.S. invaded Afghanistan

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
there is still a tremendous amount of instability.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
Pakistan and Afghanistan are still so fragile

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
that neither of them have dealt constructively

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
with the problem of Pashtun nationalism.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:37.958
This is the flag that flies in the minds

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.958
of 20 million Pashtuns

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
who live on both sides of the Afghan and Pakistan border.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
Let's not neglect the insurgency just to the south,

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
Balochistan. Two weeks ago,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
Balochi rebels attacked a Pakistani military garrison,

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:53.958
and this was the flag that they raised over it.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
The post-colonial entropy

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
that is happening around the world is accelerating,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:00.958
and I expect more such changes to occur in the map

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
as the states fragment.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
Of course, we can't forget Africa.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
53 countries, and by far the most number

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
of suspiciously straight lines on the map.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
If we were to look at all of Africa

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
we could most certainly acknowledge far more,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
tribal divisions and so forth.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:20.958
But let's just look at Sudan, the second-largest country in Africa.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
It has three ongoing civil wars,

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
the genocide in Darfur, which you all know about,

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:27.958
the civil war in the east of the country,

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
and south Sudan.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.958
South Sudan is going to be having a referendum in 2011

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
in which it is very likely to vote itself independence.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:39.958
Now let's go up to the Arctic Circle.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
There is a great race on for energy resources

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
under the Arctic seabed.

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
Who will win? Canada? Russia? The United States?

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
Actually Greenland.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
Several weeks ago Greenland's [60,000] people

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
voted themselves self-governance rights

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
from Denmark.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
So Denmark is about to get a whole lot smaller.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
What is the lesson from all of this?

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:03.958
Geopolitics is a very unsentimental discipline.

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
It's constantly morphing and changing the world,

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:07.958
like climate change.

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:09.958
And like our relationship with the ecosystem

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:11.958
we're always searching for equilibrium

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:14.958
in how we divide ourselves across the planet.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:16.958
Now we fear changes on the map.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
We fear civil wars, death tolls,

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
having to learn the names of new countries.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
But I believe that the inertia of the existing borders that we have today

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
is far worse and far more violent.

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
The question is how do we change those borders,

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
and what lines do we focus on?

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:32.958
I believe we focus on the lines that cross borders,

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:34.958
the infrastructure lines.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
Then we'll wind up with the world we want, a borderless one.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
Thank you.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:44.958
(Applause)

title: Designers -- think big!
transcript: I'd like to talk a little bit this morning about what happens if we move from design to design thinking. Now this rather old photo up there is actually the first project I was ever hired to do, something like 25 years ago. It's a woodworking machine, or at least a piece of one, and my task was to make this thing a little bit more modern, a little bit easier to use. I thought, at the time, I did a pretty good job. Unfortunately, not very long afterwards the company went out of business.This is the second project that I did. It's a fax machine. I put an attractive shell around some new technology. Again, 18 months later, the product was obsolete. And now, of course, the whole technology is obsolete. Now, I'm a fairly slow learner, but eventually it occurred to me that maybe what passed for design wasn't all that important — making things more attractive, making them a bit easier to use, making them more marketable. By focusing on a design, maybe just a single product, I was being incremental and not having much of an impact.But I think this small view of design is a relatively recent phenomenon, and in fact really emerged in the latter half of the 20th century as design became a tool of consumerism. So when we talk about design today, and particularly when we read about it in the popular press, we're often talking about products like these. Amusing? Yes. Desirable? Maybe. Important? Not so very.But this wasn't always the way. And I'd like to suggest that if we take a different view of design, and focus less on the object and more on design thinking as an approach, that we actually might see the result in a bigger impact. Now this gentleman, Isambard Kingdom Brunel, designed many great things in his career in the 19th century, including the Clifton suspension bridge in Bristol and the Thames tunnel at Rotherhithe. Both great designs and actually very innovative too. His greatest creation runs actually right through here in Oxford. It's called the Great Western Railway.And as a kid I grew up very close to here, and one of my favorite things to do was to cycle along by the side of the railway waiting for the great big express trains to roar past. You can see it represented here in J.M.W. Turner's painting, "Rain, Steam and Speed". Now, what Brunel said that he wanted to achieve for his passengers was the experience of floating across the countryside.Now, this was back in the 19th century. And to do that meant creating the flattest gradients that had ever yet been made, which meant building long viaducts across river valleys — this is actually the viaduct across the Thames at Maidenhead — and long tunnels such as the one at Box, in Wiltshire. But he didn't stop there. He didn't stop with just trying to design the best railway journey. He imagined an integrated transportation system in which it would be possible for a passenger to embark on a train in London and disembark from a ship in New York. One journey from London to New York. This is the S.S. Great Western that he built to take care of the second half of that journey.Now, Brunel was working 100 years before the emergence of the design profession, but I think he was using design thinking to solve problems and to create world-changing innovations. Now, design thinking begins with what Roger Martin, the business school professor at the University of Toronto, calls integrative thinking. And that's the ability to exploit opposing ideas and opposing constraints to create new solutions. In the case of design, that means balancing desirability, what humans need, with technical feasibility, and economic viability. With innovations like the Great Western, we can stretch that balance to the absolute limit.So somehow, we went from this to this. Systems thinkers who were reinventing the world, to a priesthood of folks in black turtlenecks and designer glasses working on small things. As our industrial society matured, so design became a profession and it focused on an ever smaller canvas until it came to stand for aesthetics, image and fashion. Now I'm not trying to throw stones here. I'm a fully paid-up member of that priesthood, and somewhere in here I have my designer glasses. There we go. But I do think that perhaps design is getting big again. And that's happening through the application of design thinking to new kinds of problems — to global warming, to education, healthcare, security, clean water, whatever.And as we see this reemergence of design thinking and we see it beginning to tackle new kinds of problems, there are some basic ideas that I think we can observe that are useful. And I'd like to talk about some of those just for the next few minutes. The first of those is that design is human-centered. It may integrate technology and economics, but it starts with what humans need, or might need. What makes life easier, more enjoyable? What makes technology useful and usable? But that is more than simply good ergonomics, putting the buttons in the right place. It's often about understanding culture and context before we even know where to start to have ideas.So when a team was working on a new vision screening program in India, they wanted to understand what the aspirations and motivations were of these school children to understand how they might play a role in screening their parents. Conversion Sound has developed a high quality, ultra-low-cost digital hearing aid for the developing world. Now, in the West we rely on highly trained technicians to fit these hearing aids. In places like India, those technicians simply don't exist. So it took a team working in India with patients and community health workers to understand how a PDA and an application on a PDA might replace those technicians in a fitting and diagnostic service.Instead of starting with technology, the team started with people and culture. So if human need is the place to start, then design thinking rapidly moves on to learning by making. Instead of thinking about what to build, building in order to think. Now, prototypes speed up the process of innovation, because it is only when we put our ideas out into the world that we really start to understand their strengths and weaknesses. And the faster we do that, the faster our ideas evolve.Now, much has been said and written about the Aravind Eye Institute in Madurai, India. They do an incredible job of serving very poor patients by taking the revenues from those who can afford to pay to cross-subsidize those who cannot. Now, they are very efficient, but they are also very innovative. When I visited them a few years ago, what really impressed me was their willingness to prototype their ideas very early.This is the manufacturing facility for one of their biggest cost breakthroughs. They make their own intraocular lenses. These are the lenses that replace those that are damaged by cataracts. And I think it's partly their prototyping mentality that really allowed them to achieve the breakthrough. Because they brought the cost down from $200 a pair, down to just $4 a pair. Partly they did this by instead of building a fancy new factory, they used the basement of one of their hospitals. And instead of installing the large-scale machines used by western producers, they used low-cost CAD/CAM prototyping technology. They are now the biggest manufacturer of these lenses in the developing world and have recently moved into a custom factory.So if human need is the place to start, and prototyping, a vehicle for progress, then there are also some questions to ask about the destination. Instead of seeing its primary objective as consumption, design thinking is beginning to explore the potential of participation — the shift from a passive relationship between consumer and producer to the active engagement of everyone in experiences that are meaningful, productive and profitable.So I'd like to take the idea that Rory Sutherland talked about, this notion that intangible things are worth perhaps more than physical things, and take that a little bit further and say that I think the design of participatory systems, in which many more forms of value beyond simply cash are both created and measured, is going to be the major theme, not only for design, but also for our economy as we go forward.So William Beveridge, when he wrote the first of his famous reports in 1942, created what became Britain's welfare state in which he hoped that every citizen would be an active participant in their own social well-being. By the time he wrote his third report, he confessed that he had failed and instead had created a society of welfare consumers.Hilary Cottam, Charlie Leadbeater, and Hugo Manassei of Participle have taken this idea of participation, and in their manifesto entitled Beveridge 4.0, they are suggesting a framework for reinventing the welfare state. So in one of their projects called Southwark Circle, they worked with residents in Southwark, South London and a small team of designers to develop a new membership organization to help the elderly with household tasks. Designs were refined and developed with 150 older people and their families before the service was launched earlier this year.We can take this idea of participation perhaps to its logical conclusion and say that design may have its greatest impact when it's taken out of the hands of designers and put into the hands of everyone. Nurses and practitioners at U.S. healthcare system Kaiser Permanente study the topic of improving the patient experience, and particularly focused on the way that they exchange knowledge and change shift. Through a program of observational research, brainstorming new solutions and rapid prototyping, they've developed a completely new way to change shift.They went from retreating to the nurse's station to discuss the various states and needs of patients, to developing a system that happened on the ward in front of patients, using a simple software tool. By doing this they brought the time that they were away from patients down from 40 minutes to 12 minutes, on average. They increased patient confidence and nurse happiness. When you multiply that by all the nurses in all the wards in 40 hospitals in the system, it resulted, actually, in a pretty big impact.And this is just one of thousands of opportunities in healthcare alone. So these are just some of the kind of basic ideas around design thinking and some of the new kinds of projects that they're being applied to. But I'd like to go back to Brunel here, and suggest a connection that might explain why this is happening now, and maybe why design thinking is a useful tool. And that connection is change. In times of change we need new alternatives, new ideas.Now, Brunel worked at the height of the Industrial Revolution, when all of life and our economy was being reinvented. Now the industrial systems of Brunel's time have run their course, and indeed they are part of the problem today. But, again, we are in the midst of massive change. And that change is forcing us to question quite fundamental aspects of our society — how we keep ourselves healthy, how we govern ourselves, how we educate ourselves, how we keep ourselves secure. And in these times of change, we need these new choices because our existing solutions are simply becoming obsolete.So why design thinking? Because it gives us a new way of tackling problems. Instead of defaulting to our normal convergent approach where we make the best choice out of available alternatives, it encourages us to take a divergent approach, to explore new alternatives, new solutions, new ideas that have not existed before. But before we go through that process of divergence, there is actually quite an important first step. And that is, what is the question that we're trying to answer? What's the design brief? Now Brunel may have asked a question like this, "How do I take a train from London to New York?" But what are the kinds of questions that we might ask today?So these are some that we've been asked to think about recently. And one in particular, is one that we're working on with the Acumen Fund, in a project that's been funded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. How might we improve access to safe drinking water for the world's poorest people, and at the same time stimulate innovation amongst local water providers?So instead of having a bunch of American designers come up with new ideas that may or may not have been appropriate, we took a sort of more open, collaborative and participative approach. We teamed designers and investment experts up with 11 water organizations across India. And through workshops they developed innovative new products, services, and business models.We hosted a competition and then funded five of those organizations to develop their ideas. So they developed and iterated these ideas. And then IDEO and Acumen spent several weeks working with them to help design new social marketing campaigns, community outreach strategies, business models, new water vessels for storing water and carts for delivering water. Some of those ideas are just getting launched into the market. And the same process is just getting underway with NGOs in East Africa.So for me, this project shows kind of how far we can go from some of those sort of small things that I was working on at the beginning of my career. That by focusing on the needs of humans and by using prototypes to move ideas along quickly, by getting the process out of the hands of designers, and by getting the active participation of the community, we can tackle bigger and more interesting questions. And just like Brunel, by focusing on systems, we can have a bigger impact. So that's one thing that we've been working on.I'm actually really quite interested, and perhaps more interested to know what this community thinks we could work on. What kinds of questions do we think design thinking could be used to tackle? And if you've got any ideas then feel free, you can post them to Twitter. There is a hash tag there that you can use, #CBDQ. And the list looked something like this a little while ago. And of course you can search to find the questions that you're interested in by using the same hash code.So I'd like to believe that design thinking actually can make a difference, that it can help create new ideas and new innovations, beyond the latest High Street products. To do that I think we have to take a more expansive view of design, more like Brunel, less a domain of a professional priesthood. And the first step is to start asking the right questions. Thank you very much. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
I'd like to talk a little bit this morning

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:16.958
about what happens if we move from design

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
to design thinking.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:21.958
Now this rather old photo up there

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.958
is actually the first project I was ever hired to do,

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
something like 25 years ago.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:28.958
It's a woodworking machine, or at least a piece of one,

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
and my task was to

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
make this thing a little bit more modern,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
a little bit easier to use.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
I thought, at the time, I did a pretty good job.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
Unfortunately, not very long afterwards

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:42.958
the company went out of business.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
This is the second project that I did. It's a fax machine.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
I put an attractive shell around some new technology.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
Again, 18 months later,

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
the product was obsolete.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:57.958
And now, of course, the whole technology is obsolete.

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
Now, I'm a fairly slow learner,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
but eventually it occurred to me that

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
maybe what passed for design

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
wasn't all that important --

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
making things more attractive,

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
making them a bit easier to use,

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
making them more marketable.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
By focusing on a design,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
maybe just a single product,

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
I was being incremental

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:22.958
and not having much of an impact.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
But I think this small view of design

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
is a relatively recent phenomenon,

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
and in fact really emerged

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
in the latter half of the 20th century

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:34.958
as design became a tool of consumerism.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
So when we talk about design today,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
and particularly when we read about it in the popular press,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
we're often talking about products like these.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
Amusing? Yes. Desirable? Maybe.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.958
Important? Not so very.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
But this wasn't always the way.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
And I'd like to suggest that if we take

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:53.958
a different view of design,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
and focus less on the object

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
and more on design thinking as an approach,

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:04.958
that we actually might see the result in a bigger impact.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
Now this gentleman, Isambard Kingdom Brunel,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:10.958
designed many great things in his career in the 19th century,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:14.958
including the Clifton suspension bridge in Bristol

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
and the Thames tunnel at Rotherhithe.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:21.958
Both great designs and actually very innovative too.

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.958
His greatest creation

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
runs actually right through here in Oxford.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:29.958
It's called the Great Western Railway.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
And as a kid I grew up very close to here,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
and one of my favorite things to do

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
was to cycle along by the side of the railway

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
waiting for the great big express trains to roar past.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
You can see it represented here in J.M.W. Turner's painting,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
"Rain, Steam and Speed".

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Now, what Brunel said that he wanted to achieve for his passengers

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:54.958
was the experience of floating across the countryside.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
Now, this was back in the 19th century.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
And to do that meant creating the flattest gradients

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
that had ever yet been made,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
which meant building long viaducts across river valleys --

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:07.958
this is actually the viaduct across the Thames at Maidenhead --

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:13.958
and long tunnels such as the one at Box, in Wiltshire.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
But he didn't stop there. He didn't stop

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
with just trying to design the best railway journey.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:22.958
He imagined an integrated transportation system

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
in which it would be possible for a passenger to embark

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
on a train in London

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
and disembark from a ship in New York.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:35.958
One journey from London to New York.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
This is the S.S. Great Western that he built

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:41.958
to take care of the second half of that journey.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
Now, Brunel was working 100 years before

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
the emergence of the design profession,

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
but I think he was using design thinking

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:54.958
to solve problems and to create world-changing innovations.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
Now, design thinking begins with what Roger Martin,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
the business school professor at the University of Toronto,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
calls integrative thinking.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And that's the ability to exploit opposing ideas

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
and opposing constraints

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
to create new solutions.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
In the case of design, that means

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:15.958
balancing desirability, what humans need,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
with technical feasibility,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
and economic viability.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
With innovations like the Great Western,

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:26.958
we can stretch that balance to the absolute limit.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:33.958
So somehow, we went from this to this.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
Systems thinkers who were reinventing the world,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:41.958
to a priesthood of folks in black turtlenecks and designer glasses

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
working on small things.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:47.958
As our industrial society matured,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
so design became a profession

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
and it focused on an ever smaller canvas

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
until it came to stand for aesthetics,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
image and fashion.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
Now I'm not trying to throw stones here.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
I'm a fully paid-up member of that priesthood,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
and somewhere in here I have my designer glasses.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
There we go.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
But I do think that perhaps design

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
is getting big again.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
And that's happening through

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
the application of design thinking

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
to new kinds of problems --

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
to global warming, to education,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:23.958
healthcare, security, clean water, whatever.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
And as we see this reemergence of design thinking

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
and we see it beginning to tackle new kinds of problems,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
there are some basic ideas that I think we can observe that are useful.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
And I'd like to talk about some of those

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
just for the next few minutes.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
The first of those is that design is

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
human-centered.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
It may integrate technology and economics,

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:47.958
but it starts with what humans need, or might need.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
What makes life easier, more enjoyable?

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:53.958
What makes technology useful and usable?

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
But that is more than simply good ergonomics,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
putting the buttons in the right place.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
It's often about understanding culture and context

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
before we even know where to start to have ideas.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:09.958
So when a team was working on a new vision screening program in India,

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
they wanted to understand what the aspirations

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
and motivations were of these school children

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
to understand how they might play a role

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:21.958
in screening their parents.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
Conversion Sound has developed a high quality,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
ultra-low-cost digital hearing aid

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
for the developing world.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Now, in the West we rely on highly trained technicians

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
to fit these hearing aids.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:38.958
In places like India, those technicians simply don't exist.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
So it took a team working in India

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
with patients and community health workers

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
to understand how a PDA

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
and an application on a PDA

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
might replace those technicians

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
in a fitting and diagnostic service.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
Instead of starting with technology,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
the team started with people and culture.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
So if human need is the place to start,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
then design thinking rapidly moves on to

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
learning by making.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
Instead of thinking about what to build,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
building in order to think.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
Now, prototypes speed up the process of innovation,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
because it is only when we put our ideas out into the world

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
that we really start to understand their strengths and weaknesses.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
And the faster we do that,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
the faster our ideas evolve.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Now, much has been said and written about

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
the Aravind Eye Institute in Madurai, India.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:32.958
They do an incredible job of serving very poor patients

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
by taking the revenues from those who can afford to pay

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:38.958
to cross-subsidize those who cannot.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
Now, they are very efficient,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
but they are also very innovative.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
When I visited them a few years ago,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
what really impressed me was their willingness

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
to prototype their ideas very early.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
This is the manufacturing facility

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
for one of their biggest cost breakthroughs.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
They make their own intraocular lenses.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
These are the lenses that replace those

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
that are damaged by cataracts.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:06.958
And I think it's partly their prototyping mentality

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
that really allowed them to achieve the breakthrough.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
Because they brought the cost down

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:11.958
from $200 a pair,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:16.958
down to just $4 a pair.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
Partly they did this by instead of building

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
a fancy new factory,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.958
they used the basement of one of their hospitals.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
And instead of installing the large-scale machines

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
used by western producers,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:33.958
they used low-cost CAD/CAM prototyping technology.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
They are now the biggest manufacturer of these lenses in the developing world

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:41.958
and have recently moved into a custom factory.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
So if human need is the place to start,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
and prototyping, a vehicle for progress,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:49.958
then there are also some questions to ask about the destination.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:54.958
Instead of seeing its primary objective as consumption,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
design thinking is beginning to explore the potential of participation --

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
the shift from a passive relationship

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
between consumer and producer

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
to the active engagement of everyone

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
in experiences that are meaningful,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:10.958
productive and profitable.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
So I'd like to take the idea that Rory Sutherland talked about,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
this notion that intangible things are worth perhaps more than physical things,

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
and take that a little bit further and say that

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
I think the design of participatory systems,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
in which many more forms of value

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
beyond simply cash

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
are both created and measured,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
is going to be the major theme, not only for design,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:36.958
but also for our economy as we go forward.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:40.958
So William Beveridge, when he wrote the first of his famous reports in 1942,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:44.958
created what became Britain's welfare state

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
in which he hoped that every citizen

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
would be an active participant

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
in their own social well-being.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
By the time he wrote his third report,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
he confessed that he had failed

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:02.958
and instead had created a society of welfare consumers.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
Hilary Cottam, Charlie Leadbeater,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
and Hugo Manassei of Participle

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
have taken this idea of participation,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
and in their manifesto entitled Beveridge 4.0,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
they are suggesting a framework

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
for reinventing the welfare state.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
So in one of their projects called Southwark Circle,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
they worked with residents in Southwark, South London

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and a small team of designers

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:28.958
to develop a new membership organization

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
to help the elderly with household tasks.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
Designs were refined and developed

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
with 150 older people and their families

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:41.958
before the service was launched earlier this year.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:45.958
We can take this idea of participation

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
perhaps to its logical conclusion

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
and say that design may have its greatest impact

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
when it's taken out of the hands of designers

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
and put into the hands of everyone.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
Nurses and practitioners at U.S. healthcare system

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
Kaiser Permanente

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:05.958
study the topic of improving the patient experience,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:10.958
and particularly focused on the way that they exchange knowledge

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
and change shift.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
Through a program of observational research,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
brainstorming new solutions and rapid prototyping,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
they've developed a completely new way to change shift.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:25.958
They went from retreating to the nurse's station

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
to discuss the various states and needs of patients,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
to developing a system that happened on the ward

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
in front of patients, using a simple software tool.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
By doing this they brought the time that they were away from patients

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
down from 40 minutes to 12 minutes, on average.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
They increased patient confidence and nurse happiness.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
When you multiply that by all the nurses

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
in all the wards in 40 hospitals in the system,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
it resulted, actually, in a pretty big impact.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
And this is just one of thousands

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:58.958
of opportunities in healthcare alone.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
So these are just some of the kind of basic ideas

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
around design thinking

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
and some of the new kinds of projects

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
that they're being applied to.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
But I'd like to go back to Brunel here,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:14.958
and suggest a connection that might explain why this is happening now,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:19.958
and maybe why design thinking is a useful tool.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And that connection is change.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
In times of change we need

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:28.958
new alternatives, new ideas.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
Now, Brunel worked at the height of the Industrial Revolution,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
when all of life and our economy

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
was being reinvented.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:38.958
Now the industrial systems of Brunel's time have run their course,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
and indeed they are part of the problem today.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:44.958
But, again, we are in the midst of massive change.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
And that change is forcing us to question

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
quite fundamental aspects of our society --

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
how we keep ourselves healthy, how we govern ourselves,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
how we educate ourselves, how we keep ourselves secure.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And in these times of change, we need these new choices

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:04.958
because our existing solutions are simply becoming obsolete.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
So why design thinking?

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
Because it gives us a new way of tackling problems.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:14.958
Instead of defaulting to our normal convergent approach

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:18.958
where we make the best choice out of available alternatives,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
it encourages us to take a divergent approach,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
to explore new alternatives, new solutions,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:27.958
new ideas that have not existed before.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
But before we go through that process of divergence,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
there is actually quite an important first step.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
And that is, what is the question that we're trying to answer?

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
What's the design brief?

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
Now Brunel may have asked a question like this,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:43.958
"How do I take a train from London to New York?"

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.958
But what are the kinds of questions that we might ask today?

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:53.958
So these are some that we've been asked to think about recently.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
And one in particular, is one that we're working on with the Acumen Fund,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.958
in a project that's been funded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
How might we improve access to safe drinking water

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
for the world's poorest people,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
and at the same time stimulate innovation

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:11.958
amongst local water providers?

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
So instead of having a bunch of American designers

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
come up with new ideas that may or may not have been appropriate,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.958
we took a sort of more open, collaborative and participative approach.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
We teamed designers and investment experts up with

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
11 water organizations across India.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
And through workshops they developed

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
innovative new products, services, and business models.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
We hosted a competition

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
and then funded five of those organizations

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
to develop their ideas.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
So they developed and iterated these ideas.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
And then IDEO and Acumen spent several weeks working with them

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:47.958
to help design new social marketing campaigns,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
community outreach strategies, business models,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
new water vessels for storing water

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
and carts for delivering water.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
Some of those ideas are just getting launched into the market.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
And the same process is just getting underway

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
with NGOs in East Africa.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
So for me, this project shows

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
kind of how far we can go from

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
some of those sort of small things

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
that I was working on

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
at the beginning of my career.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
That by focusing on the needs of humans

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
and by using prototypes

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
to move ideas along quickly,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
by getting the process out of the hands of designers,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
and by getting the active participation of the community,

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
we can tackle bigger and more interesting questions.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:33.958
And just like Brunel, by focusing on systems,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
we can have a bigger impact.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
So that's one thing that we've been working on.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
I'm actually really quite interested, and perhaps more interested

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:46.958
to know what this community thinks we could work on.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
What kinds of questions do we think

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
design thinking could be used to tackle?

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
And if you've got any ideas

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
then feel free, you can post them to Twitter.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
There is a hash tag there that you can use, #CBDQ.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
And the list looked something like this a little while ago.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:06.958
And of course you can search to find the questions that you're interested in

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
by using the same hash code.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:12.958
So I'd like to believe that design thinking

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
actually can make a difference,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
that it can help create new ideas

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
and new innovations,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
beyond the latest High Street products.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:24.958
To do that I think we have to take a more expansive view of design,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:30.958
more like Brunel, less a domain of a professional priesthood.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
And the first step is to start asking the right questions.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
Thank you very much.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:40.958
(Applause)

title: Let's revive the Golden Rule
transcript: For years I've been feeling frustrated, because as a religious historian, I've become acutely aware of the centrality of compassion in all the major world faiths. Every single one of them has evolved their own version of what's been called the Golden Rule. Sometimes it comes in a positive version — "Always treat all others as you'd like to be treated yourself." And equally important is the negative version — "Don't do to others what you would not like them to do to you." Look into your own heart, discover what it is that gives you pain and then refuse, under any circumstance whatsoever, to inflict that pain on anybody else.And people have emphasized the importance of compassion, not just because it sounds good, but because it works. People have found that when they have implemented the Golden Rule as Confucius said, "all day and every day," not just a question of doing your good deed for the day and then returning to a life of greed and egotism, but to do it all day and every day, you dethrone yourself from the center of your world, put another there, and you transcend yourself. And it brings you into the presence of what's been called God, Nirvana, Rama, Tao. Something that goes beyond what we know in our ego-bound existence.But you know you'd never know it a lot of the time, that this was so central to the religious life. Because with a few wonderful exceptions, very often when religious people come together, religious leaders come together, they're arguing about abstruse doctrines or uttering a council of hatred or inveighing against homosexuality or something of that sort. Often people don't really want to be compassionate. I sometimes see when I'm speaking to a congregation of religious people a sort of mutinous expression crossing their faces because people often want to be right instead. And that of course defeats the object of the exercise.Now why was I so grateful to TED? Because they took me very gently from my book-lined study and brought me into the 21st century, enabling me to speak to a much, much wider audience than I could have ever conceived. Because I feel an urgency about this. If we don't manage to implement the Golden Rule globally, so that we treat all peoples, wherever and whoever they may be, as though they were as important as ourselves, I doubt that we'll have a viable world to hand on to the next generation.The task of our time, one of the great tasks of our time, is to build a global society, as I said, where people can live together in peace. And the religions that should be making a major contribution are instead seen as part of the problem. And of course it's not just religious people who believe in the Golden Rule. This is the source of all morality, this imaginative act of empathy, putting yourself in the place of another.And so we have a choice, it seems to me. We can either go on bringing out or emphasizing the dogmatic and intolerant aspects of our faith, or we can go back to the rabbis. Rabbi Hillel, the older contemporary of Jesus, who, when asked by a pagan to sum up the whole of Jewish teaching while he stood on one leg, said, "That which is hateful to you, do not do to your neighbor. That is the Torah and everything else is only commentary."And the rabbis and the early fathers of the church who said that any interpretation of scripture that bred hatred and disdain was illegitimate. And we need to revive that spirit. And it's not just going to happen because a spirit of love wafts us down. We have to make this happen, and we can do it with the modern communications that TED has introduced. Already I've been tremendously heartened at the response of all our partners.In Singapore, we have a group going to use the Charter to heal divisions recently that have sprung up in Singaporean society, and some members of the parliament want to implement it politically. In Malaysia, there is going to be an art exhibition in which leading artists are going to be taking people, young people, and showing them that compassion also lies at the root of all art. Throughout Europe, the Muslim communities are holding events and discussions, are discussing the centrality of compassion in Islam and in all faiths.But it can't stop there. It can't stop with the launch. Religious teaching, this is where we've gone so wrong, concentrating solely on believing abstruse doctrines. Religious teaching must always lead to action. And I intend to work on this till my dying day. And I want to continue with our partners to do two things — educate and stimulate compassionate thinking. Education because we've so dropped out of compassion. People often think it simply means feeling sorry for somebody. But of course you don't understand compassion if you're just going to think about it. You also have to do it.I want them to get the media involved because the media are crucial in helping to dissolve some of the stereotypical views we have of other people, which are dividing us from one another. The same applies to educators. I'd like youth to get a sense of the dynamism, the dynamic and challenge of a compassionate lifestyle. And also see that it demands acute intelligence, not just a gooey feeling.I'd like to call upon scholars to explore the compassionate theme in their own and in other people's traditions. And perhaps above all, to encourage a sensitivity about uncompassionate speaking, so that because people have this Charter, whatever their beliefs or lack of them, they feel empowered to challenge uncompassionate speech, disdainful remarks from their religious leaders, their political leaders, from the captains of industry. Because we can change the world, we have the ability.I would never have thought of putting the Charter online. I was still stuck in the old world of a whole bunch of boffins sitting together in a room and issuing yet another arcane statement. And TED introduced me to a whole new way of thinking and presenting ideas. Because that is what is so wonderful about TED. In this room, all this expertise, if we joined it all together, we could change the world. And of course the problems sometimes seem insuperable.But I'd just like to quote, finish at the end with a reference to a British author, an Oxford author whom I don't quote very often, C.S. Lewis. But he wrote one thing that stuck in my mind ever since I read it when I was a schoolgirl. It's in his book "The Four Loves." He said that he distinguished between erotic love, when two people gaze, spellbound, into each other's eyes. And then he compared that to friendship, when two people stand side by side, as it were, shoulder to shoulder, with their eyes fixed on a common goal.We don't have to fall in love with each other, but we can become friends. And I am convinced. I felt it very strongly during our little deliberations at Vevey, that when people of all different persuasions come together, working side by side for a common goal, differences melt away. And we learn amity. And we learn to live together and to get to know one another. Thank you very much. (Applause)
