00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.006
stories in pencil
with crayon illustrations

00:00:48.030 --> 00:00:51.562
that my poor mother was obligated to read,

00:00:51.586 --> 00:00:55.154
I wrote exactly the kinds
of stories I was reading:

00:00:55.178 --> 00:00:59.934
All my characters were
white and blue-eyed,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.265
they played in the snow,

00:01:02.289 --> 00:01:04.376
they ate apples,

00:01:04.400 --> 00:01:05.797
(Laughter)

00:01:05.971 --> 00:01:07.982
and they talked a lot about the weather,

00:01:08.006 --> 00:01:10.134
how lovely it was
that the sun had come out.

00:01:10.367 --> 00:01:12.331
(Laughter)

00:01:12.355 --> 00:01:15.489
Now, this despite the fact
that I lived in Nigeria.

00:01:15.513 --> 00:01:17.291
I had never been outside Nigeria.

00:01:19.101 --> 00:01:22.362
We didn't have snow, we ate mangoes,

00:01:22.386 --> 00:01:24.234
and we never talked about the weather,

00:01:24.258 --> 00:01:25.934
because there was no need to.

00:01:26.227 --> 00:01:28.934
My characters also drank
a lot of ginger beer,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.339
because the characters
in the British books I read

00:01:31.363 --> 00:01:32.934
drank ginger beer.

00:01:33.259 --> 00:01:35.934
Never mind that I had no idea
what ginger beer was.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.489
(Laughter)

00:01:37.513 --> 00:01:38.963
And for many years afterwards,

00:01:38.987 --> 00:01:41.934
I would have a desperate desire
to taste ginger beer.

00:01:42.434 --> 00:01:43.934
But that is another story.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.441
What this demonstrates, I think,

00:01:46.465 --> 00:01:49.319
is how impressionable
and vulnerable we are

00:01:49.343 --> 00:01:50.934
in the face of a story,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.343
particularly as children.

00:01:53.597 --> 00:01:57.367
Because all I had read were books
in which characters were foreign,

00:01:57.391 --> 00:01:59.510
I had become convinced that books

00:01:59.534 --> 00:02:02.704
by their very nature
had to have foreigners in them

00:02:02.728 --> 00:02:06.447
and had to be about things with which
I could not personally identify.

00:02:07.558 --> 00:02:10.177
Now, things changed
when I discovered African books.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.934
There weren't many of them available,

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.827
and they weren't quite as easy to find
as the foreign books.

00:02:15.851 --> 00:02:18.934
But because of writers like
Chinua Achebe and Camara Laye,

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:22.934
I went through a mental shift
in my perception of literature.

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.172
I realized that people like me,

00:02:25.196 --> 00:02:27.203
girls with skin the color of chocolate,

00:02:27.227 --> 00:02:30.489
whose kinky hair could not form ponytails,

00:02:30.513 --> 00:02:32.323
could also exist in literature.

00:02:32.640 --> 00:02:35.934
I started to write
about things I recognized.

00:02:36.695 --> 00:02:39.934
Now, I loved those
American and British books I read.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.934
They stirred my imagination.
They opened up new worlds for me.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.934
But the unintended consequence

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.006
was that I did not know
that people like me

00:02:48.030 --> 00:02:49.456
could exist in literature.

00:02:50.409 --> 00:02:53.934
So what the discovery of African writers
did for me was this:

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:57.835
It saved me from having a single story
of what books are.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.934
I come from a conventional,
middle-class Nigerian family.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.934
My father was a professor.

00:03:04.343 --> 00:03:06.026
My mother was an administrator.

00:03:07.327 --> 00:03:10.129
And so we had, as was the norm,

00:03:10.153 --> 00:03:14.502
live-in domestic help, who would often
come from nearby rural villages.

00:03:15.140 --> 00:03:18.426
So, the year I turned eight,
we got a new house boy.

00:03:19.060 --> 00:03:20.314
His name was Fide.

00:03:21.616 --> 00:03:25.917
The only thing my mother told us about him
was that his family was very poor.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:31.934
My mother sent yams and rice,
and our old clothes, to his family.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.578
And when I didn't finish my dinner,
my mother would say,

00:03:34.602 --> 00:03:38.934
"Finish your food! Don't you know?
People like Fide's family have nothing."

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:42.934
So I felt enormous pity for Fide's family.

00:03:43.534 --> 00:03:46.431
Then one Saturday,
we went to his village to visit,

00:03:46.455 --> 00:03:49.934
and his mother showed us
a beautifully patterned basket

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.934
made of dyed raffia
that his brother had made.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.934
I was startled.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.934
It had not occurred to me
that anybody in his family

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.934
could actually make something.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.934
All I had heard about them
was how poor they were,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:08.425
so that it had become impossible for me
to see them as anything else but poor.

00:04:09.101 --> 00:04:11.472
Their poverty was my single story of them.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.482
Years later, I thought about this
when I left Nigeria

00:04:15.506 --> 00:04:18.188
to go to university in the United States.

00:04:18.299 --> 00:04:19.632
I was 19.

00:04:20.379 --> 00:04:23.156
My American roommate was shocked by me.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:27.544
She asked where I had learned
to speak English so well,

00:04:27.568 --> 00:04:29.656
and was confused when I said that Nigeria

00:04:29.680 --> 00:04:32.394
happened to have English
as its official language.

00:04:33.711 --> 00:04:37.934
She asked if she could listen
to what she called my "tribal music,"

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.934
and was consequently very disappointed

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.934
when I produced my tape of Mariah Carey.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.934
(Laughter)

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:48.651
She assumed that I did not know
how to use a stove.

00:04:49.740 --> 00:04:50.996
What struck me was this:

00:04:51.020 --> 00:04:54.095
She had felt sorry for me
even before she saw me.

00:04:54.486 --> 00:04:57.934
Her default position
toward me, as an African,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.994
was a kind of patronizing,
well-meaning pity.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:05.454
My roommate had a single story of Africa:

00:05:05.581 --> 00:05:07.935
a single story of catastrophe.

00:05:08.370 --> 00:05:09.656
In this single story,

00:05:09.680 --> 00:05:13.934
there was no possibility of Africans
being similar to her in any way,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.934
no possibility of feelings
more complex than pity,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:20.934
no possibility of a connection
as human equals.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.081
I must say that before I went to the U.S.,

00:05:23.105 --> 00:05:25.386
I didn't consciously identify as African.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.934
But in the U.S., whenever Africa came up,
people turned to me.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.704
Never mind that I knew nothing
about places like Namibia.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.054
But I did come to embrace
this new identity,

00:05:35.078 --> 00:05:37.934
and in many ways I think
of myself now as African.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.934
Although I still get quite irritable
when Africa is referred to as a country,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:45.934
the most recent example being
my otherwise wonderful flight

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.243
from Lagos two days ago,

00:05:47.267 --> 00:05:50.149
in which there was an announcement
on the Virgin flight

00:05:50.173 --> 00:05:54.934
about the charity work in "India,
Africa and other countries."

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.275
(Laughter)

00:05:56.434 --> 00:05:59.934
So, after I had spent some years
in the U.S. as an African,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:03.132
I began to understand
my roommate's response to me.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.983
If I had not grown up in Nigeria,

00:06:06.007 --> 00:06:09.148
and if all I knew about Africa
were from popular images,

00:06:09.172 --> 00:06:14.344
I too would think that Africa
was a place of beautiful landscapes,

00:06:14.368 --> 00:06:15.934
beautiful animals,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.934
and incomprehensible people,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.589
fighting senseless wars,
dying of poverty and AIDS,

00:06:21.613 --> 00:06:23.934
unable to speak for themselves

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:28.113
and waiting to be saved
by a kind, white foreigner.

00:06:28.886 --> 00:06:31.055
I would see Africans
in the same way that I,

00:06:31.079 --> 00:06:33.782
as a child, had seen Fide's family.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:38.934
This single story of Africa ultimately
comes, I think, from Western literature.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:43.934
Now, here is a quote from the writing
of a London merchant called John Lok,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.934
who sailed to west Africa in 1561

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:50.621
and kept a fascinating
account of his voyage.

00:06:52.161 --> 00:06:55.934
After referring to the black Africans
as "beasts who have no houses,"

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:59.934
he writes, "They are also
people without heads,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:03.926
having their mouth and eyes
in their breasts."

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.054
Now, I've laughed
every time I've read this.

00:07:07.078 --> 00:07:10.458
And one must admire
the imagination of John Lok.

00:07:11.331 --> 00:07:13.197
But what is important about his writing

00:07:13.221 --> 00:07:14.934
is that it represents the beginning

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.934
of a tradition of telling
African stories in the West:

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:21.325
A tradition of Sub-Saharan Africa
as a place of negatives,

00:07:21.437 --> 00:07:23.592
of difference, of darkness,

00:07:23.616 --> 00:07:28.934
of people who, in the words
of the wonderful poet Rudyard Kipling,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.899
are "half devil, half child."

00:07:32.169 --> 00:07:34.934
And so, I began to realize
that my American roommate

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.934
must have throughout her life

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:40.934
seen and heard different versions
of this single story,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.934
as had a professor,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.724
who once told me that my novel
was not "authentically African."

00:07:47.827 --> 00:07:49.518
Now, I was quite willing to contend

00:07:49.542 --> 00:07:52.637
that there were a number of things
wrong with the novel,

00:07:52.661 --> 00:07:55.934
that it had failed in a number of places,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.197
but I had not quite imagined
that it had failed

00:07:58.221 --> 00:08:00.934
at achieving something
called African authenticity.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:04.664
In fact, I did not know
what African authenticity was.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:10.354
The professor told me that my characters
were too much like him,

00:08:10.378 --> 00:08:12.354
an educated and middle-class man.

00:08:12.378 --> 00:08:14.480
My characters drove cars.

00:08:14.504 --> 00:08:16.934
They were not starving.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.885
Therefore they were not
authentically African.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.934
But I must quickly add
that I too am just as guilty

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.028
in the question of the single story.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.949
A few years ago,
I visited Mexico from the U.S.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.625
The political climate in the U.S.
at the time was tense,

00:08:33.649 --> 00:08:36.934
and there were debates going on
about immigration.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.934
And, as often happens in America,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.934
immigration became
synonymous with Mexicans.

00:08:42.656 --> 00:08:44.589
There were endless stories of Mexicans

00:08:44.613 --> 00:08:47.934
as people who were
fleecing the healthcare system,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.934
sneaking across the border,

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.423
being arrested at the border,
that sort of thing.

00:08:54.121 --> 00:08:57.934
I remember walking around
on my first day in Guadalajara,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.934
watching the people going to work,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.934
rolling up tortillas in the marketplace,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.931
smoking, laughing.

00:09:05.153 --> 00:09:07.934
I remember first feeling slight surprise.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.934
And then, I was overwhelmed with shame.

00:09:11.299 --> 00:09:15.934
I realized that I had been so immersed
in the media coverage of Mexicans

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
that they had become one thing in my mind,

00:09:17.982 --> 00:09:19.807
the abject immigrant.

00:09:20.727 --> 00:09:23.149
I had bought into
the single story of Mexicans

00:09:23.173 --> 00:09:25.680
and I could not have
been more ashamed of myself.

00:09:26.029 --> 00:09:28.576
So that is how to create a single story,

00:09:28.600 --> 00:09:30.934
show a people as one thing,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.934
as only one thing,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.934
over and over again,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.473
and that is what they become.

00:09:37.751 --> 00:09:40.197
It is impossible to talk
about the single story

00:09:40.221 --> 00:09:41.910
without talking about power.

00:09:43.454 --> 00:09:45.202
There is a word, an Igbo word,

00:09:45.226 --> 00:09:48.877
that I think about whenever I think about
the power structures of the world,

00:09:48.901 --> 00:09:50.091
and it is "nkali."

00:09:50.290 --> 00:09:54.934
It's a noun that loosely translates
to "to be greater than another."

00:09:55.512 --> 00:09:58.440
Like our economic and political worlds,

00:09:58.464 --> 00:10:02.934
stories too are defined
by the principle of nkali:

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.934
How they are told, who tells them,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:08.195
when they're told,
how many stories are told,

00:10:08.219 --> 00:10:10.426
are really dependent on power.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:15.101
Power is the ability not just to tell
the story of another person,

00:10:15.125 --> 00:10:18.934
but to make it the definitive
story of that person.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.054
The Palestinian poet
Mourid Barghouti writes

00:10:21.078 --> 00:10:23.934
that if you want to dispossess a people,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.934
the simplest way to do it
is to tell their story

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.188
and to start with, "secondly."

00:10:30.442 --> 00:10:34.340
Start the story with the arrows
of the Native Americans,

00:10:34.364 --> 00:10:36.934
and not with the arrival of the British,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.935
and you have an entirely different story.

00:10:39.959 --> 00:10:44.391
Start the story with
the failure of the African state,

00:10:44.415 --> 00:10:47.934
and not with the colonial
creation of the African state,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.700
and you have an entirely different story.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.934
I recently spoke at a university

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:57.743
where a student told me
that it was such a shame

00:10:57.767 --> 00:11:00.886
that Nigerian men were physical abusers

00:11:00.910 --> 00:11:02.854
like the father character in my novel.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:07.934
I told him that I had just read a novel
called "American Psycho" --

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.934
(Laughter)

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.934
-- and that it was such a shame

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.934
that young Americans
were serial murderers.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.934
(Laughter)

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:24.934
(Applause)

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.934
Now, obviously I said this
in a fit of mild irritation.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.934
(Laughter)

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.149
But it would never have
occurred to me to think

00:11:32.173 --> 00:11:35.934
that just because I had read a novel
in which a character was a serial killer

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.934
that he was somehow
representative of all Americans.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.934
This is not because I am
a better person than that student,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.934
but because of America's cultural
and economic power,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.934
I had many stories of America.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.934
I had read Tyler and Updike
and Steinbeck and Gaitskill.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.518
I did not have a single story of America.

00:11:55.629 --> 00:11:57.335
When I learned, some years ago,

00:11:57.359 --> 00:12:01.700
that writers were expected
to have had really unhappy childhoods

00:12:01.724 --> 00:12:03.934
to be successful,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
I began to think about how I could invent
horrible things my parents had done to me.

00:12:07.982 --> 00:12:09.934
(Laughter)

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:13.934
But the truth is that I had
a very happy childhood,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.934
full of laughter and love,
in a very close-knit family.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:20.169
But I also had grandfathers
who died in refugee camps.

00:12:20.708 --> 00:12:24.934
My cousin Polle died because
he could not get adequate healthcare.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.934
One of my closest friends,
Okoloma, died in a plane crash

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.934
because our fire trucks
did not have water.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.934
I grew up under repressive
military governments

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.934
that devalued education,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.934
so that sometimes, my parents
were not paid their salaries.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:42.935
And so, as a child, I saw jam
disappear from the breakfast table,

00:12:42.959 --> 00:12:45.456
then margarine disappeared,

00:12:45.480 --> 00:12:47.934
then bread became too expensive,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.829
then milk became rationed.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:54.615
And most of all, a kind
of normalized political fear

00:12:54.639 --> 00:12:56.321
invaded our lives.

00:12:57.781 --> 00:12:59.918
All of these stories make me who I am.

00:13:00.415 --> 00:13:03.934
But to insist on only
these negative stories

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.934
is to flatten my experience

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.622
and to overlook the many other
stories that formed me.

00:13:11.352 --> 00:13:13.934
The single story creates stereotypes,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:18.934
and the problem with stereotypes
is not that they are untrue,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.934
but that they are incomplete.

00:13:21.315 --> 00:13:23.918
They make one story become the only story.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.530
Of course, Africa is a continent
full of catastrophes:

00:13:27.554 --> 00:13:30.934
There are immense ones,
such as the horrific rapes in Congo

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.584
and depressing ones,

00:13:32.608 --> 00:13:37.108
such as the fact that 5,000 people apply
for one job vacancy in Nigeria.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:41.521
But there are other stories
that are not about catastrophe,

00:13:41.545 --> 00:13:44.934
and it is very important, it is just
as important, to talk about them.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.934
I've always felt that it is impossible

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.934
to engage properly
with a place or a person

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:53.934
without engaging with all of the stories
of that place and that person.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:57.538
The consequence
of the single story is this:

00:13:57.562 --> 00:13:59.519
It robs people of dignity.

00:14:00.290 --> 00:14:03.934
It makes our recognition
of our equal humanity difficult.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:08.122
It emphasizes how we are different
rather than how we are similar.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.447
So what if before my Mexican trip,

00:14:11.471 --> 00:14:14.934
I had followed the immigration
debate from both sides,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.934
the U.S. and the Mexican?

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.934
What if my mother had told us
that Fide's family was poor

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.934
and hardworking?

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.054
What if we had an African
television network

00:14:25.078 --> 00:14:28.934
that broadcast diverse
African stories all over the world?

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:33.289
What the Nigerian writer Chinua Achebe
calls "a balance of stories."

00:14:33.313 --> 00:14:37.289
What if my roommate knew
about my Nigerian publisher,

00:14:37.313 --> 00:14:38.934
Muhtar Bakare,

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.006
a remarkable man who left
his job in a bank

00:14:41.030 --> 00:14:43.935
to follow his dream
and start a publishing house?

00:14:43.959 --> 00:14:47.646
Now, the conventional wisdom
was that Nigerians don't read literature.

00:14:47.670 --> 00:14:48.924
He disagreed.

00:14:48.948 --> 00:14:52.034
He felt that people
who could read, would read,

00:14:52.058 --> 00:14:55.934
if you made literature affordable
and available to them.

00:14:56.624 --> 00:14:58.934
Shortly after he published my first novel,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.934
I went to a TV station
in Lagos to do an interview,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:05.149
and a woman who worked there
as a messenger came up to me and said,

00:15:05.173 --> 00:15:07.934
"I really liked your novel.
I didn't like the ending.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.197
Now, you must write a sequel,
and this is what will happen ..."

00:15:11.221 --> 00:15:13.935
(Laughter)

00:15:13.959 --> 00:15:16.935
And she went on to tell me
what to write in the sequel.

00:15:17.522 --> 00:15:19.934
I was not only charmed, I was very moved.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.934
Here was a woman, part of the ordinary
masses of Nigerians,

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.961
who were not supposed to be readers.

00:15:25.859 --> 00:15:27.483
She had not only read the book,

00:15:27.507 --> 00:15:29.316
but she had taken ownership of it

00:15:29.340 --> 00:15:32.443
and felt justified in telling me
what to write in the sequel.

00:15:33.538 --> 00:15:36.934
Now, what if my roommate knew
about my friend Funmi Iyanda,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.934
a fearless woman who hosts
a TV show in Lagos,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
and is determined to tell the stories
that we prefer to forget?

00:15:43.653 --> 00:15:46.934
What if my roommate knew
about the heart procedure

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.934
that was performed in the Lagos
hospital last week?

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:53.934
What if my roommate knew
about contemporary Nigerian music,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.934
talented people singing
in English and Pidgin,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.934
and Igbo and Yoruba and Ijo,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:02.934
mixing influences from Jay-Z to Fela

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.140
to Bob Marley to their grandfathers.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.197
What if my roommate knew
about the female lawyer

00:16:08.221 --> 00:16:11.934
who recently went to court in Nigeria
to challenge a ridiculous law

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.934
that required women to get
their husband's consent

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.934
before renewing their passports?

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.934
What if my roommate knew about Nollywood,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:25.338
full of innovative people making
films despite great technical odds,

00:16:25.362 --> 00:16:26.934
films so popular

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:31.934
that they really are the best example
of Nigerians consuming what they produce?

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:35.244
What if my roommate knew about
my wonderfully ambitious hair braider,

00:16:35.268 --> 00:16:38.934
who has just started her own business
selling hair extensions?

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:42.934
Or about the millions of other Nigerians
who start businesses and sometimes fail,

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.896
but continue to nurse ambition?

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.934
Every time I am home I am confronted

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.934
with the usual sources of irritation
for most Nigerians:

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:55.402
our failed infrastructure,
our failed government,

00:16:55.426 --> 00:16:57.481
but also by the incredible resilience

00:16:57.505 --> 00:17:00.934
of people who thrive
despite the government,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.219
rather than because of it.

00:17:03.331 --> 00:17:05.934
I teach writing workshops
in Lagos every summer,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.934
and it is amazing to me
how many people apply,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.934
how many people are eager to write,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.344
to tell stories.

00:17:14.233 --> 00:17:17.256
My Nigerian publisher and I
have just started a non-profit

00:17:17.280 --> 00:17:18.934
called Farafina Trust,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:21.934
and we have big dreams
of building libraries

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.101
and refurbishing libraries
that already exist

00:17:24.125 --> 00:17:26.934
and providing books for state schools

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.054
that don't have anything
in their libraries,

00:17:29.078 --> 00:17:31.459
and also of organizing lots
and lots of workshops,

00:17:31.483 --> 00:17:32.934
in reading and writing,

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:36.157
for all the people who are eager
to tell our many stories.

00:17:36.284 --> 00:17:37.934
Stories matter.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.934
Many stories matter.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:43.934
Stories have been used
to dispossess and to malign,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:47.934
but stories can also be used
to empower and to humanize.

00:17:48.600 --> 00:17:50.934
Stories can break the dignity of a people,

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:54.661
but stories can also repair
that broken dignity.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.006
The American writer
Alice Walker wrote this

00:17:58.030 --> 00:18:01.934
about her Southern relatives
who had moved to the North.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:03.934
She introduced them to a book about

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:06.026
the Southern life
that they had left behind.

00:18:07.550 --> 00:18:10.934
"They sat around,
reading the book themselves,

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:16.486
listening to me read the book,
and a kind of paradise was regained."

00:18:17.537 --> 00:18:20.399
I would like to end with this thought:

00:18:20.423 --> 00:18:22.934
That when we reject the single story,

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:25.934
when we realize that
there is never a single story

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:28.399
about any place,

00:18:28.423 --> 00:18:29.934
we regain a kind of paradise.

00:18:30.653 --> 00:18:31.775
Thank you.

00:18:31.799 --> 00:18:34.799
(Applause)

title: Optical illusions show how we see
transcript: I want to start with a game. Okay? And to win this game, all you have to do is see the reality that's in front of you as it really is, all right? So we have two panels here, of colored dots. And one of those dots is the same in the two panels. And you have to tell me which one.Now, I narrowed it down to the gray one, the green one, and, say, the orange one. So by a show of hands, we'll start with the easiest one. Show of hands: how many people think it's the gray one? Really? Okay. How many people think it's the green one? And how many people think it's the orange one? Pretty even split.Let's find out what the reality is. Here is the orange one.(Laughter)Here is the green one. And here is the gray one.(Laughter)So for all of you who saw that, you're complete realists. All right?(Laughter)So this is pretty amazing, isn't it? Because nearly every living system has evolved the ability to detect light in one way or another. So for us, seeing color is one of the simplest things the brain does. And yet, even at this most fundamental level, context is everything. What I'm going to talk about is not that context is everything, but why context is everything. Because it's answering that question that tells us not only why we see what we do, but who we are as individuals, and who we are as a society.But first, we have to ask another question, which is, "What is color for?" And instead of telling you, I'll just show you. What you see here is a jungle scene, and you see the surfaces according to the amount of light that those surfaces reflect. Now, can any of you see the predator that's about to jump out at you? And if you haven't seen it yet, you're dead, right?(Laughter)Can anyone see it? Anyone? No? Now let's see the surfaces according to the quality of light that they reflect. And now you see it.So, color enables us to see the similarities and differences between surfaces, according to the full spectrum of light that they reflect. But what you've just done is in many respects mathematically impossible. Why? Because, as Berkeley tells us, we have no direct access to our physical world, other than through our senses. And the light that falls onto our eyes is determined by multiple things in the world, not only the color of objects, but also the color of their illumination, and the color of the space between us and those objects. You vary any one of those parameters, and you'll change the color of the light that falls onto your eye.This is a huge problem, because it means that the same image could have an infinite number of possible real-world sources. Let me show you what I mean. Imagine that this is the back of your eye, okay? And these are two projections from the world. They're identical in every single way. Identical in shape, size, spectral content. They are the same, as far as your eye is concerned. And yet they come from completely different sources. The one on the right comes from a yellow surface, in shadow, oriented facing the left, viewed through a pinkish medium. The one on the left comes from an orange surface, under direct light, facing to the right, viewed through sort of a bluish medium. Completely different meanings, giving rise to the exact same retinal information. And yet it's only the retinal information that we get.So how on Earth do we even see? So if you remember anything in this next 18 minutes, remember this: that the light that falls onto your eye, sensory information, is meaningless, because it could mean literally anything. And what's true for sensory information is true for information generally. There's no inherent meaning in information. It's what we do with that information that matters.So, how do we see? Well, we see by learning to see. The brain evolved the mechanisms for finding patterns, finding relationships in information, and associating those relationships with a behavioral meaning, a significance, by interacting with the world. We're very aware of this in the form of more cognitive attributes, like language. I'm going to give you some letter strings, and I want you to read them out for me, if you can.Audience: "Can you read this?" "You are not reading this." "What are you reading?"Beau Lotto: "What are you reading?" Half the letters are missing, right? There's no a priori reason why an "H" has to go between that "W" and "A." But you put one there. Why? Because in the statistics of your past experience, it would have been useful to do so. So you do so again. And yet you don't put a letter after that first "T." Why? Because it wouldn't have been useful in the past. So you don't do it again.So, let me show you how quickly our brains can redefine normality, even at the simplest thing the brain does, which is color. So if I could have the lights down up here. I want you to first notice that those two desert scenes are physically the same. One is simply the flipping of the other. Now I want you to look at that dot between the green and the red. And I want you to stare at that dot. Don't look anywhere else. We're going to look at it for about 30 seconds, which is a bit of a killer in an 18-minute talk.(Laughter)But I really want you to learn. And I'll tell you — don't look anywhere else — I'll tell you what's happening in your head. Your brain is learning, and it's learning that the right side of its visual field is under red illumination; the left side of its visual field is under green illumination. That's what it's learning. Okay? Now, when I tell you, I want you to look at the dot between the two desert scenes. So why don't you do that now?(Laughter)Can I have the lights up again?I take it from your response they don't look the same anymore, right?(Applause)Why? Because your brain is seeing that same information as if the right one is still under red light, and the left one is still under green light. That's your new normal. Okay? So, what does this mean for context? It means I can take two identical squares, put them in light and dark surrounds, and the one on the dark surround looks lighter than on the light surround. What's significant is not simply the light and dark surrounds that matter. It's what those light and dark surrounds meant for your behavior in the past.So I'll show you what I mean. Here we have that exact same illusion. We have two identical tiles on the left, one in a dark surround, one in a light surround. And the same thing over on the right. Now, I'll reveal those two scenes, but I'm not going to change anything within those boxes, except their meaning. And see what happens to your perception.Notice that on the left the two tiles look nearly completely opposite: one very white and one very dark, right? Whereas on the right, the two tiles look nearly the same. And yet there is still one on a dark surround, and one on a light surround. Why? Because if the tile in that shadow were in fact in shadow, and reflecting the same amount of light to your eye as the one outside the shadow, it would have to be more reflective — just the laws of physics. So you see it that way.Whereas on the right, the information is consistent with those two tiles being under the same light. If they're under the same light reflecting the same amount of light to your eye, then they must be equally reflective. So you see it that way. Which means we can bring all this information together to create some incredibly strong illusions.This is one I made a few years ago. And you'll notice you see a dark brown tile at the top, and a bright orange tile at the side. That is your perceptual reality. The physical reality is that those two tiles are the same.Here you see four gray tiles on your left, seven gray tiles on the right. I'm not going to change those tiles at all, but I'm going to reveal the rest of the scene. And see what happens to your perception. The four blue tiles on the left are gray. The seven yellow tiles on the right are also gray. They are the same. Okay? Don't believe me? Let's watch it again.What's true for color is also true for complex perceptions of motion. So, here we have — let's turn this around — a diamond. And what I'm going to do is, I'm going to hold it here, and I'm going to spin it. And for all of you, you'll see it probably spinning this direction. Now I want you to keep looking at it. Move your eyes around, blink, maybe close one eye. And suddenly it will flip, and start spinning the opposite direction. Yes? Raise your hand if you got that. Yes? Keep blinking. Every time you blink, it will switch. So I can ask you, which direction is it rotating? How do you know? Your brain doesn't know, because both are equally likely. So depending on where it looks, it flips between the two possibilities.Are we the only ones that see illusions? The answer to this question is no. Even the beautiful bumblebee, with its mere one million brain cells, which is 250 times fewer cells than you have in one retina, sees illusions, does the most complicated things that even our most sophisticated computers can't do. So in my lab we work on bumblebees, because we can completely control their experience, and see how it alters the architecture of their brain. We do this in what we call the Bee Matrix.Here you have the hive. You can see the queen bee, the large bee in the middle. Those are her daughters, the eggs. They go back and forth between this hive and the arena, via this tube. You'll see one of the bees come out here. You see how she has a little number on her? There's another one coming out, she also has a number on her. Now, they're not born that way, right? We pull them out, put them in the fridge, and they fall asleep. Then you can superglue little numbers on them.(Laughter)And now, in this experiment they get a reward if they go to the blue flowers. They land on the flower, stick their tongue in there, called a proboscis, and drink sugar water. She's drinking a glass of water that's about that big to you and I, will do that about three times, then fly. And sometimes they learn not to go to the blue, but to go where the other bees go. So they copy each other. They can count to five. They can recognize faces. And here she comes down the ladder. And she'll come into the hive, find an empty honey pot, and throw up, and that's honey.(Laughter)Now remember, she's supposed to be going to the blue flowers, but what are these bees doing in the upper right corner? It looks like they're going to green flowers. Now, are they getting it wrong? And the answer to the question is no. Those are actually blue flowers. But those are blue flowers under green light. So they're using the relationships between the colors to solve the puzzle, which is exactly what we do.So, illusions are often used, especially in art, in the words of a more contemporary artist, "to demonstrate the fragility of our senses." Okay, this is complete rubbish. The senses aren't fragile. And if they were, we wouldn't be here. Instead, color tells us something completely different, that the brain didn't actually evolve to see the world the way it is. We can't. Instead, the brain evolved to see the world the way it was useful to see in the past. And how we see is by continually redefining normality.So, how can we take this incredible capacity of plasticity of the brain and get people to experience their world differently? Well, one of the ways we do it in my lab and studio is we translate the light into sound, and we enable people to hear their visual world. And they can navigate the world using their ears.Here's David on the right, and he's holding a camera. On the left is what his camera sees. And you'll see there's a faint line going across that image. That line is broken up into 32 squares. In each square, we calculate the average color. And then we just simply translate that into sound. And now he's going to turn around, close his eyes, and find a plate on the ground with his eyes closed.(Continuous sound)(Sound changes momentarily)(Sound changes momentarily)(Sound changes momentarily)(Sound changes momentarily)(Sound changes momentarily)Beau Lotto: He finds it. Amazing, right? So not only can we create a prosthetic for the visually impaired, but we can also investigate how people literally make sense of the world. But we can also do something else. We can also make music with color. So, working with kids, they created images, thinking about what might the images you see sound like if we could listen to them. And then we translated these images. And this is one of those images. And this is a six-year-old child composing a piece of music for a 32-piece orchestra. And this is what it sounds like.(Electronic representation of orchestral music)So, a six-year-old child. Okay?Now, what does all this mean? What this suggests is that no one is an outside observer of nature, okay? We're not defined by our central properties, by the bits that make us up. We're defined by our environment and our interaction with that environment, by our ecology. And that ecology is necessarily relative, historical and empirical. So, what I'd like to finish with is this over here. Because what I've been trying to do is really celebrate uncertainty. Because I think only through uncertainty is there potential for understanding.So, if some of you are still feeling a bit too certain, I'd like to do this one. So, if we have the lights down. And what we have here — Can everyone see 25 purple surfaces on your left, and 25, call it yellowish, surfaces on your right? So now, what I want to do, I'm going to put the middle nine surfaces here under yellow illumination, by simply putting a filter behind them. Now you can see that changes the light that's coming through there, right? Because now the light is going through a yellowish filter and then a purplish filter. I'm going to do the opposite on the left here. I'm going to put the middle nine under a purplish light.Now, some of you will have noticed that the consequence is that the light coming through those middle nine on the right, or your left, is exactly the same as the light coming through the middle nine on your right. Agreed? Yes? Okay. So they are physically the same. Let's pull the covers off. Now remember — you know that the middle nine are exactly the same. Do they look the same? No. The question is, "Is that an illusion?" And I'll leave you with that.So, thank you very much.(Laughter)(Applause)

00:01:04.572 --> 00:01:06.392
Here is the orange one.

00:01:07.671 --> 00:01:09.107
(Laughter)

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.282
Here is the green one.

00:01:13.170 --> 00:01:15.171
And here is the gray one.

00:01:16.670 --> 00:01:19.934
(Laughter)

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.757
So for all of you who saw that,
you're complete realists.

00:01:23.226 --> 00:01:24.399
All right?

00:01:24.423 --> 00:01:25.934
(Laughter)

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.729
So this is pretty amazing, isn't it?

00:01:27.753 --> 00:01:29.555
Because nearly every living system

00:01:29.579 --> 00:01:33.487
has evolved the ability
to detect light in one way or another.

00:01:33.511 --> 00:01:35.352
So for us, seeing color

00:01:35.376 --> 00:01:37.686
is one of the simplest things
the brain does.

00:01:37.710 --> 00:01:40.511
And yet, even at this
most fundamental level,

00:01:40.535 --> 00:01:43.154
context is everything.

00:01:43.178 --> 00:01:46.359
What I'm going to talk about
is not that context is everything,

00:01:46.383 --> 00:01:48.408
but why context is everything.

00:01:48.432 --> 00:01:50.648
Because it's answering that question

00:01:50.672 --> 00:01:54.216
that tells us not only
why we see what we do,

00:01:54.240 --> 00:01:55.934
but who we are as individuals,

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:57.839
and who we are as a society.

00:01:59.447 --> 00:02:01.510
But first, we have to ask
another question,

00:02:01.534 --> 00:02:03.042
which is, "What is color for?"

00:02:03.066 --> 00:02:05.281
And instead of telling you,
I'll just show you.

00:02:05.305 --> 00:02:07.934
What you see here is a jungle scene,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.742
and you see the surfaces
according to the amount of light

00:02:10.766 --> 00:02:12.431
that those surfaces reflect.

00:02:12.455 --> 00:02:16.838
Now, can any of you see the predator
that's about to jump out at you?

00:02:16.862 --> 00:02:19.886
And if you haven't seen it yet,
you're dead, right?

00:02:19.910 --> 00:02:20.911
(Laughter)

00:02:20.935 --> 00:02:23.273
Can anyone see it? Anyone? No?

00:02:23.297 --> 00:02:24.766
Now let's see the surfaces

00:02:24.790 --> 00:02:27.644
according to the quality of light
that they reflect.

00:02:27.668 --> 00:02:29.209
And now you see it.

00:02:30.287 --> 00:02:32.552
So, color enables us to see

00:02:32.576 --> 00:02:35.002
the similarities and differences
between surfaces,

00:02:35.026 --> 00:02:38.072
according to the full spectrum
of light that they reflect.

00:02:38.096 --> 00:02:39.557
But what you've just done

00:02:39.581 --> 00:02:42.621
is in many respects
mathematically impossible.

00:02:42.645 --> 00:02:43.892
Why?

00:02:43.916 --> 00:02:45.346
Because, as Berkeley tells us,

00:02:45.370 --> 00:02:47.933
we have no direct access
to our physical world,

00:02:47.957 --> 00:02:49.934
other than through our senses.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.773
And the light that falls onto our eyes

00:02:51.797 --> 00:02:54.059
is determined by multiple
things in the world,

00:02:54.083 --> 00:02:55.934
not only the color of objects,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.934
but also the color of their illumination,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.767
and the color of the space
between us and those objects.

00:03:00.791 --> 00:03:03.044
You vary any one of those parameters,

00:03:03.068 --> 00:03:06.590
and you'll change the color
of the light that falls onto your eye.

00:03:08.106 --> 00:03:09.290
This is a huge problem,

00:03:09.314 --> 00:03:12.283
because it means that the same image

00:03:12.307 --> 00:03:15.828
could have an infinite number
of possible real-world sources.

00:03:15.852 --> 00:03:17.193
Let me show you what I mean.

00:03:17.217 --> 00:03:20.050
Imagine that this
is the back of your eye, okay?

00:03:20.074 --> 00:03:22.574
And these are two projections
from the world.

00:03:22.598 --> 00:03:25.061
They're identical in every single way.

00:03:25.085 --> 00:03:29.117
Identical in shape,
size, spectral content.

00:03:29.141 --> 00:03:31.910
They are the same,
as far as your eye is concerned.

00:03:32.956 --> 00:03:37.050
And yet they come
from completely different sources.

00:03:38.178 --> 00:03:42.679
The one on the right
comes from a yellow surface,

00:03:42.703 --> 00:03:45.108
in shadow, oriented facing the left,

00:03:45.132 --> 00:03:48.004
viewed through a pinkish medium.

00:03:48.028 --> 00:03:51.272
The one on the left comes
from an orange surface,

00:03:51.296 --> 00:03:53.479
under direct light, facing to the right,

00:03:53.503 --> 00:03:55.487
viewed through sort of a bluish medium.

00:03:55.511 --> 00:03:57.686
Completely different meanings,

00:03:57.710 --> 00:04:00.987
giving rise to the exact same
retinal information.

00:04:01.011 --> 00:04:04.328
And yet it's only the retinal
information that we get.

00:04:05.038 --> 00:04:08.320
So how on Earth do we even see?

00:04:08.344 --> 00:04:11.551
So if you remember anything
in this next 18 minutes,

00:04:11.575 --> 00:04:12.821
remember this:

00:04:12.845 --> 00:04:14.787
that the light that falls onto your eye,

00:04:14.811 --> 00:04:17.234
sensory information, is meaningless,

00:04:17.258 --> 00:04:19.376
because it could mean literally anything.

00:04:19.956 --> 00:04:23.501
And what's true for sensory information
is true for information generally.

00:04:23.525 --> 00:04:25.558
There's no inherent
meaning in information.

00:04:25.582 --> 00:04:27.995
It's what we do with that
information that matters.

00:04:28.693 --> 00:04:32.416
So, how do we see?
Well, we see by learning to see.

00:04:32.440 --> 00:04:35.979
The brain evolved the mechanisms
for finding patterns,

00:04:36.003 --> 00:04:38.043
finding relationships in information,

00:04:38.067 --> 00:04:42.265
and associating those relationships
with a behavioral meaning,

00:04:42.289 --> 00:04:45.154
a significance, by interacting
with the world.

00:04:45.178 --> 00:04:46.933
We're very aware of this

00:04:46.957 --> 00:04:49.786
in the form of more cognitive
attributes, like language.

00:04:49.810 --> 00:04:51.843
I'm going to give you some letter strings,

00:04:51.867 --> 00:04:54.360
and I want you to read them
out for me, if you can.

00:04:54.384 --> 00:04:56.049
Audience: "Can you read this?"

00:04:56.890 --> 00:04:58.934
"You are not reading this."

00:04:59.388 --> 00:05:00.834
"What are you reading?"

00:05:00.858 --> 00:05:04.242
Beau Lotto: "What are you reading?"
Half the letters are missing, right?

00:05:04.266 --> 00:05:05.575
There's no a priori reason

00:05:05.599 --> 00:05:08.091
why an "H" has to go
between that "W" and "A."

00:05:08.115 --> 00:05:09.670
But you put one there. Why?

00:05:09.694 --> 00:05:12.050
Because in the statistics
of your past experience,

00:05:12.074 --> 00:05:13.768
it would have been useful to do so.

00:05:13.792 --> 00:05:15.233
So you do so again.

00:05:15.257 --> 00:05:17.934
And yet you don't put a letter
after that first "T."

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.822
Why? Because it wouldn't have been
useful in the past.

00:05:20.846 --> 00:05:22.934
So you don't do it again.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:26.827
So, let me show you how quickly
our brains can redefine normality,

00:05:26.851 --> 00:05:29.581
even at the simplest thing
the brain does, which is color.

00:05:29.605 --> 00:05:32.239
So if I could have
the lights down up here.

00:05:32.263 --> 00:05:36.062
I want you to first notice that those
two desert scenes are physically the same.

00:05:36.086 --> 00:05:38.263
One is simply the flipping of the other.

00:05:40.042 --> 00:05:42.352
Now I want you to look at that dot

00:05:42.376 --> 00:05:44.933
between the green and the red.

00:05:44.957 --> 00:05:47.934
And I want you to stare at that dot.
Don't look anywhere else.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.164
We're going to look
at it for about 30 seconds,

00:05:50.188 --> 00:05:52.630
which is a bit of a killer
in an 18-minute talk.

00:05:52.654 --> 00:05:53.947
(Laughter)

00:05:53.971 --> 00:05:55.565
But I really want you to learn.

00:05:55.589 --> 00:05:57.890
And I'll tell you -- don't look
anywhere else --

00:05:57.914 --> 00:05:59.969
I'll tell you what's
happening in your head.

00:05:59.993 --> 00:06:01.260
Your brain is learning,

00:06:01.284 --> 00:06:04.012
and it's learning
that the right side of its visual field

00:06:04.036 --> 00:06:05.329
is under red illumination;

00:06:05.353 --> 00:06:08.280
the left side of its visual field
is under green illumination.

00:06:08.304 --> 00:06:11.190
That's what it's learning. Okay?

00:06:11.214 --> 00:06:15.893
Now, when I tell you, I want you to look
at the dot between the two desert scenes.

00:06:15.917 --> 00:06:17.932
So why don't you do that now?

00:06:17.956 --> 00:06:21.316
(Laughter)

00:06:21.340 --> 00:06:23.243
Can I have the lights up again?

00:06:23.267 --> 00:06:26.733
I take it from your response
they don't look the same anymore, right?

00:06:26.757 --> 00:06:27.934
(Applause)

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.934
Why? Because your brain
is seeing that same information

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.645
as if the right one is still
under red light,

00:06:33.669 --> 00:06:35.827
and the left one is still
under green light.

00:06:35.851 --> 00:06:37.216
That's your new normal.

00:06:37.240 --> 00:06:39.246
Okay? So, what does this mean for context?

00:06:39.270 --> 00:06:41.604
It means I can take two identical squares,

00:06:41.628 --> 00:06:43.448
put them in light and dark surrounds,

00:06:43.472 --> 00:06:46.957
and the one on the dark surround
looks lighter than on the light surround.

00:06:46.981 --> 00:06:50.565
What's significant is not simply the light
and dark surrounds that matter.

00:06:50.589 --> 00:06:54.234
It's what those light and dark surrounds
meant for your behavior in the past.

00:06:54.258 --> 00:06:55.655
So I'll show you what I mean.

00:06:55.679 --> 00:06:57.662
Here we have that exact same illusion.

00:06:57.686 --> 00:06:59.812
We have two identical tiles on the left,

00:06:59.836 --> 00:07:02.122
one in a dark surround,
one in a light surround.

00:07:02.146 --> 00:07:04.225
And the same thing over on the right.

00:07:04.249 --> 00:07:07.100
Now, I'll reveal those two scenes,

00:07:07.124 --> 00:07:09.792
but I'm not going to change
anything within those boxes,

00:07:09.816 --> 00:07:10.967
except their meaning.

00:07:10.991 --> 00:07:13.304
And see what happens to your perception.

00:07:13.328 --> 00:07:14.934
Notice that on the left

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.723
the two tiles look nearly
completely opposite:

00:07:17.747 --> 00:07:20.838
one very white and one very dark, right?

00:07:20.862 --> 00:07:24.137
Whereas on the right,
the two tiles look nearly the same.

00:07:24.161 --> 00:07:26.399
And yet there is still one
on a dark surround,

00:07:26.423 --> 00:07:27.788
and one on a light surround.

00:07:27.812 --> 00:07:28.963
Why?

00:07:28.987 --> 00:07:32.934
Because if the tile in that shadow
were in fact in shadow,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.387
and reflecting the same
amount of light to your eye

00:07:35.411 --> 00:07:37.179
as the one outside the shadow,

00:07:37.203 --> 00:07:40.600
it would have to be more reflective
-- just the laws of physics.

00:07:40.624 --> 00:07:42.142
So you see it that way.

00:07:42.166 --> 00:07:44.824
Whereas on the right,
the information is consistent

00:07:44.848 --> 00:07:47.531
with those two tiles
being under the same light.

00:07:47.555 --> 00:07:51.388
If they're under the same light reflecting
the same amount of light to your eye,

00:07:51.412 --> 00:07:53.197
then they must be equally reflective.

00:07:53.221 --> 00:07:54.484
So you see it that way.

00:07:54.508 --> 00:07:57.034
Which means we can bring
all this information together

00:07:57.058 --> 00:07:59.106
to create some incredibly
strong illusions.

00:07:59.130 --> 00:08:00.934
This is one I made a few years ago.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:04.271
And you'll notice you see
a dark brown tile at the top,

00:08:04.295 --> 00:08:06.774
and a bright orange tile at the side.

00:08:06.798 --> 00:08:08.528
That is your perceptual reality.

00:08:08.552 --> 00:08:11.516
The physical reality
is that those two tiles are the same.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.934
Here you see four gray tiles on your left,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.470
seven gray tiles on the right.

00:08:19.494 --> 00:08:21.551
I'm not going to change
those tiles at all,

00:08:21.575 --> 00:08:23.742
but I'm going to reveal
the rest of the scene.

00:08:23.766 --> 00:08:25.724
And see what happens to your perception.

00:08:26.319 --> 00:08:29.828
The four blue tiles on the left are gray.

00:08:29.852 --> 00:08:33.505
The seven yellow tiles
on the right are also gray.

00:08:33.529 --> 00:08:35.410
They are the same. Okay?

00:08:35.434 --> 00:08:37.472
Don't believe me? Let's watch it again.

00:08:39.356 --> 00:08:43.610
What's true for color is also true
for complex perceptions of motion.

00:08:43.634 --> 00:08:46.443
So, here we have --

00:08:46.467 --> 00:08:49.731
let's turn this around -- a diamond.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.578
And what I'm going to do is,
I'm going to hold it here,

00:08:53.602 --> 00:08:55.448
and I'm going to spin it.

00:08:56.789 --> 00:08:59.933
And for all of you, you'll see it
probably spinning this direction.

00:08:59.957 --> 00:09:02.569
Now I want you to keep looking at it.

00:09:02.593 --> 00:09:05.093
Move your eyes around,
blink, maybe close one eye.

00:09:05.117 --> 00:09:08.934
And suddenly it will flip, and start
spinning the opposite direction.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.130
Yes? Raise your hand if you got that. Yes?

00:09:12.154 --> 00:09:13.361
Keep blinking.

00:09:13.385 --> 00:09:15.970
Every time you blink, it will switch.

00:09:15.994 --> 00:09:18.591
So I can ask you,
which direction is it rotating?

00:09:20.115 --> 00:09:21.385
How do you know?

00:09:22.098 --> 00:09:25.208
Your brain doesn't know,
because both are equally likely.

00:09:25.232 --> 00:09:26.770
So depending on where it looks,

00:09:26.794 --> 00:09:30.123
it flips between the two possibilities.

00:09:30.147 --> 00:09:32.071
Are we the only ones that see illusions?

00:09:32.095 --> 00:09:33.934
The answer to this question is no.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.677
Even the beautiful bumblebee,

00:09:35.701 --> 00:09:38.575
with its mere one million brain cells,

00:09:38.599 --> 00:09:41.614
which is 250 times fewer cells
than you have in one retina,

00:09:41.638 --> 00:09:44.466
sees illusions, does
the most complicated things

00:09:44.490 --> 00:09:46.934
that even our most
sophisticated computers can't do.

00:09:47.299 --> 00:09:49.155
So in my lab we work on bumblebees,

00:09:49.179 --> 00:09:51.668
because we can completely
control their experience,

00:09:51.692 --> 00:09:54.225
and see how it alters
the architecture of their brain.

00:09:54.249 --> 00:09:56.350
We do this in what we call the Bee Matrix.

00:09:56.374 --> 00:09:57.648
Here you have the hive.

00:09:57.672 --> 00:10:00.267
You can see the queen bee,
the large bee in the middle.

00:10:00.291 --> 00:10:01.917
Those are her daughters, the eggs.

00:10:01.941 --> 00:10:05.556
They go back and forth between this hive
and the arena, via this tube.

00:10:08.800 --> 00:10:11.387
You'll see one of the bees come out here.

00:10:11.411 --> 00:10:13.505
You see how she has
a little number on her?

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.894
There's another one coming out,
she also has a number on her.

00:10:17.383 --> 00:10:19.654
Now, they're not born that way, right?

00:10:19.678 --> 00:10:22.693
We pull them out, put them
in the fridge, and they fall asleep.

00:10:22.717 --> 00:10:25.010
Then you can superglue
little numbers on them.

00:10:25.034 --> 00:10:26.217
(Laughter)

00:10:26.241 --> 00:10:29.934
And now, in this experiment they get
a reward if they go to the blue flowers.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.151
They land on the flower,

00:10:31.175 --> 00:10:34.684
stick their tongue in there,
called a proboscis, and drink sugar water.

00:10:34.708 --> 00:10:37.866
She's drinking a glass of water
that's about that big to you and I,

00:10:37.890 --> 00:10:41.524
will do that about three times, then fly.

00:10:43.864 --> 00:10:46.142
And sometimes they learn
not to go to the blue,

00:10:46.166 --> 00:10:47.934
but to go where the other bees go.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.172
So they copy each other.

00:10:49.196 --> 00:10:51.482
They can count to five.
They can recognize faces.

00:10:51.506 --> 00:10:53.467
And here she comes down the ladder.

00:10:53.491 --> 00:10:56.072
And she'll come into the hive,
find an empty honey pot,

00:10:56.096 --> 00:10:58.153
and throw up, and that's honey.

00:10:58.177 --> 00:10:59.328
(Laughter)

00:10:59.352 --> 00:11:04.162
Now remember, she's supposed
to be going to the blue flowers,

00:11:04.186 --> 00:11:06.813
but what are these bees doing
in the upper right corner?

00:11:06.837 --> 00:11:09.326
It looks like they're
going to green flowers.

00:11:09.350 --> 00:11:12.156
Now, are they getting it wrong?

00:11:12.180 --> 00:11:15.672
And the answer to the question is no.
Those are actually blue flowers.

00:11:15.696 --> 00:11:19.259
But those are blue flowers
under green light.

00:11:19.283 --> 00:11:23.015
So they're using the relationships
between the colors to solve the puzzle,

00:11:23.039 --> 00:11:25.110
which is exactly what we do.

00:11:25.134 --> 00:11:27.465
So, illusions are often used,

00:11:27.489 --> 00:11:31.100
especially in art, in the words
of a more contemporary artist,

00:11:31.124 --> 00:11:33.584
"to demonstrate the fragility
of our senses."

00:11:33.608 --> 00:11:35.932
Okay, this is complete rubbish.

00:11:35.956 --> 00:11:39.906
The senses aren't fragile.
And if they were, we wouldn't be here.

00:11:39.930 --> 00:11:42.829
Instead, color tells us
something completely different,

00:11:42.853 --> 00:11:46.221
that the brain didn't actually evolve
to see the world the way it is.

00:11:46.245 --> 00:11:47.456
We can't.

00:11:47.480 --> 00:11:49.892
Instead, the brain
evolved to see the world

00:11:49.916 --> 00:11:52.934
the way it was useful to see in the past.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:57.129
And how we see is by continually
redefining normality.

00:11:59.448 --> 00:12:06.320
So, how can we take this incredible
capacity of plasticity of the brain

00:12:06.344 --> 00:12:08.868
and get people to experience
their world differently?

00:12:08.892 --> 00:12:11.589
Well, one of the ways we do it
in my lab and studio

00:12:11.613 --> 00:12:14.851
is we translate the light into sound,

00:12:14.875 --> 00:12:17.949
and we enable people to hear
their visual world.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.616
And they can navigate
the world using their ears.

00:12:22.223 --> 00:12:25.579
Here's David on the right,
and he's holding a camera.

00:12:25.603 --> 00:12:27.333
On the left is what his camera sees.

00:12:27.357 --> 00:12:30.365
And you'll see there's a faint line
going across that image.

00:12:30.389 --> 00:12:32.798
That line is broken up into 32 squares.

00:12:32.822 --> 00:12:35.149
In each square,
we calculate the average color.

00:12:35.173 --> 00:12:37.554
And then we just simply
translate that into sound.

00:12:37.578 --> 00:12:40.811
And now he's going to turn around,

00:12:40.835 --> 00:12:43.695
close his eyes,

00:12:43.719 --> 00:12:46.981
and find a plate on the ground
with his eyes closed.

00:12:47.005 --> 00:12:48.229
(Continuous sound)

00:12:49.962 --> 00:12:51.290
(Sound changes momentarily)

00:12:52.100 --> 00:12:53.450
(Sound changes momentarily)

00:12:54.941 --> 00:12:57.171
(Sound changes momentarily)

00:12:59.378 --> 00:13:01.215
(Sound changes momentarily)

00:13:03.084 --> 00:13:04.921
(Sound changes momentarily)

00:13:05.571 --> 00:13:07.512
Beau Lotto: He finds it. Amazing, right?

00:13:07.536 --> 00:13:10.599
So not only can we create a prosthetic
for the visually impaired,

00:13:10.623 --> 00:13:13.106
but we can also investigate

00:13:13.130 --> 00:13:15.826
how people literally
make sense of the world.

00:13:15.850 --> 00:13:17.485
But we can also do something else.

00:13:17.509 --> 00:13:20.597
We can also make music with color.

00:13:20.621 --> 00:13:22.297
So, working with kids,

00:13:22.321 --> 00:13:24.114
they created images,

00:13:24.138 --> 00:13:26.254
thinking about what might
the images you see

00:13:26.278 --> 00:13:28.102
sound like if we could listen to them.

00:13:28.126 --> 00:13:29.934
And then we translated these images.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.934
And this is one of those images.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.934
And this is a six-year-old child
composing a piece of music

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.934
for a 32-piece orchestra.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.959
And this is what it sounds like.

00:13:39.983 --> 00:13:46.661
(Electronic representation
of orchestral music)

00:14:06.547 --> 00:14:08.814
So, a six-year-old child. Okay?

00:14:08.838 --> 00:14:10.955
Now, what does all this mean?

00:14:12.551 --> 00:14:16.891
What this suggests is that no one
is an outside observer of nature, okay?

00:14:16.915 --> 00:14:18.980
We're not defined
by our central properties,

00:14:19.004 --> 00:14:20.668
by the bits that make us up.

00:14:20.692 --> 00:14:24.366
We're defined by our environment
and our interaction with that environment,

00:14:24.390 --> 00:14:26.042
by our ecology.

00:14:26.066 --> 00:14:32.098
And that ecology is necessarily
relative, historical and empirical.

00:14:34.003 --> 00:14:38.264
So, what I'd like to finish with
is this over here.

00:14:38.288 --> 00:14:41.549
Because what I've been trying to do
is really celebrate uncertainty.

00:14:41.573 --> 00:14:45.334
Because I think only through uncertainty
is there potential for understanding.

00:14:45.358 --> 00:14:48.226
So, if some of you are still
feeling a bit too certain,

00:14:48.250 --> 00:14:49.792
I'd like to do this one.

00:14:49.816 --> 00:14:52.230
So, if we have the lights down.

00:14:52.254 --> 00:14:57.136
And what we have here --

00:14:58.344 --> 00:15:03.114
Can everyone see 25
purple surfaces on your left,

00:15:03.138 --> 00:15:07.330
and 25, call it yellowish,
surfaces on your right?

00:15:07.354 --> 00:15:08.668
So now, what I want to do,

00:15:08.692 --> 00:15:11.709
I'm going to put
the middle nine surfaces here

00:15:11.733 --> 00:15:13.360
under yellow illumination,

00:15:13.384 --> 00:15:15.390
by simply putting a filter behind them.

00:15:17.852 --> 00:15:21.823
Now you can see that changes the light
that's coming through there, right?

00:15:21.847 --> 00:15:24.928
Because now the light is going
through a yellowish filter

00:15:24.952 --> 00:15:26.499
and then a purplish filter.

00:15:26.523 --> 00:15:30.834
I'm going to do the opposite
on the left here.

00:15:30.858 --> 00:15:36.525
I'm going to put the middle nine
under a purplish light.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:42.495
Now, some of you will have noticed
that the consequence

00:15:42.519 --> 00:15:45.582
is that the light coming through those
middle nine on the right,

00:15:45.606 --> 00:15:48.414
or your left, is exactly
the same as the light

00:15:48.438 --> 00:15:51.130
coming through the middle
nine on your right.

00:15:51.154 --> 00:15:53.739
Agreed? Yes?

00:15:53.763 --> 00:15:56.312
Okay. So they are physically the same.

00:15:56.336 --> 00:15:58.974
Let's pull the covers off.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.299
Now remember --

00:16:05.662 --> 00:16:09.381
you know that the middle nine
are exactly the same.

00:16:09.405 --> 00:16:10.624
Do they look the same?

00:16:12.260 --> 00:16:13.415
No.

00:16:13.439 --> 00:16:15.394
The question is, "Is that an illusion?"

00:16:15.418 --> 00:16:16.825
And I'll leave you with that.

00:16:16.849 --> 00:16:18.054
So, thank you very much.

00:16:18.078 --> 00:16:19.243
(Laughter)

00:16:19.267 --> 00:16:21.958
(Applause)

title: Claim your "manspace"
transcript: So, I am indeed going to talk about the spaces men create for themselves, but first I want to tell you why I'm here. I'm here for two reasons. These two guys are my two sons Ford and Wren. When Ford was about three years old, we shared a very small room together, in a very small space. My office was on one half of the bedroom, and his bedroom was on the other half. And you can imagine, if you're a writer, that things would get really crowded around deadlines.So when Wren was on the way, I realized I needed to find a space of my own. There was no more space in the house. So I went out to the backyard, and without any previous building experience, and about 3,000 dollars and some recycled materials, I built this space. It had everything I needed. It was quiet. There was enough space. And I had control, which was very important.As I was building this space, I thought to myself, "Surely I'm not the only guy to have to have carved out a space for his own." So I did some research. And I found that there was an historic precedence. Hemingway had his writing space. Elvis had two or three manspaces, which is pretty unique because he lived with both his wife and his mother in Graceland. In the popular culture, Superman had the Fortress of Solitude, and there was, of course, the Batcave.So I realized then that I wanted to go out on a journey and see what guys were creating for themselves now. Here is one of the first spaces I found. It is in Austin, Texas, which is where I'm from. On the outside it looks like a very typical garage, a nice garage. But on the inside, it's anything but. And this, to me, is a pretty classic manspace. It has neon concert posters, a bar and, of course, the leg lamp, which is very important.I soon realized that manspaces didn't have to be only inside. This guy built a bowling alley in his backyard, out of landscaping timbers, astroturf. And he found the scoreboard in the trash.Here's another outdoor space, a little bit more sophisticated. This a 1923 wooden tugboat, made completely out of Douglas fir. The guy did it all himself. And there is about 1,000 square feet of hanging-out space inside.So, pretty early on in my investigations I realized what I was finding was not what I expected to find, which was, quite frankly, a lot of beer can pyramids and overstuffed couches and flat-screen TVs. There were definitely hang-out spots. But some were for working, some were for playing, some were for guys to collect their things. Most of all, I was just surprised with what I was finding.Take this place for example. On the outside it looks like a typical northeastern garage. This is in Long Island, New York. The only thing that might tip you off is the round window. On the inside it's a recreation of a 16th century Japanese tea house. The man imported all the materials from Japan, and he hired a Japanese carpenter to build it in the traditional style. It has no nails or screws. All the joints are hand-carved and hand-scribed.Here is another pretty typical scene. This is a suburban Las Vegas neighborhood. But you open one of the garage doors and there is a professional-size boxing ring inside. (Laughter) And so there is a good reason for this. It was built by this man who is Wayne McCullough. He won the silver medal for Ireland in the 1992 Olympics, and he trains in this space. He trains other people. And right off the garage he has his own trophy room where he can sort of bask in his accomplishments, which is another sort of important part about a manspace.So, while this space represents someone's profession, this one certainly represents a passion. It's made to look like the inside of an English sailing ship. It's a collection of nautical antiques from the 1700s and 1800s. Museum quality.So, as I came to the end of my journey, I found over 50 spaces. And they were unexpected and they were surprising. But they were also — I was really impressed by how personalized they were, and how much work went into them. And I realized that's because the guys that I met were all very passionate about what they did. And they really loved their professions. And they were very passionate about their collections and their hobbies. And so they created these spaces to reflect what they love to do, and who they were.So if you don't have a space of your own, I highly recommend finding one, and getting into it. Thank you very much. (Applause)
