00:06:18.147 --> 00:06:20.574
We're going to go
through four value shifts

00:06:20.598 --> 00:06:22.934
that we see driving
new consumer behaviors,

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.015
that offer new management principles.

00:06:25.039 --> 00:06:26.849
The first cultural value shift we see

00:06:26.873 --> 00:06:29.499
is this tendency toward something
we call "liquid life."

00:06:29.523 --> 00:06:30.673
This is the movement

00:06:30.697 --> 00:06:33.778
from Americans defining
their success on having things

00:06:33.802 --> 00:06:35.084
to having liquidity,

00:06:35.108 --> 00:06:37.800
because the less excess
that you have around you,

00:06:37.824 --> 00:06:39.976
the more nimble and fleet of foot you are.

00:06:40.000 --> 00:06:42.470
As a result, déclassé consumption is in.

00:06:42.494 --> 00:06:46.429
Déclassé consumption is the whole idea
that spending money frivolously

00:06:46.453 --> 00:06:49.191
makes you look a little bit anti-fashion.

00:06:49.215 --> 00:06:51.704
The management principle
is dollars and cents.

00:06:51.728 --> 00:06:54.572
So let's look at some examples
of this déclassé consumption

00:06:54.596 --> 00:06:56.024
that falls out of this value.

00:06:56.048 --> 00:06:58.345
The first thing is,
something must be happening

00:06:58.369 --> 00:07:00.445
when P. Diddy vows to tone down his bling.

00:07:00.469 --> 00:07:01.483
(Laughter)

00:07:01.507 --> 00:07:03.849
But seriously, we also have
this phenomenon

00:07:03.873 --> 00:07:05.798
on Madison Avenue and in other places,

00:07:05.822 --> 00:07:08.745
where people are actually
walking out of luxury boutiques

00:07:08.769 --> 00:07:12.582
with ordinary, generic paper bags
to hide the brand purchases.

00:07:12.606 --> 00:07:15.583
We see high-end haggling in fashion today,

00:07:15.607 --> 00:07:18.084
high-end haggling
for luxury and real estate.

00:07:18.108 --> 00:07:20.480
We also see just a relaxing of ego,

00:07:20.504 --> 00:07:22.756
and sort of a dismantling of artifice.

00:07:22.780 --> 00:07:26.627
This is a story on the yacht club
that's all basically blue collar.

00:07:26.651 --> 00:07:28.825
Blue-collar yacht club --
where you can join,

00:07:28.849 --> 00:07:32.084
but you've got to work in the boatyard
as condition of membership.

00:07:32.108 --> 00:07:36.769
We also see the trend toward tourism
that's a little bit more low-key:

00:07:36.793 --> 00:07:39.920
agritourism -- going to vineyards
and going to farms.

00:07:39.944 --> 00:07:43.569
And then we also see this movement
forward from dollars and cents.

00:07:43.593 --> 00:07:46.308
What businesses can do to connect
with these new mindsets

00:07:46.332 --> 00:07:47.499
is really interesting.

00:07:47.523 --> 00:07:49.368
A couple things that are kind of cool.

00:07:49.392 --> 00:07:53.085
One is that Frito-Lay figured out
this liquidity thing with their consumer.

00:07:53.109 --> 00:07:56.512
They found their consumer had more
money at the beginning of the month,

00:07:56.536 --> 00:07:57.945
less at the end of the month.

00:07:57.969 --> 00:07:59.982
So they started to change their packaging:

00:08:00.006 --> 00:08:02.028
larger packs at the beginning
of the month,

00:08:02.052 --> 00:08:04.072
smaller packaging at the end of the month.

00:08:04.096 --> 00:08:06.815
Really interestingly, too,
was the San Francisco Giants.

00:08:06.839 --> 00:08:09.084
They've just instituted dynamic pricing.

00:08:09.108 --> 00:08:12.327
It takes into account everything
from the pitcher match-ups,

00:08:12.351 --> 00:08:14.194
to the weather, to the team records,

00:08:14.218 --> 00:08:16.622
in setting prices for the consumer.

00:08:16.646 --> 00:08:21.677
Another quick example of these types
of movements is the rise of Zynga.

00:08:21.701 --> 00:08:23.981
Zynga has risen on the consumer's desire

00:08:24.005 --> 00:08:26.017
to not want to be locked in to fixed cost.

00:08:26.041 --> 00:08:28.801
Again, this theme is about variable
cost, variable living.

00:08:28.825 --> 00:08:30.697
So micro-payments have become huge.

00:08:30.721 --> 00:08:33.300
And lastly, some people are using Hulu

00:08:33.324 --> 00:08:35.396
as a device to get rid
of their cable bill.

00:08:35.420 --> 00:08:39.010
So, really clever ideas there
that are being taken ahold of

00:08:39.034 --> 00:08:41.205
and that marketers
are starting to understand.

00:08:41.229 --> 00:08:43.859
The second of the four values
is this movement toward

00:08:43.883 --> 00:08:45.188
ethics and fair play.

00:08:45.212 --> 00:08:48.349
We see that play itself out
with empathy and respect.

00:08:48.373 --> 00:08:49.994
The consumer is demanding it.

00:08:50.018 --> 00:08:53.184
And, as a result, businesses
must provide not only value,

00:08:53.208 --> 00:08:54.360
but values.

00:08:54.384 --> 00:08:57.557
Increasingly, consumers are looking
at the culture of the company,

00:08:57.581 --> 00:08:59.326
at their conduct in the marketplace.

00:08:59.350 --> 00:09:01.018
So we see with empathy and respect

00:09:01.042 --> 00:09:03.838
lots of really hopeful things
come out of this recession.

00:09:03.862 --> 00:09:05.253
I'll give you a few examples.

00:09:05.277 --> 00:09:07.802
One is the rise toward communities
and neighborhoods,

00:09:07.826 --> 00:09:11.540
and increased emphasis on your neighbors
as your support system.

00:09:11.564 --> 00:09:15.611
Also, a wonderful by-product
of a really lousy thing,

00:09:15.635 --> 00:09:17.003
which has been unemployment,

00:09:17.027 --> 00:09:19.828
is a rise in volunteerism
that's been noted in our country.

00:09:19.852 --> 00:09:23.522
We also see the phenomenon --
some of you may have "boomerang kids" --

00:09:23.546 --> 00:09:25.183
these are "boomerang alumni,"

00:09:25.207 --> 00:09:27.940
where universities are actually
reconnecting with alumni

00:09:27.964 --> 00:09:30.745
and helping them with jobs,
sharing skills and retraining.

00:09:30.769 --> 00:09:33.317
We also talked about character
and professionalism.

00:09:33.341 --> 00:09:37.084
We had this miracle on the Hudson
in New York City in January,

00:09:37.108 --> 00:09:41.084
and suddenly Sully has become
a key name on BabyCenter.

00:09:41.108 --> 00:09:42.178
(Laughter)

00:09:42.202 --> 00:09:44.598
So, from a value and values standpoint,

00:09:44.622 --> 00:09:47.575
what companies can do is connect
in lots of different ways.

00:09:47.599 --> 00:09:49.491
Microsoft is doing something wonderful.

00:09:49.515 --> 00:09:53.353
They are actually vowing to retrain
two million Americans with IT training,

00:09:53.377 --> 00:09:56.479
using their existing infrastructure
to do something good.

00:09:56.503 --> 00:09:58.964
Also, a really interesting
company is GORE-TEX.

00:09:58.988 --> 00:10:01.698
GORE-TEX is all about
personal accountability

00:10:01.722 --> 00:10:03.671
of their management and their employees,

00:10:03.695 --> 00:10:07.253
to the point where they really
kind of shun the idea of bosses.

00:10:07.277 --> 00:10:10.042
But they also talk about the fact
that their executives --

00:10:10.066 --> 00:10:13.138
all of their expense reports
are put onto their company intranet

00:10:13.162 --> 00:10:14.341
for everyone to see.

00:10:14.365 --> 00:10:16.084
Complete transparency.

00:10:16.108 --> 00:10:18.384
Think twice before you have
that bottle of wine.

00:10:18.408 --> 00:10:19.465
(Laughter)

00:10:19.489 --> 00:10:22.262
The third of the four laws
of post-crisis consumerism

00:10:22.286 --> 00:10:23.771
is about durable living.

00:10:23.795 --> 00:10:26.332
We're seeing in our data
that consumers are realizing

00:10:26.356 --> 00:10:28.084
this is a marathon, not a sprint.

00:10:28.108 --> 00:10:30.967
They're digging in and looking
for ways to extract value

00:10:30.991 --> 00:10:33.084
out of every purchase they make.

00:10:33.108 --> 00:10:36.023
Witness the fact that Americans
are holding on to their cars

00:10:36.047 --> 00:10:39.909
longer than ever before:
9.4 years on average, in March.

00:10:39.933 --> 00:10:41.084
A record.

00:10:41.108 --> 00:10:45.084
We also see the fact that libraries
have become a huge resource for America.

00:10:45.108 --> 00:10:48.950
Did you know that 68 percent
of Americans now carry a library card?

00:10:48.974 --> 00:10:51.439
The highest percentage ever
in our nation's history.

00:10:51.463 --> 00:10:55.084
So what you see in this trend
is also the accumulation of knowledge.

00:10:55.108 --> 00:10:56.827
Continuing education is up.

00:10:56.851 --> 00:10:59.489
Everything is focused
on betterment, training,

00:10:59.513 --> 00:11:01.298
development and moving forward.

00:11:01.322 --> 00:11:03.859
We also see a big DIY movement.

00:11:04.382 --> 00:11:08.546
I was fascinated to learn that 30 percent
of all homes in America

00:11:08.570 --> 00:11:10.084
are actually built by owners.

00:11:10.108 --> 00:11:11.966
That includes cottages and the like,

00:11:11.990 --> 00:11:13.158
but 30 percent.

00:11:13.182 --> 00:11:16.194
People are getting their hands dirty,
rolling up their sleeves.

00:11:16.218 --> 00:11:17.385
They want these skills.

00:11:17.409 --> 00:11:20.973
We see it with the phenomenon of raising
backyard hens, chickens and ducks.

00:11:20.997 --> 00:11:23.685
And when you work out the math,
they say it doesn't work,

00:11:23.709 --> 00:11:25.009
but the principle is there;

00:11:25.033 --> 00:11:27.748
it's about being sustainable
and taking care of yourself.

00:11:27.772 --> 00:11:30.383
Then we look at the High Line
in New York City,

00:11:30.407 --> 00:11:33.175
an excellent use of reimagining
existing infrastructure

00:11:33.199 --> 00:11:34.358
for something good,

00:11:34.382 --> 00:11:36.417
which is a brand-new park
in New York City.

00:11:36.441 --> 00:11:40.532
So what brands can do, and companies,
is pay dividends to consumers,

00:11:40.556 --> 00:11:42.084
be a brand that lasts,

00:11:42.108 --> 00:11:43.497
offer transparency,

00:11:43.521 --> 00:11:46.015
promise you're going to be there
beyond today's sale.

00:11:46.039 --> 00:11:48.084
Perfect example of that is Patagonia.

00:11:48.108 --> 00:11:49.822
Patagonia's "Footprint Chronicles"

00:11:49.846 --> 00:11:53.644
basically goes through and tracks
every product they make,

00:11:53.668 --> 00:11:55.458
and gives you social responsibility,

00:11:55.482 --> 00:11:59.021
and helps you understand the ethics
behind the product they make.

00:11:59.045 --> 00:12:00.827
Another great example is Fidelity.

00:12:00.851 --> 00:12:04.537
Rather than instant cash-back rewards
on your credit or debit purchases,

00:12:04.561 --> 00:12:09.457
this is about 529 rewards
for your student education.

00:12:09.481 --> 00:12:11.568
Or the interesting company Sunrun.

00:12:11.592 --> 00:12:12.747
I love this company.

00:12:12.771 --> 00:12:14.838
They've created a consumer collective

00:12:14.862 --> 00:12:17.208
where they put solar panels on households

00:12:17.232 --> 00:12:19.327
and create a consumer-based utility,

00:12:19.351 --> 00:12:21.049
where the electricity they generate

00:12:21.073 --> 00:12:23.697
is basically pumped back out
into the marketplace.

00:12:23.721 --> 00:12:25.457
So it's a consumer-driven co-op.

00:12:25.481 --> 00:12:29.155
The fourth post-crisis
consumerism that we see

00:12:29.179 --> 00:12:31.496
is this movement
about "return to the fold."

00:12:31.520 --> 00:12:33.319
It's incredibly important right now.

00:12:33.343 --> 00:12:35.927
Trust is not parceled out, as we all know.

00:12:35.951 --> 00:12:38.143
It's now about connecting
to your communities,

00:12:38.167 --> 00:12:39.929
connecting to your social networks.

00:12:39.953 --> 00:12:41.667
In my book, I talked about the fact

00:12:41.691 --> 00:12:44.366
that 72 percent of people trust
what other people say

00:12:44.390 --> 00:12:45.841
about a brand or a company,

00:12:45.865 --> 00:12:47.907
versus 15 percent on advertising.

00:12:47.931 --> 00:12:51.651
So in that respect, cooperative
consumerism has really taken off.

00:12:51.675 --> 00:12:54.658
This is about consumers working
together to get what they want

00:12:54.682 --> 00:12:55.858
out of the marketplace.

00:12:55.882 --> 00:12:57.859
Let's look at a couple of quick examples.

00:12:57.883 --> 00:12:59.456
The artisanal movement is huge:

00:12:59.480 --> 00:13:02.537
everything about locally
derived products and services,

00:13:02.561 --> 00:13:04.345
supporting your local neighborhoods,

00:13:04.369 --> 00:13:07.345
whether it's cheeses,
wines and other products.

00:13:07.369 --> 00:13:10.027
Also this rise of local currencies.

00:13:10.051 --> 00:13:13.026
Realizing that it's difficult
to get loans in this environment,

00:13:13.050 --> 00:13:15.109
you're doing business
with people you trust

00:13:15.133 --> 00:13:16.312
in your local markets.

00:13:16.336 --> 00:13:20.204
So this rise of local currency
is another really interesting phenomenon.

00:13:20.228 --> 00:13:23.850
And then they did a recent report
I thought was fascinating.

00:13:23.874 --> 00:13:27.047
They actually started, in certain
communities in the United States,

00:13:27.071 --> 00:13:29.098
to publish people's electricity usage.

00:13:29.122 --> 00:13:32.433
And what they found out is when
that was available for public record,

00:13:32.457 --> 00:13:35.527
the people's electricity usage
in those communities dropped.

00:13:36.469 --> 00:13:39.084
Then we also look
at the idea of cow-pooling,

00:13:39.108 --> 00:13:43.303
which is the whole phenomenon
of consumers organizing together

00:13:43.327 --> 00:13:47.220
to buy meat from organic farms,
that they know is safe and controlled

00:13:47.244 --> 00:13:49.430
in the way that they want it
to be controlled.

00:13:49.454 --> 00:13:53.021
And then there's this other really
interesting movement in California,

00:13:53.045 --> 00:13:54.528
which is about carrot mobs.

00:13:54.552 --> 00:13:57.598
The traditional thing would be
to boycott, right? Have a stick.

00:13:57.622 --> 00:13:58.968
Well, why not have a carrot?

00:13:58.992 --> 00:14:02.296
So these are consumers organizing,
pooling their resources

00:14:02.320 --> 00:14:05.084
to incentify companies to do good.

00:14:05.108 --> 00:14:07.905
And then we look at what companies can do.

00:14:07.929 --> 00:14:11.382
This is all the opportunity
about being a community organizer.

00:14:11.406 --> 00:14:14.373
You have to realize
that you can't fight and control this.

00:14:14.397 --> 00:14:16.007
You actually need to organize it.

00:14:16.031 --> 00:14:18.556
You need to harness it.
You need to give it meaning.

00:14:18.580 --> 00:14:21.792
And there's lots of really
interesting examples here.

00:14:21.816 --> 00:14:26.609
First is just the rise of the fact
that Zagat's has actually moved out of

00:14:26.633 --> 00:14:28.861
and diversified from rating restaurants,

00:14:28.885 --> 00:14:31.084
into actually rating health care.

00:14:31.108 --> 00:14:33.237
So what credentials does Zagat's have?

00:14:33.261 --> 00:14:34.431
Well, they have a lot,

00:14:34.455 --> 00:14:36.299
because it's their network of people.

00:14:36.323 --> 00:14:38.866
So that becomes
a very powerful force for them

00:14:38.890 --> 00:14:41.084
to make their brand more elastic.

00:14:41.108 --> 00:14:43.365
Then you look at the phenomenon of Kogi.

00:14:43.894 --> 00:14:46.871
This Kogi doesn't exist.
It's a moving truck.

00:14:46.895 --> 00:14:48.494
It's a moving truck through L.A.,

00:14:48.518 --> 00:14:51.014
and the only way you can find it
is through Twitter.

00:14:51.038 --> 00:14:52.095
(Laughter)

00:14:52.119 --> 00:14:53.272
Or you look at

00:14:53.296 --> 00:14:58.358
Johnson & Johnson's "Momversations,"
a phenomenal blog that's been built up,

00:14:58.382 --> 00:15:02.512
where J&J basically is tapping
into the power of mommy bloggers,

00:15:02.536 --> 00:15:06.984
allowing them to create a forum
where they can communicate and connect.

00:15:07.008 --> 00:15:11.847
And it's also become a very valuable
advertising revenue for J&J as well.

00:15:11.871 --> 00:15:16.085
This, plus the fact that you've got
phenomenal work from CEOs,

00:15:16.109 --> 00:15:18.649
from Ford to Zappos,
connecting on Twitter,

00:15:18.673 --> 00:15:20.084
creating an open environment,

00:15:20.108 --> 00:15:23.146
allowing their employees
to be part of the process,

00:15:23.170 --> 00:15:24.878
rather than hidden behind walls.

00:15:24.902 --> 00:15:29.107
You see this rising force
in total transparency and openness

00:15:29.131 --> 00:15:30.919
that companies are starting to adopt,

00:15:30.943 --> 00:15:33.250
all because the consumer is demanding it.

00:15:33.274 --> 00:15:35.220
So when we look at this and step back,

00:15:35.244 --> 00:15:39.436
what I believe is that the crisis
that exists today is definitely real.

00:15:39.460 --> 00:15:42.084
It's been tremendously
powerful for consumers.

00:15:42.108 --> 00:15:45.671
But at the same time,
this is also a tremendous opportunity.

00:15:45.695 --> 00:15:49.162
The Chinese character for crisis
is actually the same side

00:15:49.186 --> 00:15:50.353
of the same coin.

00:15:50.377 --> 00:15:52.084
Crisis equals opportunity.

00:15:52.108 --> 00:15:55.602
What we're seeing with consumers
right now is the ability for them

00:15:55.626 --> 00:15:58.262
to actually lead us forward
out of this recession.

00:15:58.286 --> 00:16:03.084
So we believe that values-driven spending
will force capitalism to be better:

00:16:03.108 --> 00:16:04.988
it will drive innovation;

00:16:05.012 --> 00:16:07.113
it will make longer-lasting products;

00:16:07.137 --> 00:16:09.733
it will create better,
more intuitive customer service;

00:16:09.757 --> 00:16:12.634
and it will give us the opportunity
to connect with companies

00:16:12.658 --> 00:16:14.729
that share the values that we share.

00:16:14.753 --> 00:16:16.772
So when we look back and step out at this

00:16:16.796 --> 00:16:20.084
and see the beginning of these trends
that we're seeing in our data,

00:16:20.108 --> 00:16:22.957
we see a very hopeful picture
for the future of America.

00:16:22.981 --> 00:16:24.149
Thank you very much.

00:16:24.173 --> 00:16:25.989
(Applause)

title: Animating a photo-real digital face
transcript: One of the biggest challenges in computer graphics has been being able to create a photo-real, digital human face. And one of the reasons it is so difficult is that, unlike aliens and dinosaurs, we look at human faces every day. They are very important to how we communicate with each other. As a result, we're tuned in to the subtlest things that could possibly be wrong with a computer rendering, in order to believe whether these things are realistic.And what I'm going to do in the next five minutes is take you through a process where we tried to create a reasonably photo-realistic computer-generated face, using some computer graphics technology we've developed, and also some collaborators at a company called Image Metrics. And we're going to try to do a photo-real face of an actress named Emily O'Brien, who is right there. And that's actually a completely computer-generated rendering of her face. By the end of the talk, we're going to see it move.The way that we did this is we tried to start with Emily herself, who was gracious enough to come to our laboratory in Marina Del Rey, and sit for a session in Light Stage 5. This is a face-scanning sphere, with 156 white LEDs all around that allow us to photograph her in a series of very controlled illumination conditions. And the lighting that we use these days looks something like this. We shoot all of these photographs in about three seconds.And we basically capture enough information with video projector patterns that drape over the contours of her face, and different principle directions of light from the light stage, to figure out both the coarse-scale and the fine-scale detail of her face. If we zoom in on this photograph right here, we can see it's a really nice photograph to have of her, because she is lit from absolutely everywhere at the same time to get a nice image of her facial texture.And in addition, we've actually used polarizers on all the lights — just like polarized sunglasses can block the glare off of the road, polarizers can block the shine off of the skin, so we don't get all those specular reflections to take this map. Now, if we turn the polarizers around just a little bit, we can actually bring that specular reflection of the skin back in, and you can see she looks kind of shiny and oily at this point. If you take the difference between these two images here, you can get an image lit from the entire sphere of light of just the shine off of Emily's skin.I don't think any photograph like this had ever been taken before we had done this. And this is very important light to capture, because this is the light that reflects off the first surface of the skin. It doesn't get underneath the translucent layers of the skin and blur out. And, as a result, it's a very good cue to the detailed shape of the skin-pore structure and all of the fine wrinkles that all of us have, the things that actually make us look like real humans.So, if we use information that comes off of this specular reflection, we can go from a traditional face scan that might have the gross contours of the face and the basic shape, and augment it with information that puts in all of that skin pore structure and fine wrinkles. And, even more importantly, since this is a photometric process that only takes three seconds to capture, we can shoot Emily in just part of an afternoon, in many different facial poses and facial expressions.So, here you can see her moving her eyes around, moving her mouth around. And these we're actually going to use to create a photo-real digital character. If you take a look at these scans that we have of Emily, you can see that the human face does an enormous amount of amazing things as it goes into different facial expressions. You can see things. Not only the face shape changes, but all sorts of different skin buckling and skin wrinkling occurs. You can see that the skin pore structure changes enormously from stretched skin pores to the regular skin texture. You can see the furrows in the brow and how the microstructure changes there. You can see muscles pulling down at flesh to bring her eyebrows down. Her muscles bulging in her forehead when she winces like that.In addition to this kind of high-resolution geometry, since it's all captured with cameras, we've got a great texture map to use for the face. And by looking at how the different color channels of the illumination, the red and the green and the blue, diffuse the light differently, we can come up with a way of shading the skin on the computer. 00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
One of the biggest challenges in computer graphics

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
has been being able to create a photo-real,

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
digital human face.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
And one of the reasons it is so difficult is that, unlike aliens and dinosaurs,

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:24.958
we look at human faces every day.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
They are very important to how we communicate with each other.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
As a result, we're tuned in to the subtlest things

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
that could possibly be wrong with a computer rendering,

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:34.958
in order to believe whether these things are realistic.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
And what I'm going to do in the next five minutes

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
is take you through a process

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:41.958
where we tried to create a reasonably photo-realistic computer-generated face,

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
using some computer graphics technology we've developed,

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:46.958
and also some collaborators at a company called Image Metrics.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
And we're going to try to do a photo-real face

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
of an actress named Emily O'Brien, who is right there.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:54.958
And that's actually a completely computer-generated rendering of her face.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
By the end of the talk, we're going to see it move.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
The way that we did this is we tried to start with Emily herself,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
who was gracious enough to come to our laboratory

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
in Marina Del Rey, and sit for a session in Light Stage 5.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:09.958
This is a face-scanning sphere, with 156 white LEDs all around

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
that allow us to photograph her

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
in a series of very controlled illumination conditions.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
And the lighting that we use these days looks something like this.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
We shoot all of these photographs in about three seconds.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.958
And we basically capture enough information

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:26.958
with video projector patterns that drape over the contours of her face,

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
and different principle directions of light from the light stage,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
to figure out both the coarse-scale

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
and the fine-scale detail of her face.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
If we zoom in on this photograph right here,

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
we can see it's a really nice photograph to have of her,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:40.958
because she is lit from absolutely everywhere at the same time

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
to get a nice image of her facial texture.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:45.958
And in addition, we've actually used polarizers on all the lights --

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
just like polarized sunglasses can block

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
the glare off of the road,

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
polarizers can block the shine off of the skin,

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
so we don't get all those specular reflections to take this map.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
Now, if we turn the polarizers around just a little bit,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
we can actually bring that specular reflection

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
of the skin back in,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
and you can see she looks kind of shiny and oily at this point.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
If you take the difference between these two images here,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
you can get an image lit from the entire sphere of light

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:11.958
of just the shine off of Emily's skin.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
I don't think any photograph like this had ever been taken

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
before we had done this.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
And this is very important light to capture,

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
because this is the light that reflects off the first surface of the skin.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
It doesn't get underneath the translucent

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
layers of the skin and blur out.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
And, as a result, it's a very good cue

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:29.958
to the detailed shape of the skin-pore structure

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
and all of the fine wrinkles that all of us have,

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
the things that actually make us look like real humans.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:37.958
So, if we use information that comes off of this specular reflection,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
we can go from a traditional face scan

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.958
that might have the gross contours of the face and the basic shape,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.958
and augment it with information

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
that puts in all of that skin pore structure and fine wrinkles.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
And, even more importantly,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
since this is a photometric process that only takes three seconds to capture,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
we can shoot Emily

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
in just part of an afternoon,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
in many different facial poses and facial expressions.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
So, here you can see her moving her eyes around, moving her mouth around.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
And these we're actually going to use to create a photo-real digital character.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:10.958
If you take a look at these scans that we have of Emily,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
you can see that the human face does an enormous amount of amazing things

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
as it goes into different facial expressions.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
You can see things. Not only the face shape changes,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:23.958
but all sorts of different skin buckling and skin wrinkling occurs.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:27.958
You can see that the skin pore structure changes enormously

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.958
from stretched skin pores

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
to the regular skin texture.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
You can see the furrows in the brow and how the microstructure changes there.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:38.958
You can see muscles pulling down at flesh to bring her eyebrows down.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.958
Her muscles bulging in her forehead when she winces like that.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
In addition to this kind of high-resolution geometry,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:48.958
since it's all captured with cameras, we've got a great texture map to use for the face.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
And by looking at how the different color channels of the illumination,

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
the red and the green and the blue,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
diffuse the light differently,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:57.958
we can come up with a way of shading the skin on the computer.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
Then, instead of looking like a plaster mannequin,

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
it actually looks like it's made out of living human flesh.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
And this is what we used

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
to give to the company Image Metrics

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
to create a rigged, digital version of Emily.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
We're just seeing the coarse-scale geometry here.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
But they basically created a digital puppet of her,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
where you can pull on these various strings,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
and it actually moves her face in ways that are

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
completely consistent with the scans that we took.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
And, in addition to the coarse-scale geometry,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
they also used all of that detail

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
to create a set of what are called "displacement maps"

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
that animate as well.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
These are the displacement maps here.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
And you can see those different wrinkles actually show up as she animates.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
So the next process was then to animate her.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:42.958
We actually used one of her own performances to provide the source data.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
So, by analyzing this video with computer vision techniques,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
they were able to drive the facial rig

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
with the computer-generated performance.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
So what you're going to see now, after this,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
is a completely photo-real digital face.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
We can turn the volume up a little bit if that's available.

title: Lead like the great conductors
transcript: The magical moment, the magical moment of conducting. Which is, you go onto a stage. There is an orchestra sitting. They are all, you know, warming up and doing stuff. And I go on the podium. You know, this little office of the conductor. Or rather a cubicle, an open-space cubicle, with a lot of space. And in front of all that noise, you do a very small gesture. Something like this, not very pomp, not very sophisticated, this. And suddenly, out of the chaos, order. Noise becomes music.And this is fantastic. And it's so tempting to think that it's all about me. (Laughter) All those great people here, virtuosos, they make noise, they need me to do that. Not really. If it were that, I would just save you the talk, and teach you the gesture. So you could go out to the world and do this thing in whatever company or whatever you want, and you have perfect harmony. It doesn't work. Let's look at the first video. I hope you'll think it's a good example of harmony. And then speak a little bit about how it comes about.(Music)Was that nice? So that was a sort of a success. Now, who should we thank for the success? I mean, obviously the orchestra musicians playing beautifully, the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra. They don't often even look at the conductor. Then you have the clapping audience, yeah, actually taking part in doing the music. You know Viennese audiences usually don't interfere with the music. This is the closest to an Oriental bellydancing feast that you will ever get in Vienna. (Laughter)Unlike, for example Israel, where audiences cough all the time. You know, Arthur Rubinstein, the pianist, used to say that, "Anywhere in the world, people that have the flu, they go to the doctor. In Tel Aviv they come to my concerts." (Laughter) So that's a sort of a tradition. But Viennese audiences do not do that. Here they go out of their regular, just to be part of that, to become part of the orchestra, and that's great. You know, audiences like you, yeah, make the event.But what about the conductor? What can you say the conductor was doing, actually? Um, he was happy. And I often show this to senior management. People get annoyed. "You come to work. How come you're so happy?" Something must be wrong there, yeah? But he's spreading happiness. And I think the happiness, the important thing is this happiness does not come from only his own story and his joy of the music. The joy is about enabling other people's stories to be heard at the same time.You have the story of the orchestra as a professional body. You have the story of the audience as a community. Yeah. You have the stories of the individuals in the orchestra and in the audience. And then you have other stories, unseen. People who build this wonderful concert hall. People who made those Stradivarius, Amati, all those beautiful instruments. And all those stories are being heard at the same time. This is the true experience of a live concert. That's a reason to go out of home. Yeah? And not all conductors do just that. Let's see somebody else, a great conductor. Riccardo Muti, please.(Music)Yeah, that was very short, but you could see it's a completely different figure. Right? He's awesome. He's so commanding. Yeah? So clear. Maybe a little bit over-clear. Can we have a little demonstration? Would you be my orchestra for a second? Can you sing, please, the first note of Don Giovanni? You have to sing "Aaaaaah," and I'll stop you. Okay? Ready?Audience: ♫ Aaaaaaah ... ♫Itay Talgam: Come on, with me. If you do it without me I feel even more redundant than I already feel. So please, wait for the conductor. Now look at me. "Aaaaaah," and I stop you. Let's go.Audience: ♫ ... Aaaaaaaah ... ♫ (Laughter)Itay Talgam: So we'll have a little chat later. (Laughter) But ... There is a vacancy for a ... But — (Laughter) — you could see that you could stop an orchestra with a finger. Now what does Riccardo Muti do? He does something like this ... (Laughter) And then — sort of — (Laughter) So not only the instruction is clear, but also the sanction, what will happen if you don't do what I tell you. (Laughter) So, does it work? Yes, it works — to a certain point.When Muti is asked, "Why do you conduct like this?" He says, "I'm responsible." Responsible in front of him. No he doesn't really mean Him. He means Mozart, which is — (Laughter) — like a third seat from the center. (Laughter) So he says, "If I'm — (Applause) if I'm responsible for Mozart, this is going to be the only story to be told. It's Mozart as I, Riccardo Muti, understand it."And you know what happened to Muti? Three years ago he got a letter signed by all 700 employees of La Scala, musical employees, I mean the musicians, saying, "You're a great conductor. We don't want to work with you. Please resign." (Laughter) "Why? Because you don't let us develop. You're using us as instruments, not as partners. And our joy of music, etc., etc. ..." So he had to resign. Isn't that nice? (Laughter) He's a nice guy. He's a really nice guy. Well, can you do it with less control, or with a different kind of control? Let's look at the next conductor, Richard Strauss.(Music)I'm afraid you'll get the feeling that I really picked on him because he's old. It's not true. When he was a young man of about 30, he wrote what he called "The Ten Commandments for Conductors." The first one was: If you sweat by the end of the concert it means that you must have done something wrong. That's the first one. The fourth one you'll like better. It says: Never look at the trombones — it only encourages them. (Laughter)So, the whole idea is really to let it happen by itself. Do not interfere. But how does it happen? Did you see him turning pages in the score? Now, either he is senile, and doesn't remember his own music, because he wrote the music. Or he is actually transferring a very strong message to them, saying, "Come on guys. You have to play by the book. So it's not about my story. It's not about your story. It's only the execution of the written music, no interpretation." Interpretation is the real story of the performer. So, no, he doesn't want that. That's a different kind of control. Let's see another super-conductor, a German super-conductor. Herbert von Karajan, please.(Music)What's different? Did you see the eyes? Closed. Did you see the hands? Did you see this kind of movement? Let me conduct you. Twice. Once like a Muti, and you'll — (Claps) — clap, just once. And then like Karajan. Let's see what happens. Okay? Like Muti. You ready? Because Muti ... (Laughter) Okay? Ready? Let's do it.Audience: (Claps)Itay Talgam: Hmm ... again.Audience: (Claps) Itay Talgam: Good. Now like a Karajan. Since you're already trained, let me concentrate, close my eyes. Come, come.Audience: (Claps) (Laughter)Itay Talgam: Why not together? (Laughter) Because you didn't know when to play. Now I can tell you, even the Berlin Philharmonic doesn't know when to play. (Laughter) But I'll tell you how they do it. No cynicism. This is a German orchestra, yes? They look at Karajan. And then they look at each other. (Laughter) "Do you understand what this guy wants?" And after doing that, they really look at each other, and the first players of the orchestra lead the whole ensemble in playing together.And when Karajan is asked about it he actually says, "Yes, the worst damage I can do to my orchestra is to give them a clear instruction. Because that would prevent the ensemble, the listening to each other that is needed for an orchestra." Now that's great. What about the eyes? Why are the eyes closed? There is a wonderful story about Karajan conducting in London. And he cues in a flute player like this. The guy has no idea what to do. (Laughter) "Maestro, with all due respect, when should I start?" What do you think Karajan's reply was? When should I start? Oh yeah. He says, "You start when you can't stand it anymore." (Laughter)Meaning that you know you have no authority to change anything. It's my music. The real music is only in Karajan's head. And you have to guess my mind. So you are under tremendous pressure because I don't give you instruction, and yet, you have to guess my mind. So it's a different kind of, a very spiritual but yet very firm control. Can we do it in another way? Of course we can. Let's go back to the first conductor we've seen: Carlos Kleiber, his name. Next video, please.(Music)(Laughter) Yeah. Well, it is different. But isn't that controlling in the same way? No, it's not, because he is not telling them what to do. When he does this, it's not, "Take your Stradivarius and like Jimi Hendrix, smash it on the floor." It's not that. He says, "This is the gesture of the music. I'm opening a space for you to put in another layer of interpretation." That is another story.But how does it really work together if it doesn't give them instructions? It's like being on a rollercoaster. Yeah? You're not really given any instructions, but the forces of the process itself keep you in place. That's what he does. The interesting thing is of course the rollercoaster does not really exist. It's not a physical thing. It's in the players' heads.And that's what makes them into partners. You have the plan in your head. You know what to do, even though Kleiber is not conducting you. But here and there and that. You know what to do. And you become a partner building the rollercoaster, yeah, with sound, as you actually take the ride. This is very exciting for those players. They do need to go to a sanatorium for two weeks, later. (Laughter) It is very tiring. Yeah? But it's the best music making, like this.But of course it's not only about motivation and giving them a lot of physical energy. You also have to be very professional. And look again at this Kleiber. Can we have the next video, quickly? You'll see what happens when there is a mistake.(Music) Again you see the beautiful body language. (Music) And now there is a trumpet player who does something not exactly the way it should be done. Go along with the video. Look. See, second time for the same player. (Laughter) And now the third time for the same player. (Laughter) "Wait for me after the concert. I have a short notice to give you." You know, when it's needed, the authority is there. It's very important. But authority is not enough to make people your partners.Let's see the next video, please. See what happens here. You might be surprised having seen Kleiber as such a hyperactive guy. He's conducting Mozart. (Music) The whole orchestra is playing. (Music) Now something else. (Music) See? He is there 100 percent, but not commanding, not telling what to do. Rather enjoying what the soloist is doing. (Music)Another solo now. See what you can pick up from this. (Music) Look at the eyes. Okay. You see that? First of all, it's a kind of a compliment we all like to get. It's not feedback. It's an "Mmmm ..." Yeah, it comes from here. So that's a good thing. And the second thing is it's about actually being in control, but in a very special way. When Kleiber does — did you see the eyes, going from here? (Singing) You know what happens? Gravitation is no more.Kleiber not only creates a process, but also creates the conditions in the world in which this process takes place. So again, the oboe player is completely autonomous and therefore happy and proud of his work, and creative and all of that. And the level in which Kleiber is in control is in a different level. So control is no longer a zero-sum game. You have this control. You have this control. And all you put together, in partnership, brings about the best music. So Kleiber is about process. Kleiber is about conditions in the world.But you need to have process and content to create the meaning. Lenny Bernstein, my own personal maestro. Since he was a great teacher, Lenny Bernstein always started from the meaning. Look at this, please.(Music)Do you remember the face of Muti, at the beginning? Well he had a wonderful expression, but only one. (Laughter) Did you see Lenny's face? You know why? Because the meaning of the music is pain. And you're playing a painful sound. And you look at Lenny and he's suffering. But not in a way that you want to stop. It's suffering, like, enjoying himself in a Jewish way, as they say. (Laughter) But you can see the music on his face. You can see the baton left his hand. No more baton. Now it's about you, the player, telling the story. Now it's a reversed thing. You're telling the story. And you're telling the story. And even briefly, you become the storyteller to which the community, the whole community, listens to. And Bernstein enables that. Isn't that wonderful?Now, if you are doing all the things we talked about, together, and maybe some others, you can get to this wonderful point of doing without doing. And for the last video, I think this is simply the best title. My friend Peter says, "If you love something, give it away." So, please.(Music)(Applause)

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
with a lot of space.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
And in front of all that noise,

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
you do a very small gesture.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:40.958
Something like this, not very pomp, not very sophisticated, this.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:43.958
And suddenly, out of the chaos, order.

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
Noise becomes music.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
And this is fantastic. And it's so tempting

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
to think that it's all about me.

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:51.958
(Laughter)

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
All those great people here, virtuosos,

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
they make noise, they need me to do that.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
Not really. If it were that,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
I would just save you the talk,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
and teach you the gesture.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
So you could go out to the world

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:06.958
and do this thing in whatever company or whatever you want,

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
and you have perfect harmony. It doesn't work.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
Let's look at the first video.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
I hope you'll think it's a good example of harmony.

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:17.958
And then speak a little bit about how it comes about.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:21.958
(Music)

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
Was that nice?

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
So that was a sort of a success.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
Now, who should we thank for the success?

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
I mean, obviously the orchestra musicians

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
playing beautifully,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:29.958
the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
They don't often even look at the conductor.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
Then you have the clapping audience, yeah,

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
actually taking part in doing the music.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:40.958
You know Viennese audiences usually don't interfere with the music.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:44.958
This is the closest to an Oriental bellydancing feast

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
that you will ever get in Vienna.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:47.958
(Laughter)

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
Unlike, for example Israel, where audiences cough all the time.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
You know, Arthur Rubinstein, the pianist, used to say

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
that, "Anywhere in the world, people that have the flu, they go to the doctor.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:59.958
In Tel Aviv they come to my concerts."

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:00.958
(Laughter)

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
So that's a sort of a tradition.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
But Viennese audiences do not do that.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:09.958
Here they go out of their regular, just to be part of that,

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
to become part of the orchestra, and that's great.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
You know, audiences like you, yeah,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
make the event.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
But what about the conductor? What can you say

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:22.958
the conductor was doing, actually?

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
Um, he was happy.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
And I often show this to senior management.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
People get annoyed.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
"You come to work. How come you're so happy?"

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
Something must be wrong there, yeah? But he's spreading happiness.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
And I think the happiness, the important thing is this happiness

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
does not come from

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
only his own story and his joy of the music.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:47.958
The joy is about enabling other people's stories

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
to be heard at the same time.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:53.958
You have the story of the orchestra as a professional body.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
You have the story of the audience as a community. Yeah.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
You have the stories of the individuals

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
in the orchestra and in the audience.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
And then you have other stories, unseen.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
People who build this wonderful concert hall.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:11.958
People who made those Stradivarius, Amati, all those beautiful instruments.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
And all those stories are being heard at the same time.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
This is the true experience of a live concert.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
That's a reason to go out of home. Yeah?

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
And not all conductors do just that.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
Let's see somebody else, a great conductor.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
Riccardo Muti, please.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:31.958
(Music)

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
Yeah, that was very short, but you could see

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
it's a completely different figure. Right?

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
He's awesome. He's so commanding. Yeah?

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:14.958
So clear. Maybe a little bit over-clear.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
Can we have a little demonstration? Would you be my orchestra for a second?

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
Can you sing, please, the first note of Don Giovanni?

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
You have to sing "Aaaaaah," and I'll stop you.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
Okay? Ready?

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
Audience: ♫ Aaaaaaah ... ♫

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
Itay Talgam: Come on, with me. If you do it without me

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
I feel even more redundant than I already feel.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
So please, wait for the conductor.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
Now look at me. "Aaaaaah," and I stop you. Let's go.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.958
Audience: ♫ ... Aaaaaaaah ... ♫

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
(Laughter)

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
Itay Talgam: So we'll have a little chat later.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:46.958
(Laughter)

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:50.958
But ... There is a vacancy for a ...

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:54.958
But -- (Laughter)

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
-- you could see that you could stop an orchestra with a finger.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
Now what does Riccardo Muti do? He does something like this ...

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:03.958
(Laughter)

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
And then -- sort of -- (Laughter)

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
So not only the instruction is clear,

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
but also the sanction, what will happen if you don't do what I tell you.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
(Laughter)

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
So, does it work? Yes, it works --

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
to a certain point.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
When Muti is asked, "Why do you conduct like this?"

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
He says, "I'm responsible."

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
Responsible in front of him.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
No he doesn't really mean Him. He means Mozart,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:33.958
which is -- (Laughter) -- like a third seat from the center.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:34.958
(Laughter)

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
So he says, "If I'm --

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
(Applause)

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
if I'm responsible for Mozart,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
this is going to be the only story to be told.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:46.958
It's Mozart as I, Riccardo Muti, understand it."

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
And you know what happened to Muti?

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
Three years ago he got a letter signed by

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
all 700 employees of La Scala,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
musical employees, I mean the musicians,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:59.958
saying, "You're a great conductor. We don't want to work with you. Please resign."

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:00.958
(Laughter)

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
"Why? Because you don't let us develop.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
You're using us as instruments, not as partners.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
And our joy of music, etc., etc. ..."

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
So he had to resign. Isn't that nice?

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
(Laughter)

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
He's a nice guy. He's a really nice guy.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
Well, can you do it with less control,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
or with a different kind of control?

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
Let's look at the next conductor, Richard Strauss.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
(Music)

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:58.958
I'm afraid you'll get the feeling that I really picked on him because he's old.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
It's not true. When he was a young man

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
of about 30, he wrote what he called

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
"The Ten Commandments for Conductors."

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
The first one was: If you sweat by the end of the concert

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
it means that you must have done something wrong.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
That's the first one. The fourth one you'll like better.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
It says: Never look at the trombones --

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
it only encourages them.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:21.958
(Laughter)

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
So, the whole idea is really to let

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
it happen by itself.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
Do not interfere.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
But how does it happen? Did you see

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
him turning pages in the score?

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
Now, either he is senile,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
and doesn't remember his own music, because he wrote the music.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
Or he is actually transferring a very strong message to them, saying,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
"Come on guys. You have to play by the book.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
So it's not about my story. It's not about your story.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
It's only the execution of the written music,

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
no interpretation."

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
Interpretation is the real story of the performer.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
So, no, he doesn't want that. That's a different kind of control.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
Let's see another super-conductor,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
a German super-conductor. Herbert von Karajan, please.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:07.958
(Music)

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
What's different? Did you see the eyes? Closed.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
Did you see the hands?

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
Did you see this kind of movement? Let me conduct you. Twice.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
Once like a Muti, and you'll -- (Claps) -- clap, just once.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
And then like Karajan. Let's see what happens. Okay?

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
Like Muti. You ready? Because Muti ...

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
(Laughter) Okay? Ready? Let's do it.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:56.958
Audience: (Claps)

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
Itay Talgam: Hmm ... again.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Audience: (Claps)

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
Itay Talgam: Good. Now like a Karajan. Since you're already trained,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
let me concentrate, close my eyes. Come, come.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
Audience: (Claps) (Laughter)

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Itay Talgam: Why not together? (Laughter)

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
Because you didn't know when to play.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
Now I can tell you, even the Berlin Philharmonic

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
doesn't know when to play.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:18.958
(Laughter)

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
But I'll tell you how they do it. No cynicism.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
This is a German orchestra, yes?

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:26.958
They look at Karajan. And then they look at each other.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
(Laughter)

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
"Do you understand what this guy wants?"

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
And after doing that,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
they really look at each other, and the first players of the orchestra

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
lead the whole ensemble in playing together.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
And when Karajan is asked about it

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
he actually says, "Yes, the worst damage

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
I can do to my orchestra

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:49.958
is to give them a clear instruction.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
Because that would

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:55.958
prevent the ensemble, the listening to each other

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
that is needed for an orchestra."

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
Now that's great. What about the eyes?

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
Why are the eyes closed?

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:05.958
There is a wonderful story about Karajan conducting in London.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
And he cues in a flute player like this.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
The guy has no idea what to do. (Laughter)

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
"Maestro, with all due respect, when should I start?"

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
What do you think Karajan's reply was? When should I start?

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
Oh yeah. He says, "You start when you can't stand it anymore."

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
(Laughter)

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:29.958
Meaning that you know you have no authority to change anything.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:33.958
It's my music. The real music is only in Karajan's head.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
And you have to guess my mind. So you are under tremendous pressure

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
because I don't give you instruction,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
and yet, you have to guess my mind.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
So it's a different kind of, a very spiritual but yet

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
very firm control.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
Can we do it in another way? Of course we can. Let's go back

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
to the first conductor we've seen:

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
Carlos Kleiber, his name. Next video, please.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
(Music)

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
(Laughter) Yeah.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
Well, it is different. But isn't that controlling in the same way?

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
No, it's not, because he is not telling them what to do.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
When he does this, it's not,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
"Take your Stradivarius and like Jimi Hendrix,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
smash it on the floor." It's not that.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
He says, "This is the gesture of the music.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
I'm opening a space for you

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
to put in another layer

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
of interpretation."

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
That is another story.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
But how does it really work together

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
if it doesn't give them instructions?

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
It's like being on a rollercoaster. Yeah?

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
You're not really given any instructions,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:26.958
but the forces of the process itself keep you in place.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
That's what he does.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
The interesting thing is of course the rollercoaster does not really exist.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
It's not a physical thing. It's in the players' heads.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
And that's what makes them into partners.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
You have the plan in your head.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
You know what to do, even though Kleiber is not conducting you.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
But here and there and that. You know what to do.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
And you become a partner building the rollercoaster,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
yeah, with sound,

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
as you actually take the ride.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
This is very exciting for those players.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
They do need to go to a sanatorium for two weeks, later.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:58.958
(Laughter)

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
It is very tiring. Yeah?

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.958
But it's the best music making, like this.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
But of course it's not only about motivation

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
and giving them a lot of physical energy.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
You also have to be very professional.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
And look again at this Kleiber.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
Can we have the next video, quickly?

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.958
You'll see what happens when there is a mistake.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
(Music) Again you see the beautiful body language.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
(Music)

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
And now there is a trumpet player who

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
does something not exactly the way it should be done.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
Go along with the video. Look.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:43.958
See, second time for the same player.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
(Laughter) And now the third time for the same player.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:53.958
(Laughter)

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
"Wait for me after the concert.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
I have a short notice to give you."

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:01.958
You know, when it's needed, the authority is there. It's very important.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
But authority is not enough to make people your partners.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
Let's see the next video, please. See what happens here.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
You might be surprised having seen Kleiber

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
as such a hyperactive guy.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
He's conducting Mozart.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
(Music)

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
The whole orchestra is playing.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
(Music)

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
Now something else.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
(Music)

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
See? He is there 100 percent,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
but not commanding, not telling what to do.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
Rather enjoying what the soloist is doing.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
(Music)

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
Another solo now. See what you can pick up from this.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
(Music)

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
Look at the eyes.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
Okay. You see that?

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
First of all, it's a kind of a compliment we all like to get.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
It's not feedback. It's an "Mmmm ..." Yeah, it comes from here.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
So that's a good thing.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
And the second thing is

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
it's about actually being in control,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
but in a very special way.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
When Kleiber does -- did you see the eyes,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
going from here? (Singing)

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:24.958
You know what happens? Gravitation is no more.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
Kleiber not only creates a process,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
but also creates the conditions in the world

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
in which this process takes place.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
So again, the oboe player

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
is completely autonomous

title: 1.3m reasons to re-invent the syringe
transcript: Twenty-five-and-a-quarter years ago I read a newspaper article which said that one day syringes would be one of the major causes of the spread of AIDS, the transmission of AIDS. I thought this was unacceptable. So I decided to do something about it.Sadly, it's come true. Malaria, as we all know, kills approximately one million people a year. The reuse of syringes now exceeds that and kills 1.3 million people a year. This young girl and her friend that I met in an orphanage in Delhi were HIV positive from a syringe. And what was so sad about this particular story was that once their parents had found out — and don't forget, their parents took them to the doctor — the parents threw them out on the street. And hence they ended up in an orphanage.And it comes from situations like this where you have either skilled or unskilled practitioners, blindly giving an injection to someone. And the injection is so valuable, that the people basically trust the doctor, being second to God, which I've heard many times, to do the right thing. But in fact they're not. And you can understand, obviously, the transmission problem between people in high-virus areas.This video we took undercover, which shows you, over a half an hour period, a tray of medicines of 42 vials, which are being delivered with only 2 syringes in a public hospital in India. And over the course of half an hour, not one syringe was filmed being unwrapped. They started with two and they ended with two. And you'll see, just now, a nurse coming back to the tray, which is their sort of modular station, and dropping the syringe she's just used back in the tray for it to be picked up and used again. So you can imagine the scale of this problem. And in fact in India alone, 62 percent of all injections given are unsafe.These kids in Pakistan don't go to school. They are lucky. They already have a job. And that job is that they go around and pick up syringes from the back of hospitals, wash them, and in the course of this, obviously picking them up they injure themselves. And then they repackage them and sell them out on markets for literally more money than a sterile syringe in the first place, which is quite bizarre. In an interesting photo, their father, while we were talking to him, picked up a syringe and pricked his finger — I don't know whether you can see the drop of blood on the end — and immediately whipped out a box of matches, lit one, and burned the blood off the end of his finger, giving me full assurance that that was the way that you stopped the transmission of HIV.In China, recycling is a major issue. And they are collected en mass — you can see the scale of it here — and sorted out, by hand, back into the right sizes, and then put back out on the street. So recycling and reuse are the major issues here. But there was one interesting anecdote that I found in Indonesia. In all schools in Indonesia, there is usually a toy seller in the playground. The toy seller, in this case, had syringes, which they usually do, next door to the diggers, which is obviously what you would expect. And they use them, in the breaks, for water pistols. They squirt them at each other, which is lovely and innocent. And they are having great fun. But they also drink from them while they're in their breaks, because it's hot. And they squirt the water into their mouths. And these are used with traces of blood visible.So we need a better product. And we need better information. And I think, if I can just borrow this camera, I was going to show you my invention, which I came up with. So, it's a normal-looking syringe. You load it up in the normal way. This is made on existing equipment in 14 factories that we license. You give the injection and then put it down. If someone then tries to reuse it, it locks and breaks afterwards. It's very, very simple. Thank you. (Applause) And it costs the same as a normal syringe. And in comparison, a Coca-Cola is 10 times the price. And that will stop reusing a syringe 20 or 30 times.And I have an information charity which has done huge scale amount of work in India. And we're very proud of giving information to people, so that little kids like this don't do stupid things. Thank you very much. (Applause)

title: Navigating our global future
transcript: The future, as we know it, is very unpredictable. The best minds in the best institutions generally get it wrong. This is in technology. This is in the area of politics, where pundits, the CIA, MI6 always get it wrong. And it's clearly in the area of finance. With institutions established to think about the future, the IMF, the BIS, the Financial Stability Forum, couldn't see what was coming. Over 20,000 economists whose job it is, competitive entry to get there, couldn't see what was happening.Globalization is getting more complex. And this change is getting more rapid. The future will be more unpredictable. Urbanization, integration, coming together, leads to a new renaissance. It did this a thousand years ago. The last 40 years have been extraordinary times. Life expectancy has gone up by about 25 years. It took from the Stone Age to achieve that. Income has gone up for a majority of the world's population, despite the population going up by about two billion people over this period. And illiteracy has gone down, from a half to about a quarter of the people on Earth. A huge opportunity, unleashing of new potential for innovation, for development.But there is an underbelly. There are two Achilles' heels of globalization. There is the Achilles' heel of growing inequality — those that are left out, those that feel angry, those that are not participating. Globalization has not been inclusive. The second Achilles' heel is complexity — a growing fragility, a growing brittleness. What happens in one place very quickly affects everything else. This is a systemic risk, systemic shock. We've seen it in the financial crisis. We've seen it in the pandemic flu. It will become virulent and it's something we have to build resilience against.A lot of this is driven by what's happening in technology. There have been huge leaps. There will be a million-fold improvement in what you can get for the same price in computing by 2030. That's what the experience of the last 20 years has been. It will continue. Our computers, our systems will be as primitive as the Apollo's are for today. Our mobile phones are more powerful than the total Apollo space engine. Our mobile phones are more powerful than some of the strongest computers of 20 years ago. So what will this do? It will create huge opportunities in technology. Miniaturization as well. There will be invisible capacity. Invisible capacity in our bodies, in our brains, and in the air. This is a dust mite on a nanoreplica.This sort of ability to do everything in new ways unleashes potential, not least in the area of medicine. This is a stem cell that we've developed here in Oxford, from an embryonic stem cell. We can develop any part of the body. Increasingly, over time, this will be possible from our own skin — able to replicate parts of the body. Fantastic potential for regenerative medicine. I don't think there will be a Special Olympics long after 2030, because of this capacity to regenerate parts of the body. But the question is, "Who will have it?"The other major development is going to be in the area of what can happen in genetics. The capacity to create, as this mouse has been genetically modified, something which goes three times faster, lasts for three times longer, we could produce, as this mouse can, to the age of our equivalent of 80 years, using about the same amount of food. But will this only be available for the super rich, for those that can afford it? Are we headed for a new eugenics? Will only those that are able to afford it be able to be this super race of the future? (Laughter)So the big question for us is, "How do we manage this technological change?" How do we ensure that it creates a more inclusive technology, a technology which means that not only as we grow older, that we can also grow wiser, and that we're able to support the populations of the future? One of the most dramatic manifestations of these improvements will be moving from population pyramids to what we might term population coffins. There is unlikely to be a pension or a retirement age in 2030. These will be redundant concepts. And this isn't only something of the West.The most dramatic changes will be the skyscraper type of new pyramids that will take place in China and in many other countries. So forget about retirements if you're young. Forget about pensions. Think about life and where it's going to be going. Of course, migration will become even more important. The war on talent, the need to attract people at all skill ranges, to push us around in our wheelchairs, but also to drive our economies. Our innovation will be vital.The employment in the rich countries will go down from about 800 to about 700 million of these people. This would imply a massive leap in migration. So the concerns, the xenophobic concerns of today, of migration, will be turned on their head, as we search for people to help us sort out our pensions and our economies in the future. And then, the systemic risks. We understand that these will become much more virulent, that what we see today is this interweaving of societies, of systems, fastened by technologies and hastened by just-in-time management systems. Small levels of stock push resilience into other people's responsibility.The collapse in biodiversity, climate change, pandemics, financial crises: these will be the currency that we will think about. And so a new awareness will have to arise, of how we deal with these, how we mobilize ourselves, in a new way, and come together as a community to manage systemic risk. It's going to require innovation. It's going to require an understanding that the glory of globalization could also be its downfall. This could be our best century ever because of the achievements, or it could be our worst. And of course we need to worry about the individuals, particularly the individuals that feel that they've been left out in one way or another.An individual, for the first time in the history of humanity, will have the capacity, by 2030, to destroy the planet, to wreck everything, through the creation, for example, of a biopathogen. How do we begin to weave these tapestries together? How do we think about complex systems in new ways? That will be the challenge of the scholars, and of all of us engaged in thinking about the future. The rest of our lives will be in the future. We need to prepare for it now. We need to understand that the governance structure in the world is fossilized. It cannot begin to cope with the challenges that this will bring. We have to develop a new way of managing the planet, collectively, through collective wisdom.We know, and I know from my own experience, that amazing things can happen, when individuals and societies come together to change their future. I left South Africa, and 15 years later, after thinking I would never go back, I had the privilege and the honor to work in the government of Nelson Mandela. This was a miracle. We can create miracles, collectively, in our lifetime. It is vital that we do so. It is vital that the ideas that are nurtured in TED, that the ideas that we think about look forward, and make sure that this will be the most glorious century, and not one of eco-disaster and eco-collapse. Thank you. (Applause)
