00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
So what will this do?

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
It will create huge opportunities in technology.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
Miniaturization as well.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.958
There will be invisible capacity. Invisible capacity in our bodies,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
in our brains, and in the air.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
This is a dust mite on a nanoreplica.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:37.958
This sort of ability to do everything in new ways unleashes potential,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
not least in the area of medicine.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
This is a stem cell that we've developed here in Oxford,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
from an embryonic stem cell.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
We can develop any part of the body.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Increasingly, over time, this will be possible from our own skin --

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
able to replicate parts of the body.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
Fantastic potential for regenerative medicine.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:57.958
I don't think there will be a Special Olympics long after 2030,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
because of this capacity to regenerate parts of the body.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
But the question is, "Who will have it?"

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
The other major development is going to be

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
in the area of what can happen in genetics.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:12.958
The capacity to create, as this mouse has been genetically modified,

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
something which goes three times faster,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
lasts for three times longer, we could produce,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:20.958
as this mouse can, to the age of our equivalent of 80 years,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
using about the same amount of food.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
But will this only be available for the super rich,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
for those that can afford it? Are we headed for a new eugenics?

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
Will only those that are able to afford it

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
be able to be this super race of the future?

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:35.958
(Laughter)

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
So the big question for us is,

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
"How do we manage this technological change?"

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
How do we ensure that it creates

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
a more inclusive technology,

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
a technology which means

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
that not only as we grow older,

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
that we can also grow wiser, and that we're able to support

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
the populations of the future?

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
One of the most dramatic manifestations of these improvements

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
will be moving from population pyramids

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
to what we might term population coffins.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
There is unlikely to be a pension

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
or a retirement age in 2030.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
These will be redundant concepts. And this isn't only something of the West.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
The most dramatic changes will be the skyscraper

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
type of new pyramids

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
that will take place in China and in many other countries.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
So forget about retirements if you're young.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
Forget about pensions. Think about life and where it's going to be going.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
Of course, migration will become even more important.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
The war on talent, the need to attract people

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
at all skill ranges,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
to push us around in our wheelchairs,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
but also to drive our economies. Our innovation will be vital.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
The employment in the rich countries

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
will go down from about 800

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
to about 700 million of these people.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
This would imply a massive leap in migration.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:44.958
So the concerns, the xenophobic concerns of today,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
of migration, will be turned on their head,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
as we search for people to help us sort out

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
our pensions and our economies in the future.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
And then, the systemic risks.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
We understand that these will become much more virulent,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
that what we see today

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
is this interweaving of societies, of systems,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:06.958
fastened by technologies and hastened by just-in-time management systems.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:11.958
Small levels of stock push resilience into other people's responsibility.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
The collapse in biodiversity,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
climate change, pandemics, financial crises:

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
these will be the currency that we will think about.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And so a new awareness will have to arise,

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
of how we deal with these, how we mobilize ourselves,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
in a new way, and come together as a community

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
to manage systemic risk.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
It's going to require innovation.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:35.958
It's going to require an understanding that the glory of globalization

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
could also be its downfall.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
This could be our best century ever because of the achievements,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
or it could be our worst.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
And of course we need to worry about the individuals,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
particularly the individuals that feel that they've

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
been left out in one way or another.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
An individual, for the first time in the history of humanity,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
will have the capacity, by 2030,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
to destroy the planet, to wreck everything,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
through the creation, for example, of a biopathogen.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
How do we begin to weave these tapestries together?

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:04.958
How do we think about complex systems in new ways?

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
That will be the challenge of the scholars,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
and of all of us engaged in thinking about the future.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
The rest of our lives will be in the future. We need to prepare for it now.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
We need to understand that the governance structure in the world is fossilized.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
It cannot begin to cope with the challenges that this will bring.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
We have to develop a new way of managing the planet,

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
collectively, through collective wisdom.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
We know, and I know from my own experience,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
that amazing things can happen,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
when individuals and societies come together

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
to change their future.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
I left South Africa, and 15 years later,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
after thinking I would never go back,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
I had the privilege and the honor to work in the government of Nelson Mandela.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
This was a miracle. We can create miracles,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
collectively, in our lifetime.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
It is vital that we do so.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
It is vital that the ideas that are nurtured in TED,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
that the ideas that we think about

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
look forward, and make sure that this will be the most glorious century,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
and not one of eco-disaster and eco-collapse.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
Thank you. (Applause)

title: A new way to explain explanation
transcript: I'm sure that, throughout the hundred-thousand-odd years of our species' existence, and even before, our ancestors looked up at the night sky, and wondered what stars are. Wondering, therefore, how to explain what they saw in terms of things unseen.Okay, so, most people only wondered that occasionally, like today, in breaks from whatever normally preoccupied them. But what normally preoccupied them also involved yearning to know. They wished they knew how to prevent their food supply from sometimes failing, and how they could rest when they were tired without risking starvation, be warmer, cooler, safer, in less pain. I bet those prehistoric cave artists would have loved to know how to draw better.In every aspect of their lives, they wished for progress, just as we do. But they failed, almost completely, to make any. They didn't know how to. Discoveries like fire happened so rarely, that from an individual's point of view, the world never improved. Nothing new was learned.The first clue to the origin of starlight happened as recently as 1899: radioactivity. Within 40 years, physicists discovered the whole explanation, expressed, as usual, in elegant symbols. But never mind the symbols. Think how many discoveries they represent. Nuclei and nuclear reactions, of course. But isotopes, particles of electricity, antimatter, neutrinos, the conversion of mass to energy — that's E=mc^2 — gamma rays, transmutation. That ancient dream that had always eluded the alchemists was achieved through these same theories that explained starlight and other ancient mysteries, and new, unexpected phenomena.That all that, discovered in 40 years, had not been in the previous hundred thousand, was not for lack of thinking about stars, and all those other urgent problems they had. They even arrived at answers, such as myths, that dominated their lives, yet bore almost no resemblance to the truth. The tragedy of that protracted stagnation isn't sufficiently recognized, I think. These were people with brains of essentially the same design that eventually did discover all those things. But that ability to make progress remained almost unused, until the event that revolutionized the human condition and changed the universe.Or so we should hope. Because that event was the Scientific Revolution, ever since which our knowledge of the physical world, and of how to adapt it to our wishes, has been growing relentlessly. Now, what had changed? What were people now doing for the first time that made that difference between stagnation and rapid, open-ended discovery? How to make that difference is surely the most important universal truth that it is possible to know. Worryingly, there is no consensus about what it is. So, I'll tell you. But I'll have to backtrack a little first.Before the Scientific Revolution, they believed that everything important, knowable, was already known, enshrined in ancient writings, institutions, and in some genuinely useful rules of thumb — which were, however, entrenched as dogmas, along with many falsehoods. So they believed that knowledge came from authorities that actually knew very little. And therefore progress depended on learning how to reject the authority of learned men, priests, traditions and rulers. Which is why the Scientific Revolution had to have a wider context.The Enlightenment, a revolution in how people sought knowledge, trying not to rely on authority. "Take no one's word for it." But that can't be what made the difference. Authorities had been rejected before, many times. And that rarely, if ever, caused anything like the Scientific Revolution. At the time, what they thought distinguished science was a radical idea about things unseen, known as empiricism. All knowledge derives from the senses. Well, we've seen that that can't be true. It did help by promoting observation and experiment. But, from the outset, it was obvious that there was something horribly wrong with it.Knowledge comes from the senses. In what language? Certainly not the language of mathematics, in which, Galileo rightly said, the book of nature is written. Look at the world. You don't see equations carved on to the mountainsides. If you did, it would be because people had carved them. By the way, why don't we do that? What's wrong with us? (Laughter)Empiricism is inadequate because, well, scientific theories explain the seen in terms of the unseen. And the unseen, you have to admit, doesn't come to us through the senses. We don't see those nuclear reactions in stars. We don't see the origin of species. We don't see the curvature of space-time, and other universes. But we know about those things. How?Well, the classic empiricist answer is induction. The unseen resembles the seen. But it doesn't. You know what the clinching evidence was that space-time is curved? It was a photograph, not of space-time, but of an eclipse, with a dot there rather than there. And the evidence for evolution? Some rocks and some finches. And parallel universes? Again: dots there, rather than there, on a screen. What we see, in all these cases, bears no resemblance to the reality that we conclude is responsible — only a long chain of theoretical reasoning and interpretation connects them."Ah!" say creationists. "So you admit it's all interpretation. No one has ever seen evolution. We see rocks. You have your interpretation. We have ours. Yours comes from guesswork, ours from the Bible." But what creationist and empiricists both ignore is that, in that sense, no one has ever seen a bible either, that the eye only detects light, which we don't perceive. Brains only detect nerve impulses. And they don't perceive even those as what they really are, namely electrical crackles. So we perceive nothing as what it really is.Our connection to reality is never just perception. It's always, as Karl Popper put it, theory-laden. Scientific knowledge isn't derived from anything. It's like all knowledge. It's conjectural, guesswork, tested by observation, not derived from it. So, were testable conjectures the great innovation that opened the intellectual prison gates? No. Contrary to what's usually said, testability is common, in myths and all sorts of other irrational modes of thinking. Any crank claiming the sun will go out next Tuesday has got a testable prediction.Consider the ancient Greek myth explaining seasons. Hades, God of the Underworld, kidnaps Persephone, the Goddess of Spring, and negotiates a forced marriage contract, requiring her to return regularly, and lets her go. And each year, she is magically compelled to return. And her mother, Demeter, Goddess of the Earth, is sad, and makes it cold and barren. That myth is testable. If winter is caused by Demeter's sadness, then it must happen everywhere on Earth simultaneously. So if the ancient Greeks had only known that Australia is at its warmest when Demeter is at her saddest, they'd have known that their theory is false.So what was wrong with that myth, and with all pre-scientific thinking, and what, then, made that momentous difference? I think there is one thing you have to care about. And that implies testability, the scientific method, the Enlightenment, and everything. And here is the crucial thing. There is such a thing as a defect in a story. I don't just mean a logical defect. I mean a bad explanation. What does that mean? Well, explanation is an assertion about what's there, unseen, that accounts for what's seen.Because the explanatory role of Persephone's marriage contract could be played equally well by infinitely many other ad hoc entities. Why a marriage contract and not any other reason for regular annual action? Here is one. Persephone wasn't released. She escaped, and returns every spring to take revenge on Hades, with her Spring powers. She cools his domain with Spring air, venting heat up to the surface, creating summer. That accounts for the same phenomena as the original myth. It's equally testable. Yet what it asserts about reality is, in many ways, the opposite. And that is possible because the details of the original myth are unrelated to seasons, except via the myth itself.This easy variability is the sign of a bad explanation, because, without a functional reason to prefer one of countless variants, advocating one of them, in preference to the others, is irrational. So, for the essence of what makes the difference to enable progress, seek good explanations, the ones that can't be easily varied, while still explaining the phenomena.Now, our current explanation of seasons is that the Earth's axis is tilted like that, so each hemisphere tilts toward the sun for half the year, and away for the other half. Better put that up. (Laughter) That's a good explanation: hard to vary, because every detail plays a functional role. For instance, we know, independently of seasons, that surfaces tilted away from radiant heat are heated less, and that a spinning sphere, in space, points in a constant direction. And the tilt also explains the sun's angle of elevation at different times of year, and predicts that the seasons will be out of phase in the two hemispheres. If they'd been observed in phase, the theory would have been refuted. But now, the fact that it's also a good explanation, hard to vary, makes the crucial difference.If the ancient Greeks had found out about seasons in Australia, they could have easily varied their myth to predict that. For instance, when Demeter is upset, she banishes heat from her vicinity, into the other hemisphere, where it makes summer. So, being proved wrong by observation, and changing their theory accordingly, still wouldn't have got the ancient Greeks one jot closer to understanding seasons, because their explanation was bad: easy to vary. And it's only when an explanation is good that it even matters whether it's testable. If the axis-tilt theory had been refuted, its defenders would have had nowhere to go. No easily implemented change could make that tilt cause the same seasons in both hemispheres.The search for hard-to-vary explanations is the origin of all progress. It's the basic regulating principle of the Enlightenment. So, in science, two false approaches blight progress. One is well known: untestable theories. But the more important one is explanationless theories. Whenever you're told that some existing statistical trend will continue, but you aren't given a hard-to-vary account of what causes that trend, you're being told a wizard did it.When you are told that carrots have human rights because they share half our genes — but not how gene percentages confer rights — wizard. When someone announces that the nature-nurture debate has been settled because there is evidence that a given percentage of our political opinions are genetically inherited, but they don't explain how genes cause opinions, they've settled nothing. They are saying that our opinions are caused by wizards, and presumably so are their own. That the truth consists of hard to vary assertions about reality is the most important fact about the physical world. It's a fact that is, itself, unseen, yet impossible to vary. Thank you. (Applause)

which were, however, entrenched as dogmas,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
along with many falsehoods.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.958
So they believed that knowledge came from authorities

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
that actually knew very little.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
And therefore progress

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
depended on learning how to reject

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
the authority of learned men,

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.958
priests, traditions and rulers.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
Which is why the Scientific Revolution

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
had to have a wider context.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:43.958
The Enlightenment, a revolution in how

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
people sought knowledge,

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
trying not to rely on authority.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
"Take no one's word for it."

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:55.958
But that can't be what made the difference.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
Authorities had been rejected before, many times.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
And that rarely, if ever,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:03.958
caused anything like the Scientific Revolution.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
At the time, what they thought

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
distinguished science

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:11.958
was a radical idea about things unseen,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
known as empiricism.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:19.958
All knowledge derives from the senses.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
Well, we've seen that that can't be true.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:26.958
It did help by promoting

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
observation and experiment.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
But, from the outset, it was obvious

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
that there was something horribly wrong with it.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
Knowledge comes from the senses.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
In what language? Certainly not the language of mathematics,

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
in which, Galileo rightly said,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
the book of nature is written.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
Look at the world. You don't see equations

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
carved on to the mountainsides.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
If you did, it would be because people

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
had carved them.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
By the way, why don't we do that?

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
What's wrong with us?

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:00.958
(Laughter)

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
Empiricism is inadequate

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
because, well,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:09.958
scientific theories explain the seen in terms of the unseen.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
And the unseen, you have to admit,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
doesn't come to us through the senses.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:17.958
We don't see those nuclear reactions in stars.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
We don't see the origin of species.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
We don't see the curvature of space-time,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
and other universes.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
But we know about those things.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
How?

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:36.958
Well, the classic empiricist answer is induction.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:40.958
The unseen resembles the seen.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
But it doesn't.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
You know what the clinching evidence was

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
that space-time is curved?

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
It was a photograph, not of space-time,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:54.958
but of an eclipse, with a dot there rather than there.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
And the evidence for evolution?

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
Some rocks and some finches.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
And parallel universes? Again: dots there,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
rather than there, on a screen.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
What we see, in all these cases,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:11.958
bears no resemblance to the reality

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
that we conclude is responsible --

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
only a long chain of theoretical reasoning

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
and interpretation connects them.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
"Ah!" say creationists.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
"So you admit it's all interpretation.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
No one has ever seen evolution.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
We see rocks.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
You have your interpretation. We have ours.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
Yours comes from guesswork,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
ours from the Bible."

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:42.958
But what creationist and empiricists both ignore

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
is that, in that sense,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
no one has ever seen a bible either,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
that the eye only detects light, which we don't perceive.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
Brains only detect nerve impulses.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
And they don't perceive even those as what they really are,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
namely electrical crackles.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:04.958
So we perceive nothing as what it really is.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
Our connection to reality

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
is never just perception.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:13.958
It's always, as Karl Popper put it,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
theory-laden.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
Scientific knowledge isn't derived from anything.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:24.958
It's like all knowledge. It's conjectural, guesswork,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
tested by observation,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:30.958
not derived from it.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
So, were testable conjectures

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:37.958
the great innovation that opened the intellectual prison gates?

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
No. Contrary to what's usually said,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
testability is common,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:46.958
in myths and all sorts of other irrational modes of thinking.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
Any crank claiming the sun will go out next Tuesday

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
has got a testable prediction.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
Consider the ancient Greek myth

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
explaining seasons.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
Hades, God of the Underworld,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
kidnaps Persephone, the Goddess of Spring,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
and negotiates a forced marriage contract,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:11.958
requiring her to return regularly, and lets her go.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
And each year,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
she is magically compelled to return.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
And her mother, Demeter,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
Goddess of the Earth,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:25.958
is sad, and makes it cold and barren.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
That myth is testable.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
If winter is caused by Demeter's sadness,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
then it must happen everywhere on Earth simultaneously.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
So if the ancient Greeks had only known that Australia

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:43.958
is at its warmest when Demeter is at her saddest,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
they'd have known that their theory is false.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
So what was wrong with that myth,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and with all pre-scientific thinking,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:57.958
and what, then, made that momentous difference?

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:01.958
I think there is one thing you have to care about.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
And that implies

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
testability, the scientific method,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
the Enlightenment, and everything.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
And here is the crucial thing.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
There is such a thing as a defect in a story.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:18.958
I don't just mean a logical defect. I mean a bad explanation.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
What does that mean? Well, explanation

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
is an assertion about what's there, unseen,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
that accounts for what's seen.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
Because the explanatory role

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
of Persephone's marriage contract

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
could be played equally well

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
by infinitely many other

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
ad hoc entities.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
Why a marriage contract and not any other reason

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:45.958
for regular annual action?

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
Here is one. Persephone wasn't released.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:52.958
She escaped, and returns every spring

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
to take revenge on Hades,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
with her Spring powers.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:12:01.958
She cools his domain with Spring air,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:05.958
venting heat up to the surface, creating summer.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:09.958
That accounts for the same phenomena as the original myth.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
It's equally testable.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
Yet what it asserts about reality

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
is, in many ways, the opposite.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
And that is possible because

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
the details of the original myth

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
are unrelated to seasons,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:28.958
except via the myth itself.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
This easy variability

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.958
is the sign of a bad explanation,

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:39.958
because, without a functional reason to prefer

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:44.958
one of countless variants,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
advocating one of them, in preference to the others,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
is irrational.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
So, for the essence of what

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
makes the difference to enable progress,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
seek good explanations,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
the ones that can't be easily varied,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:03.958
while still explaining the phenomena.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
Now, our current explanation of seasons

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
is that the Earth's axis is tilted like that,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
so each hemisphere tilts toward the sun for half the year,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
and away for the other half.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
Better put that up.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:19.958
(Laughter)

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:24.958
That's a good explanation: hard to vary,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
because every detail plays a functional role.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
For instance, we know, independently of seasons,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
that surfaces tilted away

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
from radiant heat are heated less,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
and that a spinning sphere, in space,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
points in a constant direction.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
And the tilt also explains

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:48.958
the sun's angle of elevation at different times of year,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
and predicts that the seasons

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
will be out of phase in the two hemispheres.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
If they'd been observed in phase,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
the theory would have been refuted.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:02.958
But now, the fact that it's also a good explanation,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:07.958
hard to vary, makes the crucial difference.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
If the ancient Greeks had found out

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
about seasons in Australia,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
they could have easily varied their myth

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
to predict that.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
For instance, when Demeter is upset,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
she banishes heat from her vicinity,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
into the other hemisphere, where it makes summer.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
So, being proved wrong by observation,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
and changing their theory accordingly,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
still wouldn't have got the ancient Greeks

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
one jot closer to understanding seasons,

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
because their explanation was bad: easy to vary.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
And it's only when an explanation is good

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
that it even matters whether it's testable.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
If the axis-tilt theory had been refuted,

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
its defenders would have had nowhere to go.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
No easily implemented change

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
could make that tilt

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:58.958
cause the same seasons in both hemispheres.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
The search for hard-to-vary explanations

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
is the origin of all progress.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
It's the basic regulating principle

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
of the Enlightenment.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
So, in science, two false approaches blight progress.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
One is well known: untestable theories.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
But the more important one is explanationless theories.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:24.958
Whenever you're told that some existing statistical trend will continue,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
but you aren't given a hard-to-vary account

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
of what causes that trend,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
you're being told a wizard did it.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
When you are told that carrots have human rights

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
because they share half our genes --

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:43.958
but not how gene percentages confer rights -- wizard.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:47.958
When someone announces that the nature-nurture debate

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
has been settled because there is evidence

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
that a given percentage of our

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
political opinions are genetically inherited,

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:59.958
but they don't explain how genes cause opinions,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
they've settled nothing. They are saying that our

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
opinions are caused by wizards,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
and presumably so are their own.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
That the truth consists of

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.958
hard to vary assertions about reality

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
is the most important fact

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
about the physical world.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
It's a fact that is, itself, unseen,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:25.958
yet impossible to vary. Thank you.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:29.958
(Applause)

title: Architecture that repairs itself?
transcript: All buildings today have something in common. They're made using Victorian technologies. This involves blueprints, industrial manufacturing and construction using teams of workers. All of this effort results in an inert object. And that means that there is a one-way transfer of energy from our environment into our homes and cities. This is not sustainable. I believe that the only way that it is possible for us to construct genuinely sustainable homes and cities is by connecting them to nature, not insulating them from it.Now, in order to do this, we need the right kind of language. Living systems are in constant conversation with the natural world, through sets of chemical reactions called metabolism. And this is the conversion of one group of substances into another, either through the production or the absorption of energy. And this is the way in which living materials make the most of their local resources in a sustainable way. So, I'm interested in the use of metabolic materials for the practice of architecture. But they don't exist. So I'm having to make them.I'm working with architect Neil Spiller at the Bartlett School of Architecture, and we're collaborating with international scientists in order to generate these new materials from a bottom up approach. That means we're generating them from scratch. One of our collaborators is chemist Martin Hanczyc, and he's really interested in the transition from inert to living matter. Now, that's exactly the kind of process that I'm interested in, when we're thinking about sustainable materials.So, Martin, he works with a system called the protocell. Now all this is — and it's magic — is a little fatty bag. And it's got a chemical battery in it. And it has no DNA. This little bag is able to conduct itself in a way that can only be described as living. It is able to move around its environment. It can follow chemical gradients. It can undergo complex reactions, some of which are happily architectural. So here we are. These are protocells, patterning their environment. We don't know how they do that yet. Here, this is a protocell, and it's vigorously shedding this skin. Now, this looks like a chemical kind of birth. This is a violent process.Here, we've got a protocell to extract carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere and turn it into carbonate. And that's the shell around that globular fat. They are quite brittle. So you've only got a part of one there. So what we're trying to do is, we're trying to push these technologies towards creating bottom-up construction approaches for architecture, which contrast the current, Victorian, top-down methods which impose structure upon matter. That can't be energetically sensible.So, bottom-up materials actually exist today. They've been in use, in architecture, since ancient times. If you walk around the city of Oxford, where we are today, and have a look at the brickwork, which I've enjoyed doing in the last couple of days, you'll actually see that a lot of it is made of limestone. And if you look even closer, you'll see, in that limestone, there are little shells and little skeletons that are piled upon each other. And then they are fossilized over millions of years.Now a block of limestone, in itself, isn't particularly that interesting. It looks beautiful. But imagine what the properties of this limestone block might be if the surfaces were actually in conversation with the atmosphere. Maybe they could extract carbon dioxide. Would it give this block of limestone new properties? Well, most likely it would. It might be able to grow. It might be able to self-repair, and even respond to dramatic changes in the immediate environment.So, architects are never happy with just one block of an interesting material. They think big. Okay? So when we think about scaling up metabolic materials, we can start thinking about ecological interventions like repair of atolls, or reclamation of parts of a city that are damaged by water. So, one of these examples would of course be the historic city of Venice. Now, Venice, as you know, has a tempestuous relationship with the sea, and is built upon wooden piles. So we've devised a way by which it may be possible for the protocell technology that we're working with to sustainably reclaim Venice. And architect Christian Kerrigan has come up with a series of designs that show us how it may be possible to actually grow a limestone reef underneath the city.So, here is the technology we have today. This is our protocell technology, effectively making a shell, like its limestone forefathers, and depositing it in a very complex environment, against natural materials. We're looking at crystal lattices to see the bonding process in this. Now, this is the very interesting part. We don't just want limestone dumped everywhere in all the pretty canals. What we need it to do is to be creatively crafted around the wooden piles.So, you can see from these diagrams that the protocell is actually moving away from the light, toward the dark foundations. We've observed this in the laboratory. The protocells can actually move away from the light. They can actually also move towards the light. You have to just choose your species. So that these don't just exist as one entity, we kind of chemically engineer them. And so here the protocells are depositing their limestone very specifically, around the foundations of Venice, effectively petrifying it.Now, this isn't going to happen tomorrow. It's going to take a while. It's going to take years of tuning and monitoring this technology in order for us to become ready to test it out in a case-by-case basis on the most damaged and stressed buildings within the city of Venice. But gradually, as the buildings are repaired, we will see the accretion of a limestone reef beneath the city. An accretion itself is a huge sink of carbon dioxide. Also it will attract the local marine ecology, who will find their own ecological niches within this architecture.So, this is really interesting. Now we have an architecture that connects a city to the natural world in a very direct and immediate way. But perhaps the most exciting thing about it is that the driver of this technology is available everywhere. This is terrestrial chemistry. We've all got it, which means that this technology is just as appropriate for developing countries as it is for First World countries. So, in summary, I'm generating metabolic materials as a counterpoise to Victorian technologies, and building architectures from a bottom-up approach.Secondly, these metabolic materials have some of the properties of living systems, which means they can perform in similar ways. They can expect to have a lot of forms and functions within the practice of architecture. And finally, an observer in the future marveling at a beautiful structure in the environment may find it almost impossible to tell whether this structure has been created by a natural process or an artificial one. Thank you. (Applause)

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
into another, either through

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
the production or the absorption of energy.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
And this is the way in which living materials

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
make the most of their local resources

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
in a sustainable way.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
So, I'm interested in the use of

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:24.958
metabolic materials for the practice of architecture.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
But they don't exist. So I'm having to make them.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
I'm working with architect Neil Spiller

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
at the Bartlett School of Architecture,

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
and we're collaborating with international scientists

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:34.958
in order to generate these new materials

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
from a bottom up approach.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
That means we're generating them from scratch.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:42.958
One of our collaborators is chemist Martin Hanczyc,

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:45.958
and he's really interested in the transition from

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
inert to living matter.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.958
Now, that's exactly the kind of process that I'm interested in,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
when we're thinking about sustainable materials.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:57.958
So, Martin, he works with a system called the protocell.

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:00.958
Now all this is -- and it's magic --

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
is a little fatty bag. And it's got a chemical battery in it.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
And it has no DNA.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
This little bag is able to conduct itself

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:11.958
in a way that can only be described as living.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
It is able to move around its environment.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
It can follow chemical gradients.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
It can undergo complex reactions,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:23.958
some of which are happily architectural.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
So here we are. These are protocells,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
patterning their environment.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
We don't know how they do that yet.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:34.958
Here, this is a protocell, and it's vigorously shedding this skin.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
Now, this looks like a chemical kind of birth.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
This is a violent process.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
Here, we've got a protocell to extract carbon dioxide

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
out of the atmosphere

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
and turn it into carbonate.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
And that's the shell around that globular fat.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
They are quite brittle. So you've only got a part of one there.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
So what we're trying to do is, we're trying to push these technologies

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
towards creating bottom-up construction approaches

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
for architecture,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
which contrast the current, Victorian, top-down methods

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
which impose structure upon matter.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:07.958
That can't be energetically sensible.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
So, bottom-up materials

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
actually exist today.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
They've been in use, in architecture, since ancient times.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
If you walk around the city of Oxford, where we are today,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
and have a look at the brickwork,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
which I've enjoyed doing in the last couple of days,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
you'll actually see that a lot of it is made of limestone.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
And if you look even closer,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
you'll see, in that limestone, there are little shells

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
and little skeletons that are piled upon each other.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
And then they are fossilized over millions of years.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
Now a block of limestone, in itself,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
isn't particularly that interesting.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
It looks beautiful.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:44.958
But imagine what the properties of this limestone block might be

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
if the surfaces were actually

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
in conversation with the atmosphere.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
Maybe they could extract carbon dioxide.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
Would it give this block of limestone new properties?

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:58.958
Well, most likely it would. It might be able to grow.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
It might be able to self-repair, and even respond

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:02.958
to dramatic changes

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
in the immediate environment.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
So, architects are never happy

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
with just one block of an interesting material.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
They think big. Okay?

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
So when we think about scaling up metabolic materials,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
we can start thinking about ecological interventions

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
like repair of atolls,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
or reclamation of parts of a city

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
that are damaged by water.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
So, one of these examples

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
would of course be the historic city of Venice.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:33.958
Now, Venice, as you know, has a tempestuous relationship with the sea,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
and is built upon wooden piles.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:38.958
So we've devised a way by which it may be possible

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
for the protocell technology that we're working with

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
to sustainably reclaim Venice.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
And architect Christian Kerrigan

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
has come up with a series of designs that show us

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
how it may be possible to actually grow a limestone reef

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
underneath the city.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
So, here is the technology we have today.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
This is our protocell technology,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:01.958
effectively making a shell, like its limestone forefathers,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
and depositing it in a very complex environment,

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
against natural materials.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
We're looking at crystal lattices to see the bonding process in this.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
Now, this is the very interesting part.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
We don't just want limestone dumped everywhere in all the pretty canals.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
What we need it to do is to be

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:20.958
creatively crafted around the wooden piles.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
So, you can see from these diagrams that the protocell is actually

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
moving away from the light,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
toward the dark foundations.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
We've observed this in the laboratory.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
The protocells can actually move away from the light.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
They can actually also move towards the light. You have to just choose your species.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
So that these don't just exist as one entity,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
we kind of chemically engineer them.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
And so here the protocells are depositing their limestone

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
very specifically, around the foundations of Venice,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
effectively petrifying it.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:51.958
Now, this isn't going to happen tomorrow. It's going to take a while.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:55.958
It's going to take years of tuning and monitoring this technology

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
in order for us to become ready

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
to test it out in a case-by-case basis

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
on the most damaged and stressed buildings within the city of Venice.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
But gradually, as the buildings are repaired,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
we will see the accretion of a limestone reef beneath the city.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:12.958
An accretion itself is a huge sink of carbon dioxide.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
Also it will attract the local marine ecology,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
who will find their own ecological niches within this architecture.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
So, this is really interesting. Now we have an architecture

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
that connects a city to the natural world

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
in a very direct and immediate way.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
But perhaps the most exciting thing about it

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
is that the driver of this technology is available everywhere.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
This is terrestrial chemistry. We've all got it,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
which means that this technology is just as appropriate

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
for developing countries as it is

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
for First World countries.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
So, in summary, I'm generating metabolic materials

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
as a counterpoise to Victorian technologies,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
and building architectures from a bottom-up approach.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
Secondly, these metabolic materials

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
have some of the properties of living systems,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
which means they can perform in similar ways.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
They can expect to have a lot of forms and functions

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
within the practice of architecture.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
And finally, an observer in the future

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
marveling at a beautiful structure in the environment

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
may find it almost impossible to tell

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
whether this structure

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
has been created by a natural process

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
or an artificial one.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
Thank you.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.958
(Applause)

title: The year I was homeless
transcript: I'm a writer and a journalist, and I'm also an insanely curious person, so in 22 years as a journalist, I've learned how to do a lot of new things. And three years ago, one of the things I learned how to do was to become invisible. I became one of the working homeless. I quit my job as a newspaper editor after my father died in February of that same year, and decided to travel. His death hit me pretty hard. And there were a lot of things that I wanted to feel and deal with while I was doing that.I've camped my whole life. And I decided that living in a van for a year to do this would be like one long camping trip. So I packed my cat, my Rottweiler and my camping gear into a 1975 Chevy van, and drove off into the sunset, having fully failed to realize three critical things. One: that society equates living in a permanent structure, even a shack, with having value as a person. Two: I failed to realize how quickly the negative perceptions of other people can impact our reality, if we let it. Three: I failed to realize that homelessness is an attitude, not a lifestyle.At first, living in the van was great. I showered in campgrounds. I ate out regularly. And I had time to relax and to grieve. But then the anger and the depression about my father's death set in. My freelance job ended. And I had to get a full-time job to pay the bills. What had been a really mild spring turned into a miserably hot summer. And it became impossible to park anywhere — (Laughs) — without being very obvious that I had a cat and a dog with me, and it was really hot. The cat came and went through an open window in the van. The doggy went into doggy day care. And I sweated. Whenever I could, I used employee showers in office buildings and truck stops. Or I washed up in public rest rooms.Nighttime temperatures in the van rarely dropped below 80 degrees Fahrenheit, making it difficult or impossible to sleep. Food rotted in the heat. Ice in my ice chest melted within hours, and it was pretty miserable. I couldn't afford to find an apartment, or couldn't afford an apartment that would allow me to have the Rottweiler and the cat. And I refused to give them up, so I stayed in the van. And when the heat made me too sick to walk the 50 feet to the public restroom outside my van at night, I used a bucket and a trash bag as a toilet.When winter weather set in, the temperatures dropped below freezing. And they stayed there. And I faced a whole new set of challenges. I parked a different place every night so I would avoid being noticed and hassled by the police. I didn't always succeed.But I felt out of control of my life. And I don't know when or how it happened, but the speed at which I went from being a talented writer and journalist to being a homeless woman, living in a van, took my breath away. I hadn't changed. My I.Q. hadn't dropped. My talent, my integrity, my values, everything about me remained the same. But I had changed somehow. I spiraled deeper and deeper into a depression.And eventually someone referred me to a homeless health clinic. And I went. I hadn't bathed in three days. I was as smelly and as depressed as anyone in line. I just wasn't drunk or high. And when several of the homeless men realized that, including a former university professor, they said, "You aren't homeless. Why are you really here?" Other homeless people didn't see me as homeless, but I did. Then the professor listened to my story and he said, "You have a job. You have hope. The real homeless don't have hope." A reaction to the medication the clinic gave me for my depression left me suicidal. And I remember thinking, "If I killed myself, no one would notice."A friend told me, shortly after that, that she had heard that Tim Russert, a nationally renowned journalist, had been talking about me on national T.V. An essay I'd written about my father, the year before he died, was in Tim's new book. And he was doing the talk show circuit. And he was talking about my writing. And when I realized that Tim Russert, former moderator of "Meet the Press," was talking about my writing, while I was living in a van in a Wal-Mart parking lot, I started laughing. You should too. (Laughter)I started laughing because it got to the point where, was I a writer, or was I a homeless woman? So I went in the bookstore. And I found Tim's book. And I stood there. And I reread my essay. And I cried. Because I was a writer. I was a writer. Shortly after that I moved back to Tennessee. I alternated between living in a van and couch surfing with friends. And I started writing again. By the summer of the following year I was a working journalist. I was winning awards. I was living in my own apartment. I was no longer homeless. And I was no longer invisible.Thousands of people work full and part-time jobs, and live in their cars. But society continues to stigmatize and criminalize living in your vehicle or on the streets. So the homeless, the working homeless, primarily remain invisible. But if you ever meet one, engage them, encourage them, and offer them hope. The human spirit can overcome anything if it has hope. And I'm not here to be the poster girl for the homeless. I'm not here to encourage you to give money to the next panhandler you meet. But I am here to tell you that, based on my experience, people are not where they live, where they sleep, or what their life situation is at any given time. Three years ago I was living in a van in a Wal-Mart parking lot, and today I'm speaking at TED. Hope always, always finds a way. Thank you. (Applause)
