00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.934
We grew up

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:16.934
interacting with the physical
objects around us.

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:20.358
There are an enormous number of them
that we use every day.

00:00:21.251 --> 00:00:23.934
Unlike most of our computing devices,

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:26.211
these objects are much more fun to use.

00:00:27.878 --> 00:00:29.934
When you talk about objects,

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.934
one other thing automatically
comes attached to that thing,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.934
and that is gestures:

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.934
how we manipulate these objects,

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:39.934
how we use these objects in everyday life.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:42.934
We use gestures not only to interact
with these objects,

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.244
but we also use them
to interact with each other.

00:00:45.268 --> 00:00:48.934
A gesture of "Namaste!",
maybe, to respect someone, or maybe,

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.387
in India I don't need to teach
a kid that this means

00:00:51.411 --> 00:00:52.934
"four runs" in cricket.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.481
It comes as a part
of our everyday learning.

00:00:56.414 --> 00:00:59.934
So, I am very interested,
from the beginning,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:03.934
how our knowledge
about everyday objects and gestures,

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.934
and how we use these objects,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.934
can be leveraged to our interactions
with the digital world.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.934
Rather than using a keyboard and mouse,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.934
why can I not use my computer

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.934
in the same way that I interact
in the physical world?

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.934
So, I started this exploration
around eight years back,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.934
and it literally started
with a mouse on my desk.

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:29.934
Rather than using it for my computer,
I actually opened it.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.149
Most of you might be aware
that, in those days,

00:01:32.173 --> 00:01:34.173
the mouse used to come with a ball inside,

00:01:34.197 --> 00:01:35.934
and there were two rollers

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.934
that actually guide the computer
where the ball is moving,

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.054
and, accordingly,
where the mouse is moving.

00:01:41.078 --> 00:01:43.934
So, I was interested in these two rollers,

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:47.339
and I actually wanted more, so I borrowed
another mouse from a friend --

00:01:47.363 --> 00:01:48.934
never returned to him --

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.934
and I now had four rollers.

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.934
Interestingly, what I did
with these rollers is,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:58.934
basically, I took them off of these mouses
and then put them in one line.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.934
It had some strings
and pulleys and some springs.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.934
What I got is basically
a gesture-interface device

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:08.934
that actually acts
as a motion-sensing device

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:10.934
made for two dollars.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.934
So, here, whatever movement
I do in my physical world

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.934
is actually replicated
inside the digital world

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:20.054
just using this small device
that I made, around eight years back,

00:02:20.078 --> 00:02:21.934
in 2000.

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:24.625
Because I was interested
in integrating these two worlds,

00:02:24.649 --> 00:02:25.934
I thought of sticky notes.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.934
I thought, "Why can I not connect

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.101
the normal interface
of a physical sticky note

00:02:31.125 --> 00:02:32.934
to the digital world?"

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.106
A message written
on a sticky note to my mom,

00:02:35.130 --> 00:02:36.334
on paper,

00:02:36.358 --> 00:02:37.934
can come to an SMS,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.934
or maybe a meeting reminder

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.149
automatically syncs
with my digital calendar --

00:02:42.173 --> 00:02:44.934
a to-do list that automatically
syncs with you.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.934
But you can also search
in the digital world,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.934
or maybe you can write a query, saying,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.934
"What is Dr. Smith's address?"

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.149
and this small system
actually prints it out --

00:02:54.173 --> 00:02:56.650
so it actually acts like a paper
input-output system,

00:02:56.674 --> 00:02:59.459
just made out of paper.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.934
In another exploration,

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.934
I thought of making a pen
that can draw in three dimensions.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:10.934
So, I implemented this pen
that can help designers and architects

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.934
not only think in three dimensions,

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.934
but they can actually draw,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.006
so that it's more intuitive
to use that way.

00:03:17.030 --> 00:03:19.078
Then I thought,
"Why not make a Google Map,

00:03:19.102 --> 00:03:20.934
but in the physical world?"

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.934
Rather than typing a keyword
to find something,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.934
I put my objects on top of it.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:29.149
If I put a boarding pass, it will show me
where the flight gate is.

00:03:29.173 --> 00:03:31.934
A coffee cup will show
where you can find more coffee,

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.934
or where you can trash the cup.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.934
So, these were some
of the earlier explorations I did

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
because the goal was to connect
these two worlds seamlessly.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.934
Among all these experiments,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.934
there was one thing in common:

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:48.463
I was trying to bring
a part of the physical world

00:03:48.487 --> 00:03:49.985
to the digital world.

00:03:50.009 --> 00:03:51.934
I was taking some part of the objects,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:54.935
or any of the intuitiveness of real life,

00:03:54.959 --> 00:03:57.148
and bringing them to the digital world,

00:03:57.172 --> 00:04:01.197
because the goal was to make
our computing interfaces more intuitive.

00:04:01.221 --> 00:04:05.934
But then I realized that we humans
are not actually interested in computing.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.934
What we are interested in is information.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.934
We want to know about things.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.339
We want to know about
dynamic things going around.

00:04:13.363 --> 00:04:17.934
So I thought, around last year --
in the beginning of the last year --

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:21.435
I started thinking, "Why can I not take
this approach in the reverse way?"

00:04:22.077 --> 00:04:24.134
Maybe, "How about I take my digital world

00:04:24.158 --> 00:04:28.934
and paint the physical world
with that digital information?"

00:04:30.112 --> 00:04:33.734
Because pixels are actually, right now,
confined in these rectangular devices

00:04:33.758 --> 00:04:35.505
that fit in our pockets.

00:04:35.529 --> 00:04:37.934
Why can I not remove this confine

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.934
and take that to my everyday
objects, everyday life

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.101
so that I don't need
to learn the new language

00:04:43.125 --> 00:04:44.922
for interacting with those pixels?

00:04:46.172 --> 00:04:48.934
So, in order to realize this dream,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.934
I actually thought of putting
a big-size projector on my head.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:55.197
I think that's why this is called
a head-mounted projector, isn't it?

00:04:55.221 --> 00:04:56.934
I took it very literally,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.934
and took my bike helmet,

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:02.339
put a little cut over there so that
the projector actually fits nicely.

00:05:02.363 --> 00:05:03.934
So now, what I can do --

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:07.763
I can augment the world around me
with this digital information.

00:05:08.616 --> 00:05:09.834
But later,

00:05:09.858 --> 00:05:12.017
I realized that I actually
wanted to interact

00:05:12.041 --> 00:05:13.634
with those digital pixels, also.

00:05:13.658 --> 00:05:16.934
So I put a small camera over there
that acts as a digital eye.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.934
Later, we moved to a much better,

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
consumer-oriented pendant version of that,

00:05:20.982 --> 00:05:23.934
that many of you now know
as the SixthSense device.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.934
But the most interesting thing
about this particular technology

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.934
is that you can carry
your digital world with you

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.934
wherever you go.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.934
You can start using any surface,
any wall around you,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.934
as an interface.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.934
The camera is actually tracking
all your gestures.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.934
Whatever you're doing with your hands,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.934
it's understanding that gesture.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.534
And, actually, if you see,
there are some color markers

00:05:47.558 --> 00:05:50.034
that in the beginning version
we are using with it.

00:05:50.058 --> 00:05:51.934
You can start painting on any wall.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.934
You stop by a wall,
and start painting on that wall.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.101
But we are not only tracking
one finger, here.

00:05:57.125 --> 00:06:00.934
We are giving you the freedom
of using all of both of your hands,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:04.101
so you can actually use both of your hands
to zoom into or zoom out

00:06:04.125 --> 00:06:06.101
of a map just by pinching all present.

00:06:06.125 --> 00:06:09.934
The camera is actually doing --
just, getting all the images --

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.934
is doing the edge recognition
and also the color recognition

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.934
and so many other small algorithms
are going on inside.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
So, technically,
it's a little bit complex,

00:06:17.982 --> 00:06:21.458
but it gives you an output which is more
intuitive to use, in some sense.

00:06:21.482 --> 00:06:24.334
But I'm more excited that you can
actually take it outside.

00:06:24.358 --> 00:06:26.934
Rather than getting your camera
out of your pocket,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.934
you can just do the gesture
of taking a photo,

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.934
and it takes a photo for you.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.934
(Applause)

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:36.958
Thank you.

00:06:37.557 --> 00:06:39.934
And later I can find a wall, anywhere,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.934
and start browsing those photos

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.634
or maybe, "OK, I want to modify
this photo a little bit

00:06:44.658 --> 00:06:46.644
and send it as an email to a friend."

00:06:46.668 --> 00:06:48.934
So, we are looking for an era

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.934
where computing will actually merge
with the physical world.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.934
And, of course,
if you don't have any surface,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.934
you can start using your palm
for simple operations.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.435
Here, I'm dialing a phone number
just using my hand.

00:07:03.838 --> 00:07:06.934
The camera is actually not
only understanding your hand movements,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.134
but, interestingly,

00:07:08.158 --> 00:07:11.397
is also able to understand what objects
you are holding in your hand.

00:07:11.967 --> 00:07:15.934
For example, in this case,

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.934
the book cover is matched

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.934
with so many thousands,
or maybe millions of books online,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.934
and checking out which book it is.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.434
Once it has that information,

00:07:24.458 --> 00:07:26.334
it finds out more reviews about that,

00:07:26.358 --> 00:07:28.934
or maybe New York Times
has a sound overview on that,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.054
so you can actually hear,
on a physical book,

00:07:31.078 --> 00:07:32.934
a review as sound.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.934
back to my desktop

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.934
so I can use my full-size computer.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.934
(Applause)

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.934
And why only computers?
We can just play with papers.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.934
Paper world is interesting to play with.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.934
Here, I'm taking a part of a document,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:25.934
and putting over here a second part
from a second place,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:30.934
and I'm actually modifying the information
that I have over there.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:35.934
Yeah. And I say, "OK, this looks nice,
let me print it out, that thing."

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.339
So I now have a print-out of that thing.

00:10:38.363 --> 00:10:40.687
So the workflow is more intuitive,

00:10:40.711 --> 00:10:43.934
the way we used to do it
maybe 20 years back,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.934
rather than now switching
between these two worlds.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.934
So, as a last thought,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:54.334
I think that integrating
information to everyday objects

00:10:54.358 --> 00:10:57.934
will not only help us to get rid
of the digital divide,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.934
the gap between these two worlds,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.934
but will also help us, in some way,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.934
to stay human,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
to be more connected
to our physical world.

00:11:10.366 --> 00:11:12.934
And it will actually help us
not end up being machines

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.676
sitting in front of other machines.

00:11:15.465 --> 00:11:17.934
That's all. Thank you.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:31.934
(Applause)

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.134
Thank you.

00:11:33.158 --> 00:11:35.934
(Applause)

Chris Anderson: So, Pranav,
first of all, you're a genius.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.934
This is incredible, really.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.058

Is there a company being planned?

00:11:46.082 --> 00:11:47.934
Or is this research forever, or what?

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.234

lots of companies,

00:11:50.258 --> 00:11:53.254
sponsor companies of Media Lab
interested in taking this ahead

00:11:53.278 --> 00:11:54.464
in one or another way.

Companies like mobile-phone operators

want to take this in a different way
than the NGOs in India,

thinking, "Why can we only

We should have a 'Fifth Sense'

title: Science-inspired design
transcript: One morning, in the year 1957, the neurosurgeon Wilder Penfield saw himself like this, a weird freak with huge hands, huge mouth, and a tiny bottom. Actually this creature is the result of the Penfield research. He named it homunculus. Basically the homunculus is the visualization of a human being where each part of the body is proportional to the surface it takes in the brain. So, of course, homunculus is definitely not a freak. It's you. It's me. It's our invisible reality. This visualization could explain, for example, why newborns, or smokers, put, instinctively, their fingers in the mouth. Unfortunately it doesn't explain why so many designers remain mainly interested in designing chairs.So anyway, even if I do not understand science entirely, for my design I essentially refer to it. I'm fascinated by its ability to deeply investigate the human being, its way of working, its way of feeling. And it really helps me to understand how we see, how we hear, how we breathe, how our brain can inform or mislead us. It's a great tool for me to understand what could be our real needs.Marketing people have never been able to do that. Marketing reduces things. Marketing simplifies. Marketing creates user groups. And scientists, amidst complexity, amidst fluctuation and uniqueness. What could be our real needs? Maybe the silence. In our daily life we are continuously disturbed by aggressive sounds. And you know all those kind of sound puts us in a kind of stressful state, and prevent us from being quiet and focused. So I wanted to create a kind of sound filter, able to preserve ourselves from noise pollution. But I didn't want it to make it by isolating people, without any earmuffs or those kind of things. Or neither with including complex technology. I just wanted to, using the complexity and the technology of the brain, of the human brain.So I worked with white noise. dB is basically — dB is the name of the product, basically a white noise diffuser. This is white noise. The white noise is the sum of all frequencies that are audible by the human being, brought to the same intensity. And this noise is like a "shhhhhhhhhhhhh," like that. And this noise is the most neutral. It is the perfect sound for our ears and our brain. So when you hear this sound you feel like a kind of shelter, preserved from noise pollution. And when you hear the white noise, your brain is immediately focused on it. And do not be disturbed any more by the other aggressive sound. It seems to be magic. But it is just physiology. It's just in your brain. And in mine, I hope.So in order to make this white noise a little bit active and reactive, I create a ball, a rolling ball able to analyze and find where does aggressive sound come from, and roll, at home or at work, towards aggressive noise, and emits white noise in order to neutralize it. (Laughter) It works. You feel the effect of the white noise? It's too in silence. If you make some noise you can feel the effect.So even if this object, even if this product includes some technology, it includes some speakers, it includes some microphones and some electronic devices, this object is not a very smart object. And I don't want to make a very smart object. I don't want to create a perfect object like a perfect robot. I want to create an object like you and me. So, definitely not perfect. So imagine, for instance, you are at home. A loving dispute with your girl or boyfriend. You shout. You say, "Blah blah blah, Blah blah blah. Who is this guy?" And dB will probably roll toward you. And turning around you is "shhhhhhh," like that. (Laughter) Definitely not perfect. So you would probably shut it, at this point. (Laughter)Anyway, in this same kind of approach, I designed K. K is a daylight receiver transmitter. So this object is supposed to be displayed on your desk, or on your piano, where you are supposed to spend most of your time in the day. And this object will be able to know exactly the quantity of light you receive during the day, and able to give you the quantity of light you need. This object is completely covered by fiber opticals. And the idea of those fiber opticals is to inform the object, for sure, but creates the idea of an eye sensibility of the object. I want, by this design feel, when you see it, you see, instinctively, this object seems to be very sensitive, very reactive. And this object knows, better than you and probably before you, what you really need. You have to know that the lack of daylight can provoke some problem of energy, or problem of libido. So, a huge problem. (Laughter)Most of the projects I work on — I live in collaboration with scientists. I'm just a designer. So I need them. So there can be some biologists, psychiatrists, mathematicians, and so on. And I submit them, my intuitions, my hypothesis, my first ideas. And they react. They told me what is possible, what is impossible. And together we improve the original concept. And we build the project to the end. And this kind of relationship between designer and scientist started when I was at school.Indeed in my studies I was a guinea pig for a pharmaceutical industry. And the irony for me was of course, I didn't do that for the sake of science progress. I just do that to make money. Anyway, this project, or this experience, make me start a new project on the design of medicine. You have to know that today, roughly one or two every drug pills is not taken correctly. So even if the active constituents in pharmaceuticals made constant progress in terms of chemistry, target of stability, the behavior of the patients goes more and more unstable. So we took too many of them. We took irregular dosage. We do not follow instructions. And so on.So I wanted to create a new kind of medicine, in order to create a new kind of relationship between the patient and the treatment. So I turned traditional pills into this. I'm going to give you some example. This one is an antibiotic. And its purpose is to help patient to go to the end of the treatment. And the concept is to create a kind of onion, a kind of structure in layers. So, you start with the darkest one. And you are helped to visualize the duration of the treatment. And you are helped to visualize the decrease of the infection. So the first day, this is the big one. And you have to peel and eat one layer a day. And your antibiotic goes smaller and clearer. And you're waiting for recovery as you were waiting for the Christmas day. And you follow the treatment like that, to the end of the treatment. And here you can get the white core. And it means, right, you are in the recovery. (Applause) Thank you.This one is a "third lung," a pharmaceutical device for long-term asthma treatment. I designed it to help kids to follow the treatment. So the idea of this one is to create a relationship between the patient of the treatment but a relationship of dependency. But in this case it is not the medication that is dependent on the patient. This is, the kids will feel the therapeutic object needs him. So the idea is, all night long the elastic skin of the third lung will slowly inflate itself, including air and molecules, for sure. And when the kids wake up, he can see the object needs him. And he take him to his mouth, and breathe the air it contains. So by this way, the kid, to take care of himself, is to take care of this living object. And he does not feel anymore it's relies on asthma treatment, as the asthma treatment needs him. (Applause)In this guise of living object approach, I like the idea of a kind of invisible design, as if the function of the object exists in a kind of invisible field just around the objects themselves. We could talk about a kind of soul, of a ghost accompanying them. And almost a kind of poltergeist effect. So when a passive object like this one seems to be alive, because it is — woosh — starting to move.And I remember an exhibition design I made for John Maeda, and for the Fondation Cartier in Paris. And John Maeda was supposed to show several graphic animations in this exhibition. And my idea for this exhibition design was to create a real pong game, like this one. And the idea was to create some self-moving benches in the main exhibition room. So the living benches would be exactly like the ball. And John was so excited by this idea. He said to me, "Okay let's go." I remember the day of the opening. I was a little bit late. When I bring the 10 living and self-moving benches in the exhibition room, John was just beside me, and was like, "Hmm. Hmm." And he told me, after a long silence, "I wonder, Mathieu, if people won't be more fascinated by your benches than by my videos." (Laughter) It would be a great honor, a great compliment for me, if he hadn't decided to take all them off two hours before the opening. So, huge tragedy.I guess you won't be surprised if I tell you that Pinocchio is one of my great influences. Pinocchio is probably one of my best design products, my favorite one. Because it is a kind of object with a conscience, able to be modified by its surroundings, and able to modify it as well. The other great influence is the mine's canary. In coal mines, this canary was supposed to be close to the miners. And it was singing all day long. And when it stops it means that it just died. So this canary was a living alarm, and a very efficient one. A very natural technology, in order to say to the miners, "The air is too bad. You have to go. It's an emergency." So it's, for me, a great product.And I tried to design a kind of canary. Andrea is one. Andrea is a living air filter that absorbs toxic gasses from air, contaminated indoor air. So it uses some plants to do this job, selected for their gas-filtering ability. You have to know, or you probably already know, that indoor air pollution is more toxic than outdoor one. So while I'm talking to you, the seats you are sitting on are currently emitting some invisible and odorless toxic gas. Sorry for that. (Laughter) So you are currently breathing formaldehyde. It's the same for me with the carpet. And this is exactly the same at home. Because all the product we get constantly give away the volatile component of which they're made of.So let's have a look at your home. So your sofa, your plastic chair, your kid's toys give their own invisible reality. And this one is very toxic. This is the reason why I created, with David Edward, a scientist of Harvard University, an object able to absorb the toxic elements using those kind of plants. But the idea is to force the air to go in the effective part of the plants. Because the roots of the plant are not very effective. Bill Wolverton from NASA analyzed it cleverly in the '70s. So the idea is to create an object able to force the air, and to be in contact at the right speed at the right place, in all the effective parts of the plant. So this is the final object. It will be launched next September. (Applause)This one is kind of the same approach because I include, in a product like Andrea, some plants. And in this one, plants are used for the water filtration ability. And it includes some fishes as well. But here, unlike Andrea, here are supposed to be eaten. Indeed, this object is a domestic farm, for fishes and green. So the idea of this object is to be able to get at home very local food. The locavores used to get food taken in a radius of 100 miles. Local River is able to provide you food directly in your living room. So the principle of this object is to create an ecosystem called aquaponics. And the aquaponics is the dirty water of the fish, by a water pump, feeds the plants above. And the plants will filter, by the roots, the dirty water of the fish. After, it goes back into the fish tank.After that you have two options. Or you sit down in front of it like you would do in front your TV set. Amazing channel. Or you start fishing. And you make some sushis with a fish and the aromatic plants above. Because you can grow some potatoes. No, not potatoes, but tomatoes, aromatic plants and so on.So now we can breathe safely. Now we can eat local food. Now we can be treated by smart medicine. Now we can be well-balanced in our biorhythm with daylight. But it was important to create a perfect place, so I tried to, in order to work and create. So I designed, for an American scientist based in Paris, a very stimulative, brain-stimulative office. I wanted to create a perfect place where you can work and play, and where your body and your brain can work together.So, in this office, you do not work anymore at your desk, like a politician. Your seat, your sleep and your play on a big geodesic island made of leather. See, like this one? In this office you do not work and write and draw on a sheet of paper, but you draw directly on a kind of huge whiteboard cave, like a prehistoric scientist. So you, like that, can make some sport during your work. In this office you do not need to go out in order to be in contact with nature. You include, directly, the nature in the floor of the office. You can see it there.This is an inspiration image to lead this project of the office. It really helped me to design it. I never show it to my client. He would be so afraid. (Laughter) Just for my workshop. I guess it may be the revenge of the guinea pig I was. But it's maybe the conviction as monkey and homunculus we are. All of us need to be considered according to our real nature. Thank you very much. (Applause)

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:02.958
And turning around you is "shhhhhhh," like that.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:03.958
(Laughter)

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
Definitely not perfect. So you would probably

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
shut it, at this point.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
(Laughter)

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
Anyway, in this same kind of approach,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
I designed K.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
K is a daylight receiver transmitter.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
So this object is supposed to be displayed on your desk,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
or on your piano, where you are supposed

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
to spend most of your time in the day.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
And this object will be

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
able to know exactly the quantity of light you receive during the day,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:33.958
and able to give you the quantity of light you need.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
This object is completely covered by

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
fiber opticals.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
And the idea of those fiber opticals is to inform the object, for sure,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
but creates the idea of an

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
eye sensibility of the object.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
I want, by this design

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
feel, when you see it,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
you see, instinctively,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
this object seems to be very sensitive,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
very reactive.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
And this object knows, better than you

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
and probably before you, what you really need.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
You have to know that the lack of daylight

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
can provoke some

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
problem of energy, or problem of libido.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
So, a huge problem.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:13.958
(Laughter)

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
Most of the projects I work on --

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
I live in collaboration with scientists.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
I'm just a designer. So I need them.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
So there can be some biologists,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
psychiatrists, mathematicians, and so on.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
And I submit them, my intuitions,

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
my hypothesis, my first ideas.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
And they react. They told me what is possible, what is impossible.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:36.958
And together we improve the original concept.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
And we build the project to the end.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
And this kind of relationship between designer and scientist

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
started when I was at school.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
Indeed in my studies I was a guinea pig

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
for a pharmaceutical industry.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
And the irony for me was

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
of course, I didn't do that for the sake of science progress.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
I just do that to make money.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
Anyway, this project, or this experience,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
make me start a new project on the design of medicine.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:08.958
You have to know that today, roughly one or two every drug pills

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
is not taken correctly.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:14.958
So even if the active constituents

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
in pharmaceuticals made constant progress

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
in terms of chemistry, target of stability,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
the behavior of the patients

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
goes more and more unstable.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
So we took too many of them.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
We took irregular dosage.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
We do not follow instructions. And so on.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
So I wanted to create a

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
new kind of medicine,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
in order to create a new kind of relationship

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
between the patient and the treatment.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
So I turned traditional pills into this.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
I'm going to give you some example.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
This one is an antibiotic.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
And its purpose is to help patient

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
to go to the end of the treatment.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
And the concept is to

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
create a kind of onion,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
a kind of structure in layers.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
So, you start with the darkest one.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:10.958
And you are helped to visualize the duration of the treatment.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
And you are helped to visualize the decrease of the infection.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
So the first day, this is the big one.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:21.958
And you have to peel and eat one layer a day.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
And your antibiotic goes smaller and clearer.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
And you're waiting for recovery as you were waiting for the Christmas day.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
And you follow the treatment like that,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
to the end of the treatment.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
And here you can get the white core.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:41.958
And it means, right, you are in the recovery.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
(Applause) Thank you.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
This one is a "third lung,"

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:50.958
a pharmaceutical device for long-term asthma treatment.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
I designed it to help kids to follow the treatment.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
So the idea of this one is to create

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
a relationship between the patient of the treatment

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
but a relationship of dependency.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:05.958
But in this case it is not the medication that is dependent on the patient.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:09.958
This is, the kids will feel

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
the therapeutic object needs him.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
So the idea is, all night long

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
the elastic skin of the third lung

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
will slowly inflate itself,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
including air and molecules, for sure.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
And when the kids wake up,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
he can see the object needs him. And he take him to his mouth,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
and breathe the air it contains.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
So by this way,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:35.958
the kid, to take care of himself,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
is to take care of this living object.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
And he does not feel anymore it's relies on asthma treatment,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
as the asthma treatment needs him.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
(Applause)

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
In this guise of living object approach,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
I like the idea of a kind of invisible design,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
as if the function of the object

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
exists in a kind of invisible field

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
just around the objects themselves.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
We could talk about a kind of soul,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
of a ghost accompanying them.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:13.958
And almost a kind of poltergeist effect.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
So when a passive object like this one seems to be alive,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
because it is -- woosh -- starting to move.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
And I remember an exhibition design

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
I made for John Maeda,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
and for the Fondation Cartier in Paris.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
And John Maeda was supposed to show

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
several graphic animations in this exhibition.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
And my idea for this exhibition design was to create

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
a real pong game, like this one.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
And the idea was to create some self-moving benches

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
in the main exhibition room.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
So the living benches would be exactly like the ball.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:50.958
And John was so excited by this idea. He said to me, "Okay let's go."

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
I remember the day of the opening.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
I was a little bit late.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:59.958
When I bring the 10 living and self-moving benches

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:03.958
in the exhibition room, John was just beside me,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:08.958
and was like, "Hmm. Hmm."

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
And he told me, after a long silence,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
"I wonder, Mathieu, if

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
people won't be more fascinated by your benches

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
than by my videos."

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
(Laughter)

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
It would be a great honor, a great compliment for me,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
if he hadn't decided to take all them off

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
two hours before the opening.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
So, huge tragedy.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
I guess you won't be surprised if I tell you

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
that Pinocchio is one of my great influences.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:41.958
Pinocchio is probably one of my best design products, my favorite one.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
Because it is a kind of object with a conscience,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
able to be modified by its surroundings,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
and able to modify it as well.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
The other great influence is the mine's canary.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
In coal mines, this canary

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
was supposed to be close to the miners.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
And it was singing all day long. And when it stops it means that it just died.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:05.958
So this canary was a living alarm,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
and a very efficient one.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
A very natural technology,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
in order to say to the miners,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:17.958
"The air is too bad. You have to go. It's an emergency."

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
So it's, for me, a great product.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And I tried to design a kind of canary.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
Andrea is one.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
Andrea is a living air filter that absorbs toxic gasses

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958
from air, contaminated indoor air.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
So it uses some plants to do this job,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:39.958
selected for their gas-filtering ability.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
You have to know, or you probably already know,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
that indoor air pollution is more toxic than outdoor one.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
So while I'm talking to you,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
the seats you are sitting on are currently emitting some

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:55.958
invisible and odorless toxic gas. Sorry for that. (Laughter)

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:59.958
So you are currently breathing formaldehyde.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
It's the same for me with the carpet.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:06.958
And this is exactly the same at home.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
Because all the product we get constantly give away

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
the volatile component of which they're made of.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
So let's have a look at your home.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
So your sofa, your plastic chair,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
your kid's toys

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
give their own invisible reality. And this one is very toxic.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
This is the reason why

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
I created, with David Edward,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
a scientist of Harvard University,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:52.958
an object able to absorb the toxic elements using those kind of plants.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
But the idea is to force

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
the air to go in the effective part of the plants.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
Because the roots of the plant are not very effective.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
Bill Wolverton from NASA

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:06.958
analyzed it cleverly in the '70s.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
So the idea is to create an object

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:12.958
able to force the air, and to be in contact at the right speed

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
at the right place, in all the effective parts of the plant.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
So this is the final object.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
It will be launched next September.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
(Applause)

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
This one is kind of the same approach

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
because I include, in a product

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
like Andrea, some plants.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:36.958
And in this one, plants are used for the water filtration ability.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
And it includes some fishes as well.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
But here, unlike Andrea,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
here are supposed to be eaten.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
Indeed, this object is a domestic farm,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
for fishes and green.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
So the idea of this object

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
is to be able to get at home

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
very local food.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
The locavores

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
used to get food

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
taken in a radius of 100 miles.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
Local River is able to provide you

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
food directly in your living room.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
So the principle of this object

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
is to create an ecosystem

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
called aquaponics.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
And the aquaponics is the dirty water of the fish,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
by a water pump, feeds the plants above.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
And the plants will filter, by the roots,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
the dirty water of the fish.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:29.958
After, it goes back into the fish tank.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
After that you have two options.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
Or you sit down in front of it like you would do in front your TV set.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
Amazing channel.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
Or you start fishing.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
And you make some sushis with a fish

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
and the aromatic plants above.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
Because you can grow some potatoes.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
No, not potatoes, but tomatoes,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
aromatic plants and so on.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
So now we can breathe safely.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Now we can eat local food.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
Now we can be treated by smart medicine.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
Now we can be well-balanced in our biorhythm

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
with daylight.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
But it was important to create a perfect place,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
so I tried to,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
in order to work and create.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
So I designed, for an American scientist based in Paris,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
a very stimulative, brain-stimulative office.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
I wanted to create a perfect place

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
where you can work and play,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
and where your body and your brain can work together.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
So, in this office,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:33.958
you do not work anymore at your desk, like a politician.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:37.958
Your seat, your sleep and your play

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:41.958
on a big geodesic island made of leather.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
See, like this one?

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:48.958
In this office you do not work and write and draw on a sheet of paper,

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:53.958
but you draw directly on a kind of huge whiteboard cave,

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
like a prehistoric scientist.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:59.958
So you, like that, can make some sport during your work.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:03.958
In this office

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
you do not need to go out

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
in order to be in contact with nature.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:13.958
You include, directly, the nature in the floor of the office.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
You can see it there.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
This is an inspiration image

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
to lead this project of the office.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
It really helped me to design it.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
I never show it to my client. He would be so afraid.

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:26.958
(Laughter)

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
Just for my workshop.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:33.958
I guess it may be the revenge of the guinea pig I was.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:37.958
But it's maybe the conviction

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:41.958
as monkey and homunculus we are.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:47.958
All of us need to be considered according to our real nature.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:54.958
(Applause)

title: Learning from leadership's missing manual
transcript: I'm going to talk about some of my discoveries around the world through my work. These are not discoveries of planets or new technologies or science. They're discoveries of people and the way people are, and new leadership.This is Benki. Benki is a leader of the Ashaninka Nation. His people live in Brazil and in Peru. Benki comes from a village so remote up in the Amazon that to get there, either you have to fly and land on water, or go by canoe for several days. I met Benki three years ago in Sao Paulo when I'd brought him and other leaders from indigenous peoples to meet with me and leaders from around the world, because we wanted to learn from each other. We wanted to share our stories with each other.The Ashaninka people are known throughout South America for their dignity, their spirit and their resistance, starting with the Incas and continuing through the 19th century with the rubber tappers. Today's biggest threat to the Ashaninka people and to Benki comes from illegal logging — the people who come into the beautiful forest and cut down ancient mahogany trees, float them down the river to world markets. Benki knew this. He could see what was happening to his forest, to his environment, because he was taken under his grandfather's wing when he was only two years old to begin to learn about the forest and the way of life of his people. His grandfather died when he was only 10. And at that young age, 10 years old, Benki became the paje of his community. Now, in the Ashaninka tradition and culture, the paje is the most important person in the community. This is the person who contains within him all the knowledge, all the wisdom of centuries and centuries of life, and not just about his people, but about everything that his people's survival depended on: the trees, the birds, the water, the soil, the forest. So when he was only 10 and he became the paje, he began to lead his people. He began to talk to them about the forest that they needed to protect, the way of life they needed to nurture. He explained to them that it was not a question of survival of the fittest; it was a question of understanding what they needed to survive and to protect that.Eight years later, when he was a young man of 18, Benki left the forest for the first time. He went 3,000 miles on an odyssey to Rio to the Earth Summit to tell the world what was happening in his tiny, little corner. And he went because he hoped the world would listen. Some did, not everybody. But if you can imagine this young man with his headdress and his flowing robe, learning a new language, Portuguese, not to mention English, going to Rio, building a bridge to reach out to people he'd never met before — a pretty hostile world. But he wasn't dismayed.Benki came back to his village full of ideas — new technologies, new research, new ways of understanding what was going on. Since that time, he's continued to work with his people, and not only the Ashaninka Nation, but all the peoples of the Amazon and beyond. He's built schools to teach children to care for the forest. Together, he's led the reforestation of over 25 percent of the land that had been destroyed by the loggers. He's created a cooperative to help people diversify their livelihoods. And he's brought the internet and satellite technology to the forest — both so that people themselves could monitor the deforestation, but also that he could speak from the forest to the rest of the world. If you were to meet Benki and ask him, "Why are you doing this? Why are you putting yourself at risk? Why are you making yourself vulnerable to what is often a hostile world?" he would tell you, as he told me, "I asked myself," he said, "What did my grandparents and my great-grandparents do to protect the forest for me? And what am I doing?"So when I think of that, I wonder what our grandchildren and our great-grandchildren, when they ask themselves that question, I wonder how they will answer. For me, the world is veering towards a future we don't much want when we really think about it deep inside. It's a future we don't know the details of, but it's a future that has signs, just like Benki saw the signs around him. We know we are running out of what we need. We're running out of fresh water. We're running out of fossil fuels. We're running out of land. We know climate change is going to affect all of us. We don't know how, but we know it will. And we know that there will be more of us than ever before — five times as many people in 40 years than 60 years ago. We are running out of what we need. And we also know that the world has changed in other ways, that since 1960 there are one-third as many new countries that exist as independent entities on the planet. Egos, systems of government — figuring it out — massive change. And in addition to that, we know that five other really big countries are going to have a say in the future, a say we haven't even really started to hear yet — China, India, Russia, South Africa and Benki's own Brazil, where Benki got his civil rights only in the 1988 constitution.But you know all that. You know more than Benki knew when he left his forest and went 3,000 miles. You also know that we can't just keep doing what we've always done, because we'll get the results we've always gotten. And this reminds me of something I understand Lord Salisbury said to Queen Victoria over a hundred years ago, when she was pressing him, "Please change." He said, "Change? Why change? Things are bad enough as they are." We have to change. It's imperative to me, when I look around the world, that we need to change ourselves. We need new models of what it means to be a leader. We need new models of being a leader and a human in the world.I started life as a banker. Now I don't admit to that to anybody but my very close friends. But for the past eight years, I've done something completely different. My work has taken me around the world, where I've had the real privilege of meeting people like Benki and many others who are making change happen in their communities — people who see the world differently, who are asking different questions, who have different answers, who understand the filters that they wear when they go out into the world.This is Sanghamitra. Sanghamitra comes from Bangalore. I met Sanghamitra eight years ago when I was in Bangalore organizing a workshop with leaders of different NGO's working in some of the hardest aspects of society. Sanghamitra didn't start life as a leader of an NGO, she started her career as university professor, teaching English literature. But she realized that she was much too detached from the world doing that. She loved it, but she was too detached. And so in 1993, a long time ago, she decided to start a new organization called Samraksha focused on one of the hardest areas, one of the hardest issues in India — anywhere in the world at the time — HIV/AIDS. Since that time, Samraksha has grown from strength to strength and is now one of the leading health NGO's in India. But if you just think about the state of the world and knowledge of HIV/AIDS in 1993 — in India at that time it was skyrocketing and nobody understood why, and everyone was actually very, very afraid. Today there are still three million HIV-positive people in India. That's the second largest population in the world.When I asked Sanghamitra, "How did you get from English literature to HIV/AIDS?" not an obvious path, she said to me, "It's all connected. Literature makes one sensitive, sensitive to people, to their dreams and to their ideas." Since that time, under her leadership, Samraksha has been a pioneer in all fields related to HIV/AIDS. They have respite homes, the first, the first care centers, the first counseling services — and not just in urban, 7-million-population Bangalore, but in the hardest to reach villages in the state of Karnataka. Even that wasn't enough. She wanted to change policy at the government level. 10 of their programs that she pioneered are now government policy and funded by the government. They take care of 20,000-odd people today in over 1,000 villages around Karnataka.She works with people like Murali Krishna. Murali Krishna comes from one of those villages. He lost his wife to AIDS a couple of years ago, and he's HIV-positive. But he saw the work, the care, the compassion that Sanghamitra and her team brought to the village, and he wanted to be part of it. He's a Leaders' Quest fellow, and that helps him with his work. They've pioneered a different approach to villages. Instead of handing out information in pamphlets, as is so often the case, they bring theater troupes, songs, music, dance. And they sit around, and they talk about dreams.Sanghamitra told me just last week — she had just come back from two weeks in the villages, and she had a real breakthrough. They were sitting in a circle, talking about the dreams for the village. And the young women in the village spoke up and said, "We've changed our dream. Our dream is for our partners, our husbands, not to be given to us because of a horoscope, but to be given to us because they've been tested for HIV." If you are lucky enough to meet Sanghamitra and ask her why and how, how have you achieved so much? She would look at you and very quietly, very softly say, "It just happened. It's the spirit inside."This is Dr. Fan Jianchuan. Jianchuan comes from Sichuan Province in southwest China. He was born in 1957, and you can imagine what his childhood looked like and felt like, and what his life has been like over the last 50 tumultuous years. He's been a soldier, a teacher, a politician, a vice-mayor and a business man. But if you sat down and asked him, "Who are you really, and what do you do?" He would tell you, "I'm a collector, and I curate a museum." I was lucky; I had heard about him for years, and I finally met him earlier this year at his museum in Chengdu.He's been a collector all of his life, starting when he was four or five in the early 1960's. Now, just think of the early 1960's in China. Over a lifetime, through everything, through the Cultural Revolution and everything afterward, he's kept collecting, so that he now has over eight million pieces in his museums documenting contemporary Chinese history. These are pieces that you won't find anywhere else in the world, in part because they document parts of history Chinese choose to forget. For example, he's got over one million pieces documenting the Sino-Japanese War, a war that's not talked about in China very much and whose heroes are not honored. Why did he do all this? Because he thought a nation should never repeat the mistakes of the past.So, from commissioning slightly larger than life bronze statues of the heroes of the Sino-Japanese War, including those Chinese who then fought with each other and left mainland China to go to Taiwan, to commemorating all the unknown, ordinary soldiers who survived, by asking them to take prints of their hands, he is making sure — one man is making sure — that history is not forgotten. But it's not just Chinese heroes he cares about. This building contains the world's largest collection of documents and artifacts commemorating the U.S. role in fighting on the Chinese side in that long war — the Flying Tigers. He has nine other buildings — that are already open to the public — filled to the rafters with artifacts documenting contemporary Chinese history. Two of the most sensitive buildings include a lifetime of collection about the Cultural Revolution, a period that actually most Chinese would prefer to forget. But he doesn't want his nation ever to forget.These people inspire me, and they inspire me because they show us what is possible when you change the way you look at the world, change the way you look at your place in the world. They looked outside, and then they changed what was on the inside. They didn't go to business school. They didn't read a manual, "How to Be a Good Leader in 10 Easy Steps." But they have qualities we'd all recognize. They have drive, passion, commitment. They've gone away from what they did before, and they've gone to something they didn't know. They've tried to connect worlds they didn't know existed before. They've built bridges, and they've walked across them. They have a sense of the great arc of time and their tiny place in it. They know people have come before them and will follow them. And they know that they're part of a whole, that they depend on other people. It's not about them, they know that, but it has to start with them. And they have humility. It just happens.But we know it doesn't just happen, don't we? We know it takes a lot to make it happen, and we know the direction the world is going in. So I think we need succession planning on a global basis. We can't wait for the next generation, the new joiners, to come in and learn how to be the good leaders we need. I think it has to start with us. And we know, just like they knew, how hard it is. But the good news is that we don't have to figure it out as we go along; we have models, we have examples, like Benki and Sanghamitra and Jianchuan. We can look at what they've done, if we look. We can learn from what they've learned. We can change the way we see ourselves in the world. And if we're lucky, we can change the way our great-grandchildren will answer Benki's question.Thank you.(Applause)

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
I'm going to talk

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:15.958
about some of my discoveries

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:17.958
around the world through my work.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:19.958
These are not discoveries of planets

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:21.958
or new technologies

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:23.958
or science.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:25.958
They're discoveries of people

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
and the way people are, and new leadership.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
This is Benki.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
Benki is a leader of the Ashaninka Nation.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
His people live in Brazil

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
and in Peru.

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
Benki comes from a village

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
so remote up in the Amazon

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
that to get there, either you have to fly

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
and land on water,

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
or go by canoe for several days.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958
I met Benki three years ago in Sao Paulo

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
when I'd brought him and other leaders

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
from indigenous peoples

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
to meet with me and leaders from around the world,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
because we wanted to learn from each other.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:04.958
We wanted to share our stories with each other.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
The Ashaninka people

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
are known throughout South America

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
for their dignity, their spirit

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
and their resistance,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
starting with the Incas

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
and continuing through the 19th century

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
with the rubber tappers.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
Today's biggest threat to the Ashaninka people

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
and to Benki

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
comes from illegal logging --

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
the people who come into the beautiful forest

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
and cut down ancient mahogany trees,

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:36.958
float them down the river to world markets.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
Benki knew this.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
He could see what was happening to his forest, to his environment,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
because he was taken under his grandfather's wing

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
when he was only two years old

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
to begin to learn about the forest

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
and the way of life of his people.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
His grandfather died when he was only 10.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
And at that young age, 10 years old,

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.958
Benki became the paje of his community.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
Now, in the Ashaninka tradition and culture,

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
the paje is the most important

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
person in the community.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:11.958
This is the person who contains within him

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
all the knowledge, all the wisdom

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:17.958
of centuries and centuries of life,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
and not just about his people,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
but about everything that his people's survival depended on:

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
the trees, the birds,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.958
the water, the soil, the forest.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:31.958
So when he was only 10 and he became the paje,

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
he began to lead his people.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
He began to talk to them

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.958
about the forest that they needed to protect,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:41.958
the way of life they needed to nurture.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
He explained to them

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:46.958
that it was not a question of survival of the fittest;

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
it was a question of understanding

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
what they needed to survive

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
and to protect that.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
Eight years later,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
when he was a young man of 18,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
Benki left the forest for the first time.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:03.958
He went 3,000 miles on an odyssey to Rio

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
to the Earth Summit

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
to tell the world what was happening

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
in his tiny, little corner.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:12.958
And he went because he hoped the world would listen.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
Some did, not everybody.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
But if you can imagine this young man

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
with his headdress and his flowing robe,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
learning a new language, Portuguese,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
not to mention English,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
going to Rio,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
building a bridge

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
to reach out to people he'd never met before --

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
a pretty hostile world.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
But he wasn't dismayed.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
Benki came back to his village full of ideas --

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
new technologies, new research,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
new ways of understanding what was going on.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
Since that time,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
he's continued to work with his people,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
and not only the Ashaninka Nation,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
but all the peoples of the Amazon and beyond.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
He's built schools

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
to teach children to care for the forest.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
Together, he's led the reforestation

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
of over 25 percent of the land

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
that had been destroyed by the loggers.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
to help people diversify their livelihoods.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
to the forest --

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
both so that people themselves

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
could monitor the deforestation,

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
but also that he could speak from the forest

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
to the rest of the world.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
If you were to meet Benki

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
and ask him, "Why are you doing this?

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
Why are you putting yourself at risk?

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
Why are you making yourself vulnerable

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
to what is often a hostile world?"

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
he would tell you,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
as he told me,

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
"I asked myself," he said,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
"What did my grandparents and my great-grandparents do

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
to protect the forest for me?

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
And what am I doing?"

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
So when I think of that,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
I wonder what our grandchildren

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
and our great-grandchildren,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
when they ask themselves that question,

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
I wonder how they will answer.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
For me, the world is veering

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
towards a future we don't much want

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
when we really think about it deep inside.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
It's a future we don't know the details of,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
but it's a future that has signs,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
just like Benki saw the signs around him.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
We know we are running out of what we need.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
We're running out of fresh water.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
We're running out of fossil fuels.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
We're running out of land.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:30.958
We know climate change is going to affect all of us.

We don't know how, but we know it will.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
And we know that there will be more of us than ever before --

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
Egos, systems of government --

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
massive change.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
Lord Salisbury said to Queen Victoria over a hundred years ago,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
