00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:04.958
And on that axis I have life expectancy, the health of people.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
And I also bring an innovation here.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
I have transformed the laser beam

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:14.958
into an ecological, recyclable version here, in green India.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.958
(Applause)

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And we will see, you know.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
Look here, 1858, India was here,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
China was here, Japan was there,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
United States and United Kingdom

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
was richer over there.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And I will start the world like this.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
India was not always like this level.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
Actually if we go back into the historical record,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
there was a time hundreds of years ago

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
when the income per person in India and China

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
was even above that of Europe.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:47.958
But 1850 had already been many, many years of foreign domination,

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
and India had been de-industrialized.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
And you can see that the countries who were growing

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
their economy was United States and United Kingdom.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And they were also, by the end of the century, getting healthy,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
and Japan was starting to catch up.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
India was trying down here.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
Can you see how it starts to move there?

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:07.958
But really, really natural sovereignty was good for Japan.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
And Japan is trying to move up there.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
And it's the new century now. Health is getting better,

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
United Kingdom, United States.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
But careful now -- we are approaching the First World War.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
And the First World War, you know,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.958
we'll see a lot of deaths and economical problems here.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
United Kingdom is going down.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
And now comes the Spanish flu also.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
And then after the First World War, they continue up.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Still under foreign domination, and without sovereignty,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
India and China are down in the corner.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
Not much has happened.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
They have grown their population but not much more.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
In the 1930's now, you can see

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
that Japan is going to a period of war,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
with lower life expectancy.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
And the Second World War was really a terrible event,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
also economically for Japan.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
But they did recover quite fast afterwards.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
And we are moving into the new world.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
In 1947 India finally

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
gained its independence.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:02.958
And they could raise the Indian flag and become a sovereign nation,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
but in very big difficulties down there.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
(Applause)

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:12.958
In 1949 we saw the emergence of the modern China

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
in a way which surprised the world.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
And what happened?

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
What happens in the after independence?

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
You can see that the health started to improve.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
Children started to go to school.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
Health services were provided.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
This is the Great Leap Forward, when China fell down.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
It was central planning by Mao Tse Tung.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
China recovered. Then they said,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
"Nevermore, stupid central planning."

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
But they went up here, and India was trying to follow.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
And they were catching up indeed.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
And both countries had the better health, but still

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
a very low economy.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
And we came to 1978, and Mao Tse Tung died,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
and a new guy turned up from the left.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
And it was Deng Xiaoping coming out here.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
And he said, "Doesn't matter

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
if a cat is white or black,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
as long as it catches mice."

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
Because catching mice

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
is what the two cats wanted to do.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
And you can see the two cats being here,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
China and India, wanting to catch the mices over there, you know.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
And they decided to go not only for health and education,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
but also starting to grow their economy.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And the market reformer was successful there.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
In '92 India follows with a market reform.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
And they go quite closely together,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
and you can see that the similarity with India and China,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
in many ways, are greater than the differences with them.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
And here they march on. And will they catch up?

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
This is the big question today.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
There they are today.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
Now what does it mean that the --

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
(Applause)

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
the averages there -- this is the average of China.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
If I would split China, look here,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Shanghai has already catched up.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
Shanghai is already there.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
And it's healthier than the United States.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
But on the other hand, Guizhou, one of the poorest

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
inland provinces of China, is there.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:01.958
And if I split Guizhou into urban and rural,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
the rural part of Guizhou goes down there.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
You see this enormous inequity in China,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
in the midst of fast economic growth.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
And if I would also look at India,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
you have another type of inequity, actually, in India.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:19.958
The geographical, macro-geographical difference is not so big.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
Uttar Pradesh, the biggest of the states here,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
is poorer and has a lower health than the rest of India.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
Kerala is flying on top there,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
matching United States in health,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
but not in economy.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
And here, Maharashtra, with Mumbai,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
is forging forward.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
Now in India, the big inequities are within the state,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
rather than between the states.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
And that is not a bad thing, in itself.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:47.958
If you have a lot inequity, macro-geographical inequities

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
can be more difficult in the long term to deal with,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
than if it is in the same area where you have a growth center

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
relatively close to where poor people are living.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
No, there is one more inequity. Look there, United States.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:00.958
(Laughter)

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
Oh, they broke my frame.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
Washington, D.C. went out here.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
My friends at Gapminder wanted me to show this

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
because there is a new leader in Washington

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
who is really concerned about the health system.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
And I can understand him, because Washington, D.C.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
is so rich over there

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
but they are not as healthy as Kerala.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
It's quite interesting, isn't it?

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:27.958
(Applause)

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
I can see a business opportunity for Kerala,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
helping fix the health system in the United States.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
(Laughter)

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
(Applause)

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
Now here we have the whole world. You have the legend down there.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:43.958
And when you see the two giant cats here, pushing forward,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
you see that in between them

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
and ahead of them,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
is the whole emerging economies of the world,

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:53.958
which Thomas Friedman so correctly called the "flat world."

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
You can see that in health and education,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
a large part of the world population is putting forward,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
but in Africa, and other parts,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
as in rural Guizhou in China,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
there is still people with low health and very low economy.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
We have an enormous disparity in the world.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:12.958
But most of the world in the middle are pushing forwards very fast.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
Now, back to my projections.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:19.958
When will it catch up? I have to go back to very conventional graph.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
I will show income per person on this axis instead,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
poor down here, rich up there.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
And then time here, from 1858

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
I start the world.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
And we shall see what will happen with these countries.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
You see, China under foreign domination

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
actually lowered their income and came down to the Indian level here.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:41.958
Whereas U.K. and United States is getting richer and richer.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
And after Second World War, United States is richer than U.K.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
But independence is coming here.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
Growth is starting, economic reform.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
Growth is faster, and with projection from IMF

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
you can see where you expect them to be in 2014.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:12:00.958
Now, the question is, "When will the catch up take place?"

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
Look at, look at the United States.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
Can you see the bubble?

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
The bubbles, not my bubbles,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
but the financial bubbles.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:13.958
That's the dot com bubble. This is the Lehman Brothers doorstep there.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
You see it came down there.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:20.958
And it seems this is another rock coming down there, you know.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
So they doesn't seem to go this way, these countries.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
They seem to go in a more humble growth way, you know.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
And people interested in growth

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
are turning their eyes towards Asia.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
I can compare to Japan. This is Japan coming up.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
You see, Japan did it like that.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
We add Japan to it.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
And there is no doubt that fast catch up

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
can take place.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
Can you see here what Japan did?

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
Japan did it like this, until full catch up,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:51.958
and then they follow with the other high-income economies.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
But the real projections for those ones,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:59.958
I would like to give it like this.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
Can be worse, can be better.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
It's always difficult to predict, especially about the future.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
Now, a historian tells me it's even more difficult to predict about the past.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
(Laughter)

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
I think I'm in a difficult position here.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
Inequalities in China and India

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:19.958
I consider really the big obstacle

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:23.958
because to bring the entire population into growth and prosperity

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
is what will create a domestic market,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
what will avoid social instability,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
and which will make use of the entire capacity

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
of the population.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.958
So, social investments in health, education and infrastructure,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:43.958
and electricity is really what is needed in India and China.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
You know the climate. We have great international experts

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
within India telling us that the climate is changing,

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
and actions has to be taken,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
otherwise China and India would be the countries

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
most to suffer from climate change.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
And I consider India and China the best partners in the world

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
in a good global climate policy.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
But they ain't going to pay

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
for what others, who have more money,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
have largely created, and I can agree on that.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
But what I'm really worried about is war.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
Will the former rich countries really accept

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
a completely changed world economy,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
and a shift of power away from where it has been

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
the last 50 to 100 to 150 years,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
back to Asia?

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
And will Asia be able to handle that

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
new position of being in charge

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
of being the most mighty, and the governors of the world?

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
So, always avoid war,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
because that always pushes human beings backward.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:40.958
Now if these inequalities, climate and war can be avoided,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
get ready for a world in equity,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
because this is what seems to be happening.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
And that vision that I got as a young student,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:54.958
1972, that Indians can be much better than Swedes,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
is just about to happen.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
And it will happen precisely

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:03.958
the year 2048

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
in the later part of the summer, in July,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
more precisely, the 27th of July.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:17.958
(Applause)

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:21.958
The 27th of July, 2048

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
is my 100th birthday.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
(Laughter)

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
And I expect to speak

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:31.958
in the first session of the 39th TED India.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
Get your bookings in time. Thank you very much.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:41.958
(Applause)

title: Transition to a world without oil
transcript: As a culture, we tell ourselves lots of stories about the future, and where we might move forward from this point. Some of those stories are that somebody is just going to sort everything out for us. Other stories are that everything is on the verge of unraveling.But I want to tell you a different story here today. Like all stories, it has a beginning. My work, for a long time, has been involved in education, in teaching people practical skills for sustainability, teaching people how to take responsibility for growing some of their own food, how to build buildings using local materials, how to generate their own energy, and so on.I lived in Ireland, built the first straw-bale houses in Ireland, and some cob buildings and all this kind of thing. But all my work for many years was focused around the idea that sustainability means basically looking at the globalized economic growth model, and moderating what comes in at one end, and moderating the outputs at the other end. And then I came into contact with a way of looking at things which actually changed that profoundly.And in order to introduce you to that, I've got something here that I'm going to unveil, which is one of the great marvels of the modern age. And it's something so astounding and so astonishing that I think maybe as I remove this cloth a suitable gasp of amazement might be appropriate. If you could help me with that it would be fantastic. (Laughter) This is a liter of oil.This bottle of oil, distilled over a hundred million years of geological time, ancient sunlight, contains the energy equivalent of about five weeks hard human manual labor — equivalent to about 35 strong people coming round and working for you. We can turn it into a dazzling array of materials, medicine, modern clothing, laptops, a whole range of different things. It gives us an energy return that's unimaginable, historically. We've based the design of our settlements, our business models, our transport plans, even the idea of economic growth, some would argue, on the assumption that we will have this in perpetuity.Yet, when we take a step back, and look over the span of history, at what we might call the petroleum interval, it's a short period in history where we've discovered this extraordinary material, and then based a whole way of life around it. But as we straddle the top of this energy mountain, at this stage, we move from a time where our economic success, our sense of individual prowess and well-being is directly linked to how much of this we consume, to a time when actually our degree of oil dependency is our degree of vulnerability.And it's increasingly clear that we aren't going to be able to rely on the fact that we're going to have this at our disposal forever. For every four barrels of oil that we consume, we only discover one. And that gap continues to widen. There is also the fact that the amount of energy that we get back from the oil that we discover is falling. In the 1930s we got 100 units of energy back for every one that we put in to extract it. Completely unprecedented, historically. Already that's fallen to about 11. And that's why, now, the new breakthroughs, the new frontiers in terms of oil extraction are scrambling about in Alberta, or at the bottom of the oceans.There are 98 oil-producing nations in the world. But of those, 65 have already passed their peak. The moment when the world on average passes this peak, people wonder when that's going to happen. And there is an emerging case that maybe that was what happened last July when the oil prices were so high.But are we to assume that the same brilliance and creativity and adaptability that got us up to the top of that energy mountain in the first place is somehow mysteriously going to evaporate when we have to design a creative way back down the other side? No. But the thinking that we have to come up with has to be based on a realistic assessment of where we are.There is also the issue of climate change, is the other thing that underpins this transition approach. But the thing that I notice, as I talk to climate scientists, is the increasingly terrified look they have in their eyes, as the data that's coming in, which is far ahead of what the IPCC are talking about. So the IPCC said that we might see significant breakup of the arctic ice in 2100, in their worst case scenario. Actually, if current trends continue, it could all be gone in five or 10 years' time. If just three percent of the carbon locked up in the arctic permafrost is released as the world warms, it would offset all the savings that we need to make, in carbon, over the next 40 years to avoid runaway climate change. We have no choice other than deep and urgent decarbonization.But I'm always very interested to think about what might the stories be that the generations further down the slope from us are going to tell about us. "The generation that lived at the top of the mountain, that partied so hard, and so abused its inheritance." And one of the ways I like to do that is to look back at the stories people used to tell before we had cheap oil, before we had fossil fuels, and people relied on their own muscle, animal muscle energy, or a little bit of wind, little bit of water energy.We had stories like "The Seven-League Boots": the giant who had these boots, where, once you put them on, with every stride you could cover seven leagues, or 21 miles, a kind of travel completely unimaginable to people without that kind of energy at their disposal.Stories like The Magic Porridge Pot, where you had a pot where if you knew the magic words, this pot would just make as much food as you liked, without you having to do any work, provided you could remember the other magic word to stop it making porridge. Otherwise you'd flood your entire town with warm porridge.There is the story of "The Elves and the Shoemaker." The people who make shoes go to sleep, wake up in the morning, and all the shoes are magically made for them. It's something that was unimaginable to people then.Now we have the seven-league boots in the form of Ryanair and Easyjet. We have the magic porridge pot in the form of Walmart and Tesco. And we have the elves in the form of China. But we don't appreciate what an astonishing thing that has been.And what are the stories that we tell ourselves now, as we look forward about where we're going to go. And I would argue that there are four. There is the idea of business as usual, that the future will be like the present, just more of it. But as we've seen over the last year, I think that's an idea that is increasingly coming into question. And in terms of climate change, is something that is not actually feasible.There is the idea of hitting the wall, that actually somehow everything is so fragile that it might just all unravel and collapse. This is a popular story in some places. The third story is the idea that technology can solve everything, that technology can somehow get us through this completely.And it's an idea that I think is very prevalent at these TED Talks, the idea that we can invent our way out of a profound economic and energy crisis, that a move to a knowledge economy can somehow neatly sidestep those energy constraints, the idea that we'll discover some fabulous new source of energy that will mean we can sweep all concerns about energy security to one side, the idea that we can step off neatly onto a completely renewable world.But the world isn't Second Life. We can't create new land and new energy systems at the click of a mouse. And as we sit, exchanging free ideas with each other, there are still people mining coal in order to power the servers, extracting the minerals to make all of those things. The breakfast that we eat as we sit down to check our email in the morning is still transported at great distances, usually at the expense of the local, more resilient food systems that would have supplied that in the past, which we've so effectively devalued and dismantled.We can be astonishingly inventive and creative. But we also live in a world with very real constraints and demands. Energy and technology are not the same thing. What I'm involved with is the transition response. And this is really about looking the challenges of peak oil and climate change square in the face, and responding with a creativity and an adaptability and an imagination that we really need. It's something which has spread incredibly fast. And it is something which has several characteristics.It's viral. It seems to spread under the radar very, very quickly. It's open source. It's something which everybody who's involved with it develops and passes on as they work with it. It's self-organizing. There is no great central organization that pushes this; people just pick up an idea and they run with it, and they implement it where they are. It's solutions-focused. It's very much looking at what people can do where they are, to respond to this. It's sensitive to place and to scale.Transitional is completely different. Transition groups in Chile, transition groups in the U.S., transition groups here, what they're doing looks very different in every place that you go to. It learns very much from its mistakes. And it feels historic. It tries to create a sense that this is a historic opportunity to do something really extraordinary. And it's a process which is really joyful. People have a huge amount of fun doing this, reconnecting with other people as they do it. One of the things that underpins it is this idea of resilience.And I think, in many ways, the idea of resilience is a more useful concept than the idea of sustainability. The idea of resilience comes from the study of ecology. And it's really about how systems, settlements, withstand shock from the outside. When they encounter shock from the outside that they don't just unravel and fall to pieces. And I think it's a more useful concept than sustainability, as I said.When our supermarkets have only two or three days' worth of food in them at any one time, often sustainability tends to focus on the energy efficiency of the freezers and on the packaging that the lettuces are wrapped up in. Looking through the lens of resilience, we really question how we've let ourselves get into a situation that's so vulnerable. Resilience runs much deeper: it's about building modularity into what we do, building surge breakers into how we organize the basic things that support us.This is a photograph of the Bristol and District Market Gardeners Association, in 1897. This is at a time when the city of Bristol, which is quite close to here, was surrounded by commercial market gardens, which provided a significant amount of the food that was consumed in the town, and created a lot of employment for people, as well. There was a degree of resilience, if you like, at that time, which we can now only look back on with envy.So how does this transition idea work? So basically, you have a group of people who are excited by the idea. They pick up some of the tools that we've developed. They start to run an awareness-raising program looking at how this might actually work in the town. They show films, they give talks, and so on. It's a process which is playful and creative and informative. Then they start to form working groups, looking at different aspects of this, and then from that, there emerge a whole lot of projects which then the transition project itself starts to support and enable.So it started out with some work I was involved in in Ireland, where I was teaching, and has since spread. There are now over 200 formal transition projects. And there are thousands of others who are at what we call the mulling stage. They are mulling whether they're going to take it further. And actually a lot of them are doing huge amounts of stuff. But what do they actually do? You know, it's a kind of nice idea, but what do they actually do on the ground?Well, I think it's really important to make the point that actually you know, this isn't something which is going to do everything on its own. We need international legislation from Copenhagen and so on. We need national responses. We need local government responses. But all of those things are going to be much easier if we have communities that are vibrant and coming up with ideas and leading from the front, making unelectable policies electable, over the next 5 to 10 years.Some of the things that emerge from it are local food projects, like community-supported agriculture schemes, urban food production, creating local food directories, and so on. A lot of places now are starting to set up their own energy companies, community-owned energy companies, where the community can invest money into itself, to start putting in place the kind of renewable energy infrastructure that we need. A lot of places are working with their local schools. Newent in the Forest of Dean: big polytunnel they built for the school; the kids are learning how to grow food. Promoting recycling, things like garden-share, that matches up people who don't have a garden who would like to grow food, with people who have gardens they aren't using anymore. Planting productive trees throughout urban spaces. And also starting to play around with the idea of alternative currencies.This is Lewes in Sussex, who have recently launched the Lewes Pound, a currency that you can only spend within the town, as a way of starting to cycle money within the local economy. You take it anywhere else, it's not worth anything. But actually within the town you start to create these economic cycles much more effectively.Another thing that they do is what we call an energy descent plan, which is basically to develop a plan B for the town. Most of our local authorities, when they sit down to plan for the next five, 10, 15, 20 years of a community, still start by assuming that there will be more energy, more cars, more housing, more jobs, more growth, and so on. What does it look like if that's not the case? And how can we embrace that and actually come up with something that was actually more likely to sustain everybody? As a friend of mine says, "Life is a series of things you're not quite ready for." And that's certainly been my experience with transition. From three years ago, it just being an idea, this has become something that has virally swept around the world. We're getting a lot of interest from government. Ed Miliband, the energy minister of this country, was invited to come to our recent conference as a keynote listener. Which he did — (Laughter) (Applause) — and has since become a great advocate of the whole idea.There are now two local authorities in this country who have declared themselves transitional local authorities, Leicestershire and Somerset. And in Stroud, the transition group there, in effect, wrote the local government's food plan. And the head of the council said, "If we didn't have Transition Stroud, we would have to invent all of that community infrastructure for the first time." As we see the spread of it, we see national hubs emerging.In Scotland, the Scottish government's climate change fund has funded Transition Scotland as a national organization supporting the spread of this. And we see it all over the place as well now. But the key to transition is thinking not that we have to change everything now, but that things are already inevitably changing, and what we need to do is to work creatively with that, based on asking the right questions.I think I'd like to just return at the end to the idea of stories. Because I think stories are vital here. And actually the stories that we tell ourselves, we have a huge dearth of stories about how to move forward creatively from here. And one of the key things that transition does is to pull those stories out of what people are doing. Stories about the community that's produced its own 21 pound note, for example, the school that's turned its car park into a food garden, the community that's founded its own energy company. And for me, one of the great stories recently was the Obamas digging up the south lawn of the White House to create a vegetable garden. Because the last time that was done, when Eleanor Roosevelt did it, it led to the creation of 20 million vegetable gardens across the United States.So the question I'd like to leave you with, really, is — for all aspects of the things that your community needs in order to thrive, how can it be done in such a way that drastically reduces its carbon emissions, while also building resilience?Personally, I feel enormously grateful to have lived through the age of cheap oil. I've been astonishingly lucky, we've been astonishingly lucky. But let us honor what it has bought us, and move forward from this point. Because if we cling to it, and continue to assume that it can underpin our choices, the future that it presents to us is one which is really unmanageable. And by loving and leaving all that oil has done for us, and that the Oil Age has done for us, we are able to then begin the creation of a world which is more resilient, more nourishing, and in which, we find ourselves fitter, more skilled and more connected to each other. Thank you very much. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
As a culture, we tell ourselves lots of stories

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
about the future,

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
and where we might move forward from this point.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
Some of those stories are that

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
somebody is just going to sort everything out for us.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:27.958
Other stories are that everything is on the verge of unraveling.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:29.958
But I want to tell you a different story here today.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
Like all stories, it has a beginning.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
My work, for a long time, has been involved in education,

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
in teaching people practical skills

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
for sustainability,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
teaching people how to take responsibility

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
for growing some of their own food,

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
how to build buildings using local materials,

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
how to generate their own energy, and so on.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:52.958
I lived in Ireland, built the first straw-bale houses in Ireland,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
and some cob buildings and all this kind of thing.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
But all my work for many years was focused

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
around the idea that sustainability

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
means basically looking at

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
the globalized economic growth model,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
and moderating what comes in at one end,

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
and moderating the outputs at the other end.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
And then I came into contact with a way of looking at things

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
which actually changed that profoundly.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
And in order to introduce you to that,

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
I've got something here that I'm going to unveil,

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.958
which is one of the great marvels of the modern age.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
And it's something so astounding and so astonishing

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:27.958
that I think maybe as I remove this cloth

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:30.958
a suitable gasp of amazement might be appropriate.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:34.958
If you could help me with that it would be fantastic.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:38.958
(Laughter)

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
This is a liter of oil.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
This bottle of oil,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:47.958
distilled over a hundred million years of geological time,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
ancient sunlight,

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
contains the energy equivalent of about five weeks

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:54.958
hard human manual labor --

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:58.958
equivalent to about 35 strong people

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.958
coming round and working for you.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:05.958
We can turn it into a dazzling array of materials,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
medicine, modern clothing,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:11.958
laptops, a whole range of different things.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:16.958
It gives us an energy return that's unimaginable, historically.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:18.958
We've based the design of our settlements,

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
our business models, our transport plans,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
even the idea of economic growth, some would argue,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:27.958
on the assumption that we will have this in perpetuity.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
Yet, when we take a step back,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
and look over the span of history,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.958
at what we might call the petroleum interval,

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
it's a short period in history

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
where we've discovered this extraordinary material,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
and then based a whole way of life around it.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:47.958
But as we straddle the top of this energy mountain, at this stage,

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
we move from a time where our economic success,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
our sense of individual prowess and well-being

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:57.958
is directly linked to how much of this we consume,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
to a time when actually our degree of oil dependency

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
is our degree of vulnerability.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
And it's increasingly clear that we

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
aren't going to be able to rely on the fact that

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
we're going to have this at our disposal forever.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
For every four barrels of oil that we consume,

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
we only discover one.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
And that gap continues to widen.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
There is also the fact that the amount of energy

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
that we get back from the oil that we discover is falling.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
In the 1930s we got 100 units of energy back

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
for every one that we put in to extract it.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
Completely unprecedented, historically.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
Already that's fallen to about 11.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
And that's why, now,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
the new breakthroughs, the new frontiers

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
in terms of oil extraction are scrambling about in Alberta,

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
or at the bottom of the oceans.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
There are 98 oil-producing nations in the world.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
But of those, 65 have already passed their peak.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
The moment when the world on average passes this peak,

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
people wonder when that's going to happen.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:51.958
And there is an emerging case

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
that maybe that was what happened last July

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
when the oil prices were so high.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
But are we to assume that the same brilliance

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
and creativity and adaptability

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
that got us up to the top of that energy mountain in the first place

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
is somehow mysteriously going to evaporate

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:09.958
when we have to design a creative way back down the other side?

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
No. But the thinking that we have to come up with

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
has to be based on a realistic assessment

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
of where we are.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
There is also the issue of climate change,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
is the other thing that underpins this transition approach.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
But the thing that I notice, as I talk to climate scientists,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
is the increasingly terrified look they have in their eyes,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
as the data that's coming in,

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:33.958
which is far ahead of what the IPCC are talking about.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
So the IPCC said

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
that we might see significant breakup

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
of the arctic ice in 2100, in their worst case scenario.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
Actually, if current trends continue,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
it could all be gone in five or 10 years' time.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:49.958
If just three percent of the carbon locked up in the arctic permafrost

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
is released as the world warms,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
it would offset all the savings that we need to make,

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
in carbon, over the next 40 years to avoid runaway climate change.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:05:01.958
We have no choice other than deep and urgent decarbonization.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
But I'm always very interested to think about

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
what might the stories be

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
that the generations further down the slope from us

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
are going to tell about us.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
"The generation that lived at the top of the mountain,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:18.958
that partied so hard, and so abused its inheritance."

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
And one of the ways I like to do that

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
is to look back at the stories people used to tell

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
before we had cheap oil, before we had fossil fuels,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
and people relied on their own muscle, animal muscle energy,

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
or a little bit of wind, little bit of water energy.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
We had stories like "The Seven-League Boots":

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
the giant who had these boots, where, once you put them on,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:40.958
with every stride you could cover seven leagues, or 21 miles,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
a kind of travel completely unimaginable

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
to people without that kind of energy at their disposal.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
Stories like The Magic Porridge Pot,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
where you had a pot where if you knew the magic words,

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
this pot would just make as much food as you liked,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
without you having to do any work,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
provided you could remember the other magic word to stop it making porridge.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
Otherwise you'd flood your entire town with warm porridge.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
There is the story of "The Elves and the Shoemaker."

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
The people who make shoes go to sleep, wake up in the morning,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
and all the shoes are magically made for them.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
It's something that was unimaginable to people then.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
Now we have the seven-league boots

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
in the form of Ryanair and Easyjet.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
We have the magic porridge pot

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
in the form of Walmart and Tesco.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
And we have the elves in the form of China.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:29.958
But we don't appreciate what an astonishing

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
thing that has been.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
And what are the stories that we tell ourselves now,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
as we look forward about where we're going to go.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
And I would argue that there are four. There is the idea of business as usual,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
that the future will be like the present, just more of it.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
But as we've seen over the last year, I think that's an idea

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
that is increasingly coming into question.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
And in terms of climate change,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:52.958
is something that is not actually feasible.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
There is the idea of hitting the wall,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
that actually somehow everything is so fragile

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
that it might just all unravel and collapse.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
This is a popular story in some places.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
The third story is the idea that technology can solve everything,

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:09.958
that technology can somehow get us through this completely.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:13.958
And it's an idea that I think is very prevalent at these TED Talks,

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
the idea that we can invent our way out of a profound

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
economic and energy crisis,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
that a move to a knowledge economy

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
can somehow neatly sidestep those energy constraints,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
the idea that we'll discover some fabulous new source of energy

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
that will mean we can sweep all concerns

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
about energy security to one side,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
the idea that we can step off neatly

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
onto a completely renewable world.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
But the world isn't Second Life.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
We can't create new land and new energy systems at the click of a mouse.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
And as we sit, exchanging free ideas with each other,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
there are still people mining coal

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
in order to power the servers, extracting the minerals

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
to make all of those things.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
The breakfast that we eat as we sit down

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
to check our email in the morning

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
is still transported at great distances,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
usually at the expense of the local, more resilient

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
food systems that would have supplied that in the past,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:05.958
which we've so effectively devalued and dismantled.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
We can be astonishingly inventive and creative.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.958
But we also live in a world with very real constraints and demands.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
Energy and technology are not the same thing.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
What I'm involved with is the transition response.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
And this is really about looking the challenges

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
of peak oil and climate change square in the face,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
and responding with a creativity and an adaptability

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
and an imagination that we really need.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
It's something which has spread incredibly fast.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
And it is something which has several characteristics.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:38.958
It's viral. It seems to spread under the radar very, very quickly.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:42.958
It's open source. It's something which everybody who's involved with it

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:46.958
develops and passes on as they work with it.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
It's self-organizing. There is no great central organization

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
that pushes this; people just pick up an idea

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
and they run with it, and they implement it where they are.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
It's solutions-focused. It's very much looking at what people can do

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
where they are, to respond to this.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
It's sensitive to place and to scale.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Transitional is completely different.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:08.958
Transition groups in Chile, transition groups in the U.S., transition groups here,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
what they're doing looks very different in every place that you go to.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
It learns very much from its mistakes.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
And it feels historic. It tries to create a sense

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
that this is a historic opportunity

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
to do something really extraordinary.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
And it's a process which is really joyful.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
People have a huge amount of fun doing this,

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
reconnecting with other people as they do it.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
One of the things that underpins it is this idea of resilience.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
And I think, in many ways, the idea of resilience

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:37.958
is a more useful concept than the idea of sustainability.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
The idea of resilience comes from the study of ecology.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
And it's really about how systems,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
settlements, withstand shock from the outside.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
When they encounter shock from the outside

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
that they don't just unravel and fall to pieces.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:53.958
And I think it's a more useful concept than sustainability, as I said.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:57.958
When our supermarkets have only two or three days' worth of food in them

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
at any one time, often sustainability tends to focus on

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
the energy efficiency of the freezers

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
and on the packaging that the lettuces are wrapped up in.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
Looking through the lens of resilience,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:11.958
we really question how we've let ourselves get into a situation

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
that's so vulnerable.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
Resilience runs much deeper:

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
it's about building modularity into what we do,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:22.958
building surge breakers into how we organize the basic things that support us.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
This is a photograph of the Bristol and District

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:28.958
Market Gardeners Association, in 1897.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
This is at a time when the city of Bristol,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
which is quite close to here,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
was surrounded by commercial market gardens,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
which provided a significant amount of the food

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:41.958
that was consumed in the town, and created a lot of employment for people, as well.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
There was a degree of resilience, if you like, at that time,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:48.958
which we can now only look back on with envy.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
So how does this transition idea work?

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
So basically, you have a group of people who are excited by the idea.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
They pick up some of the tools that we've developed.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
They start to run an awareness-raising program

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
looking at how this might actually work in the town.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
They show films, they give talks, and so on.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
It's a process which is playful and creative

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
and informative.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
Then they start to form working groups, looking at different aspects of this,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
and then from that, there emerge a whole lot of projects

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
which then the transition project itself

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:21.958
starts to support and enable.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
So it started out with some work I was involved in in Ireland,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
where I was teaching, and has since spread.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
There are now over 200 formal transition projects.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:32.958
And there are thousands of others who are at what we call the mulling stage.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
They are mulling whether they're going to take it further.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
And actually a lot of them are doing huge amounts of stuff.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
But what do they actually do? You know, it's a kind of nice idea,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
but what do they actually do on the ground?

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Well, I think it's really important to make the point that actually

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
you know, this isn't something which is going to do everything on its own.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:52.958
We need international legislation from Copenhagen and so on.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
We need national responses. We need local government responses.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
But all of those things are going to be much easier

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
if we have communities that are vibrant and coming up with ideas

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
and leading from the front, making unelectable policies electable,

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
over the next 5 to 10 years.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
Some of the things that emerge from it are local food projects,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
like community-supported agriculture schemes,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:15.958
urban food production, creating local food directories, and so on.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
A lot of places now are starting to set up their own energy companies,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
community-owned energy companies,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
where the community can invest money into itself,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
to start putting in place

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
the kind of renewable energy infrastructure that we need.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
A lot of places are working with their local schools.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
Newent in the Forest of Dean: big polytunnel they built for the school;

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
the kids are learning how to grow food.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
Promoting recycling, things like garden-share,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
that matches up people who don't have a garden

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
who would like to grow food, with people who have gardens they aren't using anymore.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
Planting productive trees throughout urban spaces.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
And also starting to play around with the idea of

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
alternative currencies.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
This is Lewes in Sussex,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
who have recently launched the Lewes Pound,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
a currency that you can only spend within the town,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
as a way of starting to cycle money within the local economy.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
You take it anywhere else, it's not worth anything.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
But actually within the town you start to create these economic

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
cycles much more effectively.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
Another thing that they do is what we call an energy descent plan,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
which is basically to develop a plan B for the town.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.958
Most of our local authorities, when they sit down to plan

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
for the next five, 10, 15, 20 years of a community,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
still start by assuming that there will be more energy,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
more cars, more housing,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
more jobs, more growth, and so on.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
What does it look like if that's not the case? And how can we embrace that

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
and actually come up with something that was actually more likely

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
to sustain everybody?

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:36.958
As a friend of mine says, "Life is a series of things you're not quite ready for."

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
And that's certainly been my experience with transition.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
From three years ago, it just being an idea,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:44.958
this has become something that has virally swept around the world.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
We're getting a lot of interest from government. Ed Miliband,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:50.958
the energy minister of this country, was invited to come to our recent conference

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
as a keynote listener.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
Which he did --

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:55.958
(Laughter)

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
(Applause) --

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:02.958
and has since become a great advocate of the whole idea.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
There are now two local authorities in this country

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
who have declared themselves transitional local authorities,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
Leicestershire and Somerset. And in Stroud,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:14.958
the transition group there, in effect, wrote the local government's food plan.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
And the head of the council said,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
"If we didn't have Transition Stroud, we would have to invent

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
all of that community infrastructure for the first time."

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
As we see the spread of it, we see national hubs emerging.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
In Scotland, the Scottish government's climate change fund

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
has funded Transition Scotland

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
as a national organization supporting the spread of this.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
And we see it all over the place as well now.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
But the key to transition is thinking not that we have to change everything now,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
but that things are already inevitably changing,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
and what we need to do is to work creatively with that,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
based on asking the right questions.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
I think I'd like to just return at the end

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
to the idea of stories.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
Because I think stories are vital here.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
And actually the stories that we tell ourselves,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:01.958
we have a huge dearth of stories about how to move forward creatively from here.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
And one of the key things that transition does

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
is to pull those stories out of what people are doing.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
Stories about the community that's produced

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
its own 21 pound note, for example,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
the school that's turned its car park into a food garden,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
the community that's founded its own energy company.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
And for me, one of the great stories recently

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
was the Obamas digging up the south lawn of the White House

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
to create a vegetable garden. Because the last time that was done,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
when Eleanor Roosevelt did it,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:31.958
it led to the creation of 20 million vegetable gardens across the United States.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
So the question I'd like to leave you with, really,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
is -- for all aspects of the things that your community needs

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
in order to thrive,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
how can it be done in such a way

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
that drastically reduces its carbon emissions,

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
while also building resilience?

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
Personally, I feel enormously grateful

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
to have lived through the age of cheap oil.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
I've been astonishingly lucky, we've been astonishingly lucky.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
But let us honor what it has bought us,

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
and move forward from this point.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
Because if we cling to it, and continue to assume

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
that it can underpin our choices,

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
the future that it presents to us is one which is really unmanageable.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
And by loving and leaving all that oil has done for us,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
and that the Oil Age has done for us,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
we are able to then begin the creation

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
of a world which is more resilient,

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
more nourishing,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
and in which, we find ourselves fitter, more skilled

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
and more connected to each other.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
Thank you very much.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:30.958
(Applause)

title: Turning dunes into architecture
transcript: It's a bit funny to be at a conference dedicated to things not seen, and present my proposal to build a 6,000-kilometer-long wall across the entire African continent. About the size of the Great Wall of China, this would hardly be an invisible structure. And yet it's made from parts that are invisible, or near-invisible, to the naked eye: bacteria and grains of sand.Now, as architects we're trained to solve problems. But I don't really believe in architectural problems; I only believe in opportunities. Which is why I'll show you a threat, and an architectural response. The threat is desertification. My response is a sandstone wall made from bacteria and solidified sand, stretching across the desert.Now, sand is a magical material of beautiful contradictions. It is simple and complex. It is peaceful and violent. It is always the same, never the same, endlessly fascinating. One billion grains of sand come into existence in the world each second. That's a cyclical process. As rocks and mountains die, grains of sand are born. Some of those grains may then cement naturally into sandstone. And as the sandstone weathers, new grains break free. Some of those grains may then accumulate on a massive scale, into a sand dune.In a way, the static, stone mountain becomes a moving mountain of sand. But, moving mountains can be dangerous. Let me try and explain why. Dry areas cover more than one third of the Earth's land surfaces. Some are already deserts; others are being seriously degraded by the sand. Just south of the Sahara we find the Sahel. The name means "edge of the desert." And this is the region most closely associated with desertification. It was here in the late '60s and early '70s that major droughts brought three million people to become dependent upon emergency food aid, with about up to 250,000 dying.This is a catastrophe waiting to happen again. And it's one that gets very little attention. In our accelerated media culture, desertification is simply too slow to reach the headlines. It's nothing like a tsunami or a Katrina: too few crying children and smashed up houses. And yet desertification is a major threat on all continents, affecting some 110 countries and about 70 percent of the world's agricultural drylands.It seriously threatens the livelihoods of millions of people, and especially in Africa and China. And it is largely an issue that we've created for ourselves through unsustainable use of scarce resources. So, we get climate change. We get droughts, increased desertification, crashing food systems, water scarcity, famine, forced migration, political instability, warfare, crisis. That's a potential scenario if we fail to take this seriously. But, how far away is it?I went to Sokoto in northern Nigeria to try and find out how far away it is. The dunes here move southward at a pace of around 600 meters a year. That's the Sahara eating up almost [two meters] a day of the arable land, physically pushing people away from their homes. Here I am — I'm the second person on the left — (Laughter) with the elders in Gidan-Kara, a tiny village outside of Sokoto.They had to move this village in 1987 as a huge dune threatened to swallow it. So, they moved the entire village, hut by hut. This is where the village used to be. It took us about 10 minutes to climb up to the top of that dune, which goes to show why they had to move to a safer location. That's the kind of forced migration that desertification can lead to. If you happen to live close to the desert border, you can pretty much calculate how long it will be before you have to carry your kids away, and abandon your home and your life as you know it.Now, sand dunes cover only about one fifth of our deserts. And still, those extreme environments are very good places if we want to stop the shifting sands. Four years ago, 23 African countries came together to create the Great Green Wall Sahara. A fantastic project, the initial plan called for a shelter belt of trees to be planted right across the African continent, from Mauritania in the west, all the way to Djibouti in the east. If you want to stop a sand dune from moving, what you need to make sure to do is to stop the grains from avalanching over its crest. And a good way of doing that, the most efficient way, is to use some kind of sand catcher. Trees or cacti are good for this. But, one of the problems with planting trees is that the people in these regions are so poor that they chop them down for firewood.Now there is an alternative to just planting trees and hoping that they won't get chopped down. This sandstone wall that I'm proposing essentially does three things. It adds roughness to the dune's surface, to the texture of the dune's surface, binding the grains. It provides a physical support structure for the trees, and it creates physical spaces, habitable spaces inside of the sand dunes. If people live inside of the green barrier they can help support the trees, protect them from humans, and from some of the forces of nature. Inside of the dunes we find shade. We can start harvesting condensation, and start greening the desert from within.Sand dunes are almost like ready-made buildings in a way. All we need to do is solidify the parts that we need to be solid, and then excavate the sand, and we have our architecture. We can either excavate it by hand or we can have the wind excavate it for us. So, the wind carries the sand onto the site and then it carries the redundant sand away from the structure for us.But, by now, you're probably asking, how am I planning to solidify a sand dune? How do we glue those grains of sand together? And the answer is, perhaps, that you use these guys, Bacillus pasteurii, a micro-organism that is readily available in wetlands and marshes, and does precisely that. It takes a pile of loose sand and it creates sandstone out of it. These images from the American Society for Microbiology show us the process.What happens is, you pour Bacillus pasteurii onto a pile of sand, and it starts filling up the voids in between the grains. A chemical process produces calcite, which is a kind of natural cement that binds the grains together. The whole cementation process takes about 24 hours. I learned about this from a professor at U.C. Davis called Jason DeJong. He managed to do it in a mere 1,400 minutes. Here I am, playing the part of the mad scientist, working with the bugs at UCL in London, trying to solidify them.So, how much would this cost? I'm not an economist, very much not, but I did, quite literally, a back of the envelope calculation — (Laughter) — and it seems that for a cubic meter of concrete we would have to pay in the region of 90 dollars. And, after an initial cost of 60 bucks to buy the bacteria, which you'll never have to pay again, one cubic meter of bacterial sand would be about 11 dollars.How do we construct something like this? Well, I'll quickly show you two options. The first is to create a kind of balloon structure, fill it with bacteria, then allow the sand to wash over the balloon, pop the balloon, as it were, disseminating the bacteria into the sand and solidifying it. Then, a few years afterwards, using permacultural strategies, we green that part of the desert.The second alternative would be to use injection piles. So, we pushed the piles down through the dune, and we create an initial bacterial surface. We then pull the piles up through the dune and we're able to create almost any conceivable shape inside of the sand with the sand acting as a mold as we go up. So, we have a way of turning sand into sandstone, and then creating these habitable spaces inside of the desert dunes.But, what should they look like? Well, I was inspired, for my architectural form, by tafoni, which look a little bit like this, this is a model representation of it. These are cavernous rock structures that I found on the site in Sokoto. And I realized that if I scaled them up, they would provide me with good spatial qualities, for ventilation, for thermal comfort, and for other things. Now, part of the formal control over this structure would be lost to nature, obviously, as the bacteria do their work. And I think this creates a kind of boundless beauty actually. I think there is really something in that articulation that is quite nice. We see the result, the traces, if you like, of the Bacillus pasteurii being harnessed to sculpt the desert into these habitable environments.Some people believe that this would spread uncontrollably, and that the bacteria would kill everything in its way. That's not true at all. It's a natural process. It goes on in nature today, and the bacteria die as soon as we stop feeding them. So, there it is — architectural anti-desertification structures made from the desert itself. Sand-stopping devices, made from sand. The world is likely to lose one third of its arable land by the end of the century. In a period of unprecedented population growth and increased food demands, this could prove disastrous. And quite frankly, we're putting our heads in the sand.If nothing else, I would like for this scheme to initiate a discussion. But, if I had something like a TED wish, it would be to actually get it built, to start building this habitable wall, this very, very long, but very narrow city in the desert, built into the dunescape itself. It's not only something that supports trees, but something that connects people and countries together. I would like to conclude by showing you an animation of the structure, and leave you with a sentence by Jorge Luis Borges.Borges said that "nothing is built on stone, everything is built on sand, but we must build as if the sand were stone."Now, there are many details left to explore in this scheme — political, practical, ethical, financial. My design, as it takes you down the rabbit hole, is fraught with many challenges and difficulties in the real world. But, it's a beginning, it's a vision. As Borges would have it, it's the sand. And I think now is really the time to turn it into stone. Thank you. (Applause)
